From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Mar  1 01:23:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat Mar  1 01:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail Network Options
In-Reply-To: <33205.63.105.27.245.1046384461.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0302281802340.29500-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Keith Nasman wrote:

> A client of mine is putting in another office location and I am to put in
> a server there. Right now they only have one office (we'll call it
> office1) with a fixed IP and their mail and website are on the
> server(server1) there. I will be installing server2 in office2 on it's own
> fixed-IP DSL line. I'm exploring the different options for delivering mail
> from server1 to server2.

It sounds like you have half of the problem solved. Let me repsond to each
point as they come up.
>
> 1) First thought was to just put .forward for each user to send the mail
> to user at new.ip and setup postfix to accept mail to the IP. For office2 to
> add a new user, they would have to add the user into server1, add a
> ..forward, and add the user to server2. Of course, if server1 is
> inaccessible office2 doesn't get their mail.

Well, you could do something like this, especially if you are dealing with
a small business of less than a dozen people total.
>
> 2) Don't do the .forward routine and just have all mail that doesn't have
> a user on server1 forwarded to the server2 and then bounced if there is no
> user. This is easier maintenance-wise but has the same fault of server1
> going down.

I don't think this is the best solution, even though it handles the
spam problem.
>
> 3) Set up the upstream DNS MX records to point server1.domain.com to one
> IP and server2.domain.com to the other IP. This avoids the server1 link
> problem. My question is whether or not the users could still have
> user at domain.com addresses at the office2 location or would they have to
> have user at server2.domain.com as their addresses. I'm guessing that they
> would have to be user at server2.domain.com.

As I understand standard practice -- & assuming that your client isn't
about to allow workers at one site to commute to the other -- this is
the way many commercial domains with multiple sites are set up. By this
I mean that setting up proper MX records with one server acting as the
secondary for the other is a Good Idea. Then IT takes the next step &
aliases all of the mailservers under one domain, so that to the outside
world everyone has an address in the user at domain.com form.

The other way this is done is to have one machine set up as a central
mail server, but still do the aliasing. Then the two offices use SMTP &
POP3 to send & receive email, & with the right kind of magic, your client's
employees can read their email from either office. The trick lies with
the aliasing, which I kinda remember how to do with sendmail -- but unless
you want to learn sendmail, I'd advise you to stick with either postfix or
exim.
>
> This is my first dealing with multiple physical locations under the same
> domain so I'd like to get more input on how this is normally done and
> whether there are other (probably obvious) options out there that I need
> to look at.
>
Well, I know the theory of this quite well: I haven't done the actual
implimentation, so I for one would like to hear how you solved this
problem & about any gotchas you encountered.

Geoff

Mr. Shepard replied:

>  This I know; at least with vacuum tubes it was easy to tell a dead one
>(and I had a tube tester, too). From the time the transitor was first 
>introduced the mantra was that solid-state devices would fail quickly or 
>last for years. I guess I have been lucky to not experience the quick
>failure before now.

I tell people that graphing solid state failures over time produces a
bath-tub shaped curve.

>  What I asked, poorly and in a round-about way, was if there was something
>other than the video card that might be responsible for the lack of signal
>to the monitor.

I liked Paul's suggestions. Perhaps you have a geek buddy or two in town who
might loan you an AGP video card? Perhaps the thrift store at freegeek.org
might have one they can sell you for cheap? Perhaps you know some computer
store with a liberal open-box returns policy?

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sat Mar  1 09:17:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sat Mar  1 09:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: hardware problem 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 28 Feb 2003 18:29:10 PST."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302281823090.10571-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200303011716.h21HGvZ30698@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

What was the result when you power cycled the machine?  I wouldn't assume
that card was broken until you see the absence of video on power up.
Problems with X, the screen saver, mouse/keyboard driver, or apm could cause 
the screen to stay blanked.  Only a power cycle will truly confirm
the card is broken.

Oh yes, don't forget to try swapping video cables.

galen

How about a non-os-specific question?

I have a SCSI tape drive hooked to an Adaptec 2940W controller. The 
controller posts. Should the controller recognize the drive during post, or 
does it ignore it, similar to how some EIDE controllers ignore CD ROMs 
during post?

I've tried setting the drive to various SCSI ids. It's an external drive, 
although I can take it out of the housing and hook it up to the card 
internally. I haven't tried that yet.

SCSI termination is present on the back of the drive housing, and it's turn 
on in the card setup. The card doesn't recognize the drive in setup either.

The drive is a Sony, SDT-S9000. It basically a SDT-9000 with an external 
chassis.

Thanks in advance for any ideas.

Russ




From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Sun Mar  2 17:32:01 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Sun Mar  2 17:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware question
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBD65@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

I don't know if your specific controller has different options, but every
SCSI controller I've used has enumerated devices on its bus(es) on POST.

1) do you have other devices besides the tape drive on that SCSI bus?
2) do you have physical termination resistor packs on the controller card,
or is SCSI termination handled by jumpers or software?
3) are you confident that you have good cables?

From rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Mon Mar  3 10:34:02 2003
From: rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Mon Mar  3 10:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Vulnerability
Message-ID: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A018C5274@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>

Subject: [VulnWatch] ISS Security Brief: Remote Sendmail Header Processing
Vulnerability

- -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Internet Security Systems Security Brief
March 3, 2002

Remote Sendmail Header Processing Vulnerability

Synopsis:

ISS X-Force has discovered a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Sendmail
Mail Transfer Agent (MTA). Sendmail is the most common MTA and has been
documented to handle between 50% and 75% of all Internet email traffic.

Impact:

Attackers may remotely exploit this vulnerability to gain "root" or
superuser
control of any vulnerable Sendmail server. Sendmail and all other email
servers are typically exposed to the Internet in order to send and receive
Internet email. Vulnerable Sendmail servers will not be protected by legacy
security devices such as firewalls and/or packet filters. This vulnerability
is especially dangerous because the exploit can be delivered within an email
message and the attacker doesn't need any specific knowledge of the target
to
launch a successful attack. 

Affected Versions:

Sendmail versions from 5.79 to 8.12.7 are vulnerable

Note: The affected versions of Sendmail commercial, Sendmail open source
running on all platforms are known to be vulnerable.

For the complete ISS X-Force Security Advisory, please visit: 
http://www.iss.net/issEn/delivery/xforce/alertdetail.jsp?oid=21950

______

Founded in 1994, Internet Security Systems (ISS) (Nasdaq: ISSX) is a
pioneer and world leader in software and services that protect critical
online resources from an ever-changing spectrum of threats and misuse.
Internet Security Systems is headquartered in Atlanta, GA, with
additional operations throughout the Americas, Asia, Australia, Europe
and the Middle East.

worldwide.

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Mar  3 11:47:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Mar  3 11:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Vulnerability
In-Reply-To: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A018C5274@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>
References: 
	 <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A018C5274@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>
Message-ID: <1046720784.1896.340.camel@red>

An increasing number of my customers are no longer
using sendmail. It seems that Postfix has become the
new standard for email on *nix. It's included with
many Linux distributions though not necessarily
installed by default as it is on, say, UnitedLinux.

I'm co-authoring a book on Email right now that makes
the assumption that Postfix is the standard, though
it does mention that Exim and qmail are also fine
servers. Sendmail is covered minimally - as one would
cover a legacy product. I'm doing the server-side
portion of the book and my co-author is doing the
client-side. Our tech reviewer is the author of a
well-known mail client.

I'd be pleased to hear what you think are the most
confusing email concepts or issues, so I can be sure
I'm doing justice to the subject in the book.

Ed

Message-ID: <200303031300.18806.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Monday 03 March 2003 11:46 am, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I'd be pleased to hear what you think are the most
> confusing email concepts or issues, so I can be sure
> I'm doing justice to the subject in the book.
>
> Ed

One common point of confusion is all the MTAs use a component named 
'sendmail', which of course gets confused with Sendmail. I've heard this is 
because some programs are hardcoded to look for sendmail, instead of $MTA. 

A common point of confusion with Postfix is what's the difference between 
'postfix reload' and 'postfix restart.' Yeah, everybody knows about how the 
first re-reads only main.cf, not master.cf, but what does it mean to the 
admin? And I thought I heard rumblings that this was going to change anyway.

With all the little specialized utilities like fetchmail, procmail, Cyrus, 
spam filters, etc it's confusing which of these are really needed.

OK, you wanted some 0.02, there's 0.06.

cheers,
Carla

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Mar  3 13:50:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Mar  3 13:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Vulnerability
In-Reply-To: <1046720784.1896.340.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303031344190.29824-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 3 Mar 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I'd be pleased to hear what you think are the most confusing email
> concepts or issues, so I can be sure I'm doing justice to the subject in
> the book.
 
Ed,

  When I first started using linux, about 5 years ago, it took me quite a
while to understand that e-mail requires 1 from column A, one from column B,
one from column C and (perhaps) one from column D. Once I understood that
the rest was easy.

  There are four separate, but integrated components of a mail system. For
systems not running a local server one needs fetchmail. Then, everyone needs a
MTA to handle incoming and outgoing mail. After this comes the MDA (most of
us use procmail) and, finally, the MUA of which there are a gazillion
choices (text and graphical).

  Understanding the flow of both incoming and outgoing messages does not
come from reading man pages or looking at a list of application choices.
It's necessary to understand the big picture so the appropriate choices can
be made for each component.

Rich

> the rest was easy.

>   There are four separate, but integrated components of a mail system. For
> systems not running a local server one needs fetchmail. Then, everyone needs a
> MTA to handle incoming and outgoing mail. After this comes the MDA (most of
> us use procmail) and, finally, the MUA of which there are a gazillion
> choices (text and graphical).
>

On Mon, 2003-03-03 at 13:00, Carla Schroder wrote:

> One common point of confusion is all the MTAs use a component named 
> 'sendmail', which of course gets confused with Sendmail. I've heard this is 
> because some programs are hardcoded to look for sendmail, instead of $MTA. 

Since Postfix, Exim, qmail, and others are Sendmail replacements,
these alternative mail programs must masquerade as Sendmail to
satisfy legacy applications or users. 

> A common point of confusion with Postfix is what's the difference between 
> 'postfix reload' and 'postfix restart.' Yeah, everybody knows about how the 
> first re-reads only main.cf, not master.cf, but what does it mean to the 
> admin? And I thought I heard rumblings that this was going to change anyway.

"postfix reload" is supported by the postfix program and,
as you say, is used after changes to main.cf occur.

The postfix program does not support a "postfix restart"
command as far as I can tell. Instead it uses "postfix
start" and "postfix stop". However, the startup script in
/etc/init.d (or /etc/rc.d/init.d) has a restart command,
which is probably a "postscript stop" followed by a
"postscript start". I dunno. I don't have Postfix running
on a box with a System V-style startup at the moment.


> OK, you wanted some 0.02, there's 0.06.

Thanks. I'll give you your 0.04 change when I see you next.

> cheers,
> Carla

Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Mar  3 14:31:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Mon Mar  3 14:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Vulnerability
In-Reply-To: <20030303222132.GA516@nellump.net>
References: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A018C5274@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>
	<mailman.1046720823.18988.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<86heakw68s.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
	<mailman.1046724122.22658.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<86u1ekunce.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> <20030303222132.GA516@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <86llzwulqh.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Mullen <pem at nellump.net> writes:

Paul> On Mon, Mar 03, 2003 at 01:55:29PM -0800, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
>> 
>> And OpenBSD instead of Linux.  Very Important.

Paul> Would you care to elaborate? I'd hate to see someone cry "troll!" :-)

Not a troll.  After looking carefully and consulting with others,
I'm running openbsd on stonehenge.com because I want to sleep at night.

Linux has a large installed base.  This makes it a prime target for
scriptkiddy hackers, because an exploit will work on so many more
computers.  OpenBSD has a much smaller installed base, making it a
lower target.

OpenBSD also has an intense focus on source-level peer review of every
line of core installed code.  Linux can't afford that level of review,
because it has to appeal to a broader audience with more features
sooner, and more developers contributing.  In essence, its success
strangles it.

In the four years since OpenBSD's initial release, there's been only
*one* remote root exploit, and that was in OpenSSL code that was
incorporated wholesale into OpenBSD, and also affected Linux and other
Unix distros.

The track record matches the announced intentions.  OpenBSD is about
security, and that gives me peace of mind.

Please note that this is OpenBSD specifically, and not FreeBSD or
NetBSD.  I make no claims for the other families.

--

<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>

OK, call me old fashioned. I use sendmail. It does what I need doing 
and, this week's notice aside, hasn't had many security problems of 
late.

Plus:

* libmilter is downright cool, and works very quickly with virus 
  scanners and SpamAssassin

* you can do stuff like "allow unencrypted, unathenticated SMTP from 
  network A, but require 128-bit, authenticated connections from 
  anywhere else"

All of which is not to say Postfix, Qmail, Exim, and others aren't 
cool too. It's just that some of us aren't terribly dissatisifed with 
sendmail.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Mar  3 21:16:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon Mar  3 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] An Employment Idea
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303032041000.29500-100000@joan.burling.com>

I wouldn't call the following a lead, but for the members
of the unemployed SIG (of which I managed to leave), I
had an interesting talk with a fellow tonight about
a possible job.

The long & the short of it was this: he works for a
local divison of Ricoh (the folks who sell copiers) as a
network engineer/technician/guy who gets paid to make stuff work.
He told me that his group is finding things slow because
they lack a salesman who knows how to sell network
consulting; they have all the copier salesmen that they
need, but none of them knows how to sell Netware, Linux
or Windows consulting. (And he is interested in getting
more Linux work for his group.)

As he explained, his management has basically given up
looking to fill this position, & are waiting for the
right person to come in & sell him/herself to them.
Which -- to me -- suggests that this is a job that is
out there, but not actually advertised. And can be landed
with a little bit of work by the right person.

Obviously, this will require more than sending a resume
& a follow-up call. And obviously, not everyone on this
list is a salesman. But I suspect that there is someone
out there who knows someone who wouldn't mind selling a
solid product (e.g., Linux networking) for a change from
the usual garbage that so many consulting groups want to
offer (e.g., that other ``Operating System").

If you are interested, & need a bit more help in researching
this position, contact me off-list. I have no input beyond
perhaps being a reference for this job, so don't send me
any resumes. Or sales specials on Symantec Antivirus software.

Geoff

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Mar  4 09:34:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Mar  4 09:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fonts
In-Reply-To: <20030304083800.98151.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303040930280.5548-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:

> When I click on "Preferences" in the GNOME menu, and then "Font,"
> there is a drop-down menu listing fonts. Where are these fonts
> actually located? I might want to add to the list.

There are a couple likely locations:

* /usr/share/fonts/default
* /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts

For a more complete take, try 'locate .ttf' or 'locate .afm' on your 
system.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Mar  4 10:07:05 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue Mar  4 10:07:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Vulnerability
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303031438160.32742-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303040944520.11398-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:

>
> OK, call me old fashioned. I use sendmail. It does what I need doing
> and, this week's notice aside, hasn't had many security problems of
> late.
>

I'm still a fan of sendmail myself.

I have used qmail, postfix, exim, smail, and ...  Some of these are
pretty nice.  They are often easier to use than sendmail and seem
more secure.  Most of them also run faster.

However, sendmail is fast enough for 99% of all mail servers, and
sendmail has been hacked enough that it is fairly secure - altho
one gets an uneasy feeling because it is not security be design.
Finally, sendmail is flexible.  It isn't particularly easy to use,
but it will do almost anything and that is kind of nice.

Several distributions moved to postfix or something else as the
default MTA and then moved back.  I can understand this.  I seem
to move away from sendmail and then I run into a problem and end
of moving back.  I know I installed a couple mail servers for a
client a while back and for some reason we decided to install one
as sendmail and the other as postfix.  By the time I finished
setting up the postfix machine, I was very glad I used sendmail
on the primary machine.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Mar  4 10:32:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue Mar  4 10:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mac Linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303040842220.11398-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <3E62B799.9D1FD02A@linkport.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303040842220.11398-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <20030304183153.GB17088@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Two misconceptions I see a lot about linux on apple hardware is that
you have to use MK Linux, and/or you must have MacOS installed and
boot linux from within that. Both of these are false in the general
case. MK Linux is basically dead, afaik, but it does work on older
hardware where more recent distributions/kernels wont (I believe you
must use the MK Kernel for non-new world macs). If you have
openfirmware on your mac (all new-world macs do), then you can use
that to start yaboot which is analagous to lilo / grub.

If you do have a macOS partition, you can use MOL (Mac-On-Linux) to
run MacOS within linux.. somewhat like vmware, iirc, but I've never
done it.. another interesting project is Basilisk II, a full mac
emulator that runs in x86. (I may have the name a bit off, going from
memory).

As far as I know, debian, Yellow Dog, Black Lab, and MK Linux are
available for various blends of Apple hardware.

I'm running debian on an old Imac (a 266 G3, with 128). It does quite
well, there is some weirdness with the nic disconnecting at random
times (requires a networking restart to fix it) but that is probably
just my hardware. I previously ran Yellow Dog Linux on it, and didn't
have that problem.

On the whole I've been pretty happy with it (a cron'd perl script
hides the network error reasonably well).

-Rogan

When I had a Blue-and-White G3 with the new world PROM, I used Mandrake PPC
and Yellow Dog at different times.  Both booted from yaboot, though I had to
hunt to find the right settings to pass to the boot PROM to select the right
partition (it's in the Mandrake setup guide, I later discovered).  But it
dual-booted Linux and OS9 just fine.

I've got the Mandrake CDs laying around which someone is welcome to take off
my hands, as I traded my Mac for an O2 a while back...

- Geoff

Gentoo does Mac PPC too.  I put it on a lot of old world g3 machines. 
It requires the Mac os be installed mimimally to boot Linux from using 
bootx.

The newer macs do not require Mac Os to be installed as stated below.

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue Mar  4 13:16:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Tue Mar  4 13:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] March PDX.rb Meeting
Message-ID: <1046765283.5202.41.camel@traveller.home.com>

Rubyists (and those curious about Ruby):

We'll be having our monthly meeting this coming Monday March 10th at
7PM. This time we'll meet on the East side at:

The Lucky Lab At SE Hawthorne and 10th (north side of the street).

This month we'll have a presentation by Lennon Day-Reynolds on his yet
unamed database binding library discussed in a recent post to ruby-talk.
>From his post:

  I have a simple binding library which lets you do something like the
  following:

  class Foo
     attr_reader :bar, baz
     attr_writer :bar, :baz
  end
  Persist::bind(Foo, 'foo_table', :bar, :baz)
  f = Foo.fetch('pkey_value')
  f.bar = 3
  f.store
  Foo.select('where bar > ?', 2) {|foo_obj|
     p foo_obj
  }

 It handles about 80% of the database queries I use in a moderately
 complex (~20kloc)
 business application, with the remaining bits done in basic DBI calls.

 I've also been experimenting with a thread-safe LRU cache for objects, 
 so that at least multiple concurrent reads of a database-bound data
 object don't have to make a full round trip to the database for each
 instance.

 Right now, it's not really package as a standalone library, but I'd be
 happy to go back over the code, clean it up, and either post it here 
 or on RAA for others to try out.
 
 


Phil
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
To find out more about Ruby, check out:
http://www.ruby-lang.org
To subscribe to the PDX.rb mailing list, send an email to:
pdxruby-subscribe at kohalabs.com 






From seanpdixon at yahoo.com  Tue Mar  4 13:25:02 2003
From: seanpdixon at yahoo.com (Sean)

Subject: [PLUG] trouble with GNOME
Message-ID: <3E651956.2060600@yahoo.com>

I finally made the switch to Linux.  It has been a lot of fun and a lot 
of frustration as I struggle to learn the idiosyncrocies of this OS.

One problem I have had are critical errors on my user accounts.  After 
struggling to fix them, I decided to simply delete them from the GUI. 
 When I added the new account with the same name I had the same problems 
- mozilla launching and then crashing was one issue.  I finally just 
renamed the user directories with a .old and created new account through 
xterm.

Although Mozilla works, now my evolution mail client will not launch.

I believe many of the problems I am having are a result of an initial 
issue I have at start-up.  The following is the error message I get when 
I login:

Could not look up internet address for <local computer>.
This will prevent GNOME from operating correctly.
It may be possible to correct the problem by adding
<local computer> to the file /etc/hosts

Any suggestions on what is going on and what I need to do to fix it?

I am running Redhat 8




From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Tue Mar  4 13:30:02 2003
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: Tue Mar  4 13:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] trouble with GNOME
In-Reply-To: <3E651956.2060600@yahoo.com>
References: <3E651956.2060600@yahoo.com>

Make sure your hostname is in your /etc/hosts file, pointing to
127.0.0.1

This should fix any issues with the start up problem, you should then be
able to put back all your evolution stuff, and hopefully that will fix
evolution (which is kinda finiky).

Chris Emery

From pem at nellump.net  Tue Mar  4 14:07:02 2003

On Tue, Mar 04, 2003 at 08:46:24AM -0800, David Mandel wrote:
> 
> Would some of you respond.  I know Linux runs on Macs, but I'm not
> sure what distributions are available or should be recommended.

Several distributions have PPC versions: Debian and Gentoo come to mind,
and there's Yellow Dog Linux, a Red Hat derivative. The Yellow Dog
company has figured out much of the configuration stuff for its
customers, but sadly the distro is RPM-based. I think SuSE also has a
PPC version.

> Actually, I'm interested in the answer.
> I have an old Mac laying around that I always thought I would put
> Linux on at some point.

It depends on what vintage the Mac is. Non-PCI based Macs (NuBus,
namely) are, IIRC, without many options. There was MkLinux several years
ago (Mach micro-kernel based) that ran on the older machines, but it had
pretty much stagnated the last time I checked. There are BSD options for
the old 68k Macs, naturally.

> > I'm running a 5oomhz iMac with 384 mb of RAM. I'm wondering if there is
> > a version of k12 linux for mac (hopefully with a windows emulator) that

I don't know much of anything about the K12 stuff (is the author
referring to the LTSP project?), so I can't comment here. The iMac
mentioned is certainly new enough to be able to run any of the
aforementioned PPC distros.

> > is available on  a CD.

Yellow Dog probably. It sounds as if the author wouldn't be a good
candidate for Debian, and certainly not Gentoo. :-)


Paul

From robbert at vafam.com  Tue Mar  4 18:20:02 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Tue Mar  4 18:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] trouble with GNOME
In-Reply-To: <3E651956.2060600@yahoo.com>
References: <3E651956.2060600@yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1046830759.1166.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've had the same trouble when I first switched to linux.  There are
actually two files you will want to check.

This is the entry on the computer name from my Linux Cheat Sheet:


Changing the Computer name

     1. Log in as root.
     2. Edit /etc/hosts to read as the following
        127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost {desired computer
        name}
     3. Edit /etc/sysconfig/network to read as the following
        NETWORKING=yes
        HOSTNAME={desired computer name} (same as #2)
        
Replace {desired computer name} with what you want to call the server. 
I call mine Robbert (okay, so I'm vain, big deal :) ).  So my /etc/hosts
file looks like this
127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost robbert

And my /etc/sysconfig/network file looks like this
NETWORKING=yes
HOSTNAME=robbert

Hope this helps.

Robbert

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Mar  4 20:59:02 2003

I suspect the problem is more to do with file names with single quotes that
you're parsing than with underscores. You shouldn't need all those pipes or
xargs...

[bigfish at kippered findtest]$ ls -R
.:
a  b  c  DS_store  findtest2

./findtest2:
1  2  3  DS_store  findtest3a  findtest3b

./findtest2/findtest3a:
herring

./findtest2/findtest3b:
DS_store
[bigfish at kippered findtest]$ find . -name DS_store -exec rm {} \;
[bigfish at kippered findtest]$ ls -R
.:
a  b  c  findtest2

./findtest2:
1  2  3  findtest3a  findtest3b

./findtest2/findtest3a:
herring

./findtest2/findtest3b:
[bigfish at kippered findtest]$

Sandy

Subject: [PLUG] find | grep | xargs ...
In-Reply-To: <20030304205857.A6754@kippered.herring.org>

On Tue, Mar 04, 2003 at 08:58:57PM -0800, Sandy Herring wrote:
> you're parsing than with underscores. You shouldn't need all those pipes or
> xargs...
> [bigfish at kippered findtest]$ find . -name DS_store -exec rm {} \;


xargs is faster for large numbers of files, the above command spawns a
new rm process for each file found, while xargs only calls rm once.

From seanpdixon at yahoo.com  Tue Mar  4 23:08:02 2003

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Robbert van Andel
Sent: Tuesday, March 04, 2003 6:19 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] trouble with GNOME


I've had the same trouble when I first switched to linux.  There are
actually two files you will want to check.

This is the entry on the computer name from my Linux Cheat Sheet:


Changing the Computer name

     1. Log in as root.
     2. Edit /etc/hosts to read as the following
        127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost {desired computer
        name}
     3. Edit /etc/sysconfig/network to read as the following
        NETWORKING=yes
        HOSTNAME={desired computer name} (same as #2)
        
Replace {desired computer name} with what you want to call the server. 
I call mine Robbert (okay, so I'm vain, big deal :) ).  So my /etc/hosts
file looks like this 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost robbert

And my /etc/sysconfig/network file looks like this NETWORKING=yes
HOSTNAME=robbert

Hope this helps.

Robbert

        route add default gw 192.168.0.254

(use the IP address of the IPCop firewall instead of 192.168.0.254)

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Mar  5 08:16:01 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Wed Mar  5 08:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] find | grep | xargs ...
References: <mailman.1046838724.5071.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86adg9rdyk.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt Whiteley <matt-whiteley at attbi.com> writes:

Matt> I am trying to recursively delete all files with the name "DS_Store" in
Matt> a certain directory path.  I had come up with the command 'find . | grep
Matt> DS_Store | xargs rm -v' however I get the error "unmatched single
Matt> quote"  From my testing it appears to be because of the underscore
Matt> character not parsing through xargs properly.  Is there a better way to
Matt> get what I want done?  In perl maybe?

find2perl . -name DS_Store -eval unlink -ls| perl

The -ls is just for a trace.  Leave it out to do it silent.
You can save the output of find2perl to reuse repeatedly.

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Wed Mar  5 13:31:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed Mar  5 13:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 8.1 and VMWare
In-Reply-To: <34909.159.121.9.50.1046718318.squirrel@webmail.pacifier.com>
References: <34909.159.121.9.50.1046718318.squirrel@webmail.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <E18qgSl-00059Q-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

This works without to much issue if you have less than 960Mb RAM. SuSE includes
large memory kernels that will be install on systems with more than 1G Ram.
These kernels cause vmware to seg fault. Setting the memory to 960Mb at the
boot prompt will stop this but disable memory above 960. 

Thank you
Russell

Subject: [PLUG] Route Howto

On Wed, 2003-03-05 at 14:19, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-03-05 at 07:48, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> > How do I do this permanently?
> > 
> > To add a default route temporarily run:
> >         route add default gw 192.168.0.254
> > 
> > (use the IP address of the IPCop firewall instead of 192.168.0.254)
> > Thanks, Dirk
> 
> Add that line to your startup scripts...

Seems like this should be done by the network configuration.

Either as a static entry with the IP address, or from the DHCP server.

If the address space of the network changes, and it has a default route
loading independant of the network configuration, the machine could get
very confused.

Just trying to save headaches later.

Derek Loree

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Mar  5 19:34:02 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed Mar  5 19:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Route Howto
References: <1046879285.1401.136.camel@localhost.localdomain> <1046902796.9974.34.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <3E66C0EE.2070707@easystreet.com>

AthlonRob wrote:

>On Wed, 2003-03-05 at 07:48, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
>
>>How do I do this permanently?
>>
>>To add a default route temporarily run:
>>        route add default gw 192.168.0.254
>>
>>(use the IP address of the IPCop firewall instead of 192.168.0.254)
>>Thanks, Dirk
>>
>Add that line to your startup scripts...
>
>Rob
>
For RedHat users ... (other distro's may vary)...

The default route is set at boot time in /etc/sysconfig/network
by the GATEWAY variable, so for the above IP address you would
want a line that reads
   
   GATEWAY=192.168.0.254

Additional static routes (for RedHat 7.1 and later ...) are
handled by /etc/sysconfig/static-routes.  It's a bit more complex,
but if you want a route to 172.16.0.0 (for example), through gateway
192.168.0.250 to be inserted into your route table, then the magic
line is

   any   net 172.16.0.0 netmask 255.255.0.0  gw 192.168.0.250  metric 1

"any" --> adds the route for any interface that's up (apparently you can
          specify routes which are added only when a particular interface
          is brought up -- makes sense for dial-up situations).

The rest of the line is preprended with "route add -" and then
executed.


- Don




From dgc at easystreet.com  Wed Mar  5 19:58:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Wed Mar  5 19:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] firewire disks
In-Reply-To: <3E66BEC1.8060108@easystreet.com>
References: <3E66A64B.3070305@easystreet.com>
	 <1046915063.9974.36.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <3E66BEC1.8060108@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <1046923029.2604.8.camel@merrivale.dhs.org>

Is this a system that wants or needs acpi and/or apci support?

I've been playing with one of the Shuttle cube systems (sk41g) and the
gentoo distribution.  Depending on exactly what kernel patches you use,
there can be problems.  The consensus on the gentoo forums seems to be
problems getting interrupts set up right, related to how well acpi
and apci is working.

Reported symptoms include 
	no usb devices working
	no firewire devices working
	realtek 8139 ethernet chips not responding
I've seen most of those while playing around.  Of the gentoo kernels
I've tried so far, gentoo-sources-2.4.19 works the best.  
Unfortunately it predates official linux support for the via vt8235
southbridge so ide drives have problems with dma.  But everything 
else works, including fireware (disks at /dev/sda and /dev/sdb).

On other motherboards people have reported success turning acpi
and/or apci on or off in the bios.

dgc

> Subject: Re: [PLUG] trouble with GNOME
> 
> 
> I've had the same trouble when I first switched to linux.  There are
> actually two files you will want to check.
> 
> This is the entry on the computer name from my Linux Cheat Sheet:
> 
> 
> Changing the Computer name
> 
>      1. Log in as root.
>      2. Edit /etc/hosts to read as the following
>         127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost {desired computer
>         name}
>      3. Edit /etc/sysconfig/network to read as the following
>         NETWORKING=yes
>         HOSTNAME={desired computer name} (same as #2)
>         
> Replace {desired computer name} with what you want to call the server. 
> I call mine Robbert (okay, so I'm vain, big deal :) ).  So my /etc/hosts
> file looks like this 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost robbert
> 
> And my /etc/sysconfig/network file looks like this NETWORKING=yes
> HOSTNAME=robbert
> 
> Hope this helps.
> 
> Robbert
>         
> On Tue, 2003-03-04 at 13:23, Sean wrote:

                        Aspire to Crudeness -- Issue 35

  March 6, 2003

  by Don Marti, Editor in Chief of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                       This Week's Sponsor: NetSonic

                 NetSonic Dedicated Servers and Colocation

   Since 1996, NetSonic has been a leader in providing robust dedicated
   servers and server colocation services. Dedicated server pricing from
   $89.99/mo, set up for you the same day you order. Red Hat 7.3, 8.0 and
   FreeBSD. See our web site:
   http://www.netsonic.net/lj/ for complete details.
     _________________________________________________________________

   Follow the Patents, People

   Quite a buzz formed on the Linux news sites over The SCO Group's:
   http://ir.sco.com/ReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=99965 announcement that
   "it has created a new business division to manage the licensing of its
   UNIX intellectual property. The new division, called SCOsource, will
   manage the substantial UNIX intellectual property assets owned by SCO,
   and will operate an array of licensing programs."

   Some people have speculated this announcement is SCO's attempt to use
   software patents to extract royalties from Linux vendors. But when
   somebody starts blustering about "intellectual property" and doesn't
   cite a patent number, I wonder.

   Why hasn't anyone done some homework here? I went down to the
   Sunnyvale, California public library to do a search on the US Patent
   Office's CASSIS2 system. Here are some key dates:

     * November 1995: Unix System Laboratories Inc. assigns three patents
       to Novell: 5,652,854, 5,265,250 and 6,097,384. Apparently, Novell
       made sure to keep UNIX-related patents when selling the UNIX
       source code to the original SCO, whose full name was "Santa Cruz
       Operation Inc."
     * August 1998: Novell assigns the trademark "Unixware" to Santa Cruz
       Operation Inc., but assigns no patents. This is around the same
       time that Novell assigned the trademark "Unix" to the X/Open
       Company Ltd.
     * August 2000: Caldera announces intent to buy the SCO Server
       Software Division and the Professional Services Division from
       Santa Cruz Operation, Inc. Caldera held no patents at this time
       and still doesn't.
     * December 2001: Santa Cruz Operation Inc. changes its name to
       Tarantella Inc. Both of Santa Cruz Operation Inc.'s patents,
       6,104,392 and 6,362,836, stay with Tarantella.

   Novell has assigned away only seven patents since 1980, when the
   CASSIS2 records begin: two to Corel, one to Interlogis Inc. and three
   to Volera Inc. Caldera has never had a patent assigned to it.

   So, if SCO is interested in throwing the first stone in a licensing
   war, all they have to play with is copyright on UNIX source code. The
   only people who won't have to worry are GNU and Linux developers,
   distributors and users. The GNU Project has kept itself scrupulously
   clean of UNIX source code "taint" since the beginning, and Linux is a
   rewrite from scratch, not a direct descendant of UNIX, as is almost
   every other common OS. The threat to Linux from this SCOsource deal
   would have been patents, because a patent holder can sue someone who
   independently arrived at the same idea.

   This doesn't mean that software patents aren't still a potential
   problem for the whole industry, like rhyming word patents would be to
   poets. Are the large software patent holders simply waiting to file
   infringement suits until they can get Europe to go for US-style
   software patents?

   My main concern here is why didn't any of the news organizations that
   try to cover Linux do the patent search? In the time it takes to write
   some pointless speculation about nonexistent patents, someone could
   have done a search or gone to the library. Don't news organizations
   have researchers and editorial assistants any more? You don't even
   have to pay them; call them interns, give them bylines, and they'll
   work for free in exchange for learning how to cover the news.

   One more reason not to like the term "intellectual property":
   analogies between information and physical objects always break down.
   The weaker your analogy, the more evil you have to be to enforce it.

   More Editor Stuff

   What is the most common reason why I reject article ideas? Usually,
   it's because the article doesn't show the potential to make the reader
   capable of doing something after reading it that he or she couldn't
   have done before reading it.

   DMCA Update

   Rep. Zoe Lofgren has reintroduced her DMCA reform bill:
   http://www.house.gov/lofgren/news/2003/030304.htm. The Business
   Software Alliance promptly came out with a rant against it, which Rich
   Kulawiec helpfully translated:
   http://www.politechbot.com/p-04517.html from its original Corporate
   Newspeak:

     We stand shoulder-to-shoulder with the RIAA and the MPAA in our
     willingness to criminalize any behavior that threatens our obscene
     profits, or which penalizes us in any way for our complete failure
     to anticipate changing market conditions, new technology, or
     overwhelming dissatisfaction with the crap we're selling."

   Write to Congress, and point out the important, legitimate things you
   need to do that the DMCA prevents you from doing. We need DMCA reform;
   if we can't do that, at least maybe we can keep the forces of evil
   tied up fighting DMCA reform and not pushing for the really heinous
   stuff, such as mandatory Digital Rights Management on all hardware. Or
   all TV-capable hardware, which--thanks to Moore's law--is everything
   you buy next year.

   Eric Blossom of GNU Radio rocked everyone's socks at CodeCon, with a
   full software implementation of HDTV. It's not real-time yet, but one
   clock doubling at the same time as a round of code tweaking should
   take care of that. Check out GNU Radio:
   http://www.gnu.org/software/gnuradio/gnuradio.html, and maybe you'll
   want to put off that expensive radio hardware purchase. It already can
   do multiple FM signals in real time.

   Random Question

   Is the lack of out-of-the-box hardware support for Linux an advantage,
   long-term, because it makes more people understand more about Linux
   and hardware? You lose some potential end users at the cost of
   subjecting some people to the first stage of developer or sysadmin
   training.

   --
   Don Marti:
   mailto:dmarti at ssc.com




From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Mar  6 06:30:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Mar  6 06:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
In-Reply-To: <001201c2e374$34d4fbc0$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
References: <001201c2e374$34d4fbc0$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
Message-ID: <200303060811.40390.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

No reason to panic, Sean.  It just sounds like you accidentally modified the 
"Files" section of your XF86Config file so that the X server can't find your 
fonts.  Here is the corresponding section of XF86Config-4 from my system 
(Mandrake 8.2)

Section "Files"

    RgbPath     "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/rgb"
    FontPath   "unix/:-1"

EndSection

The FontPath variable contains possible locations for fonts.  In my case (and 
it sounds like this is your case too), the X server acquires fonts via a font 
server xfs.  The number "-1" in my case and "700" in your case refers to the 
port that the font server uses.  Since the default port for the font server 
is 7100, my guess is that you accidentally deleted the 1 to end up with 700.  
If you were not using a font server, this variable would contain a list of 
directories where the X server should look for fonts.

You can determine what port your font server is running on by looking at the 
command line used to start the font server.  A quick and dirty way to do this 
is to read it from the process table, which you can do using the command

ps wp `ps aux | grep xfs | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}'`

On my system, this shows that the font server was started with the command

xfs -port -1 -daemon -droppriv -user xfs

which indicates that the port that my font server is running on is -1.  If the 
command line does not contain the -port argument, then the font server is 
running on the default port of 7100.

For more information about the font server, look at the man page for xfs.  You 
could also look at the man page for XF86Config for more information about the 
configuration file.

Good luck,

Mark

P.S. Problems with the X server are not usually related to problems with a 
filesystem.  So, checking your filesystem wasn't really warranted.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Mar  6 09:39:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Oregon Open Source Bill Introduced
Message-ID: <1046972519.3023.71.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends,

A bill will be introduced to the House of Representatives requiring that
State Government in Oregon consider "using open source software when
acquiring new software." You may find a link to the bill on Oregon's
legislative web site here:

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/03reg/measures/hb2800.dir/hb2892.intro.html

You may also find a link to Rob "Roblimo" Miller's write-up here:

  http://newsforge.com/newsforge/03/03/06/018222.shtml?tid=4

The bill is in good hands, but we need your support! I will post a draft
letter in the next few days for delivery to your local representative
about the bill, and why it is important for both the people of Oregon
and it's economy. I would like each of you to just spend a few moments
to modify the letter as you deem necessary and send it to the House
Representative in your local district. I will provide a list of contacts
in your area.

This bill is _very_ important to helping with the budget shortfall in
Oregon and encouraging our State Government to ensure a fair and
competitive process when procuring IT products and services.

If you have any questions or would like to get involved, please do let
me know.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
http://www.mwvlug.org

> This is the entry on the computer name from my Linux Cheat Sheet:
> 
> 
> Changing the Computer name
> 
>      1. Log in as root.
>      2. Edit /etc/hosts to read as the following
>         127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost {desired computer
>         name}
>      3. Edit /etc/sysconfig/network to read as the following
>         NETWORKING=yes
>         HOSTNAME={desired computer name} (same as #2)
>         
> Replace {desired computer name} with what you want to call the server.
> I call mine Robbert (okay, so I'm vain, big deal :) ).  So my
/etc/hosts
> file looks like this 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost robbert
> 
> And my /etc/sysconfig/network file looks like this NETWORKING=yes 
> HOSTNAME=robbert
> 
> Hope this helps.
> 
> Robbert

In-Reply-To: <000c01c2e408$a657d300$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
Message-ID: <000e01c2e40a$67d603c0$7729e00c@w2c6z6>

This is the error message I get when I try to launch startx in user
account:

Error loading keymap /var/tmp/server-0.xkm
Couldn't load XKB keymap, falling back to pre-XKB keymap
Mkdtemp: private socket dir: No space left on device

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Sean Dixon
Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 9:49 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: RE: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx


Actually what I did is ran Xfree -configure and created a new XF86Config
file.  I replaced the old one with this new one and startx worked in
root.  HOWEVER, when I tried to launch startx in my user account it
returned an error.

When I looked at the new file, I noticed it was very different that the
original and missing a lot of data, but it had more font info.  I edited
the new file to include the missing data of the original and it wouldn't
boot stating the screen info couldn't be found.

I have returned to the new file and trying to figure out why startx
won't work in the user account.  

The info you provided is awesome and I am going to check it out.  I
don't really mind breaking this and fixing it again.  My intention is to
learn and this is the fastest way I know how.  At least in this case I
am not messing around on someone else's network.

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Mark Martin
Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 6:12 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx


No reason to panic, Sean.  It just sounds like you accidentally modified
the 
"Files" section of your XF86Config file so that the X server can't find
your 
fonts.  Here is the corresponding section of XF86Config-4 from my system

(Mandrake 8.2)

Section "Files"

    RgbPath     "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/rgb"
    FontPath   "unix/:-1"

EndSection

The FontPath variable contains possible locations for fonts.  In my case
(and 
it sounds like this is your case too), the X server acquires fonts via a
font 
server xfs.  The number "-1" in my case and "700" in your case refers to
the 
port that the font server uses.  Since the default port for the font
server 
is 7100, my guess is that you accidentally deleted the 1 to end up with
700.  
If you were not using a font server, this variable would contain a list
of 
directories where the X server should look for fonts.

You can determine what port your font server is running on by looking at
the 
command line used to start the font server.  A quick and dirty way to do
this 
is to read it from the process table, which you can do using the command

ps wp `ps aux | grep xfs | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}'`

On my system, this shows that the font server was started with the
command

xfs -port -1 -daemon -droppriv -user xfs

which indicates that the port that my font server is running on is -1.
If the 
command line does not contain the -port argument, then the font server
is 
running on the default port of 7100.

For more information about the font server, look at the man page for
xfs.  You 
could also look at the man page for XF86Config for more information
about the 
configuration file.

Good luck,

Mark

P.S. Problems with the X server are not usually related to problems with
a 
filesystem.  So, checking your filesystem wasn't really warranted.

On Wednesday 05 March 2003 18:06, Sean Dixon wrote:
> On a recent reboot my computer freaked out and refused to boot into
> xwindows.  I changed the inittab to login at console and tried to go 
> in trough startx and was greeted with a fatal error message.
>
> I was dinking around with the XF86config file trying to see if I could

> get my wheel mouse to work and think I might have screwed something
> up. I tried to run XFree86 from GUI but didn't see anything happen.
>
> Now I am unable to get to any GUI.
>
> What have I done?!
>
> I ran fsck /dev/hda1, but to no avail.
>
> The error messages that are returned on startx failure are:
>
> Fatal Server Error:
> Could not open default font 'fixed'
>
> Could not init font path element unix/:700, removing from list!
--

Mark A. Martin, Ph.D.

I

is 
> > to learn and this is the fastest way I know how.  At least in this 
> > case I am not messing around on someone else's network.
> > 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Mark Martin
> > Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 6:12 AM
> > To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > Subject: Re: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
> > 
> > 
> > No reason to panic, Sean.  It just sounds like you accidentally
> > modified the "Files" section of your XF86Config file so that the X 
> > server can't find your
> > fonts.  Here is the corresponding section of XF86Config-4 from my
> system
> > 
> > (Mandrake 8.2)
> > 
> > Section "Files"
> > 
> >     RgbPath     "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/rgb"
> >     FontPath   "unix/:-1"
> > 
> > EndSection
> > 
> > The FontPath variable contains possible locations for fonts.  In my
> > case (and it sounds like this is your case too), the X server
acquires
> 
> > fonts via a font
> > server xfs.  The number "-1" in my case and "700" in your case 
> > refers
> to
> > the
> > port that the font server uses.  Since the default port for the font
> > server 
> > is 7100, my guess is that you accidentally deleted the 1 to end up
> with
> > 700.
> > If you were not using a font server, this variable would contain a
> list
> > of
> > directories where the X server should look for fonts.
> > 
> > You can determine what port your font server is running on by 
> > looking
> > at the command line used to start the font server.  A quick and
dirty 
> > way to do this
> > is to read it from the process table, which you can do using the
> command
> > 
> > ps wp `ps aux | grep xfs | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}'`
> > 
> > On my system, this shows that the font server was started with the
> > command
> > 
> > xfs -port -1 -daemon -droppriv -user xfs
> > 
> > which indicates that the port that my font server is running on is 
> > -1.
> 
> > If the command line does not contain the -port argument, then the 
> > font
> 
> > server is
> > running on the default port of 7100.
> > 
> > For more information about the font server, look at the man page for
> > xfs.  You could also look at the man page for XF86Config for more 
> > information about the
> > configuration file.
> > 
> > Good luck,
> > 
> > Mark
> > 
> > P.S. Problems with the X server are not usually related to problems
> > with a filesystem.  So, checking your filesystem wasn't really 
> > warranted.
> > 
> > On Wednesday 05 March 2003 18:06, Sean Dixon wrote:
> > > On a recent reboot my computer freaked out and refused to boot 
> > > into
> > > xwindows.  I changed the inittab to login at console and tried to
go
> 
> > > in trough startx and was greeted with a fatal error message.
> > >
> > > I was dinking around with the XF86config file trying to see if I
> > > could
> > 
> > > get my wheel mouse to work and think I might have screwed 
> > > something
> > > up. I tried to run XFree86 from GUI but didn't see anything
happen.
> > >
> > > Now I am unable to get to any GUI.
> > >
> > > What have I done?!
> > >
> > > I ran fsck /dev/hda1, but to no avail.
> > >
> > > The error messages that are returned on startx failure are:
> > >
> > > Fatal Server Error:
> > > Could not open default font 'fixed'
> > >
> > > Could not init font path element unix/:700, removing from list!

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Mar  6 10:46:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Mar  6 10:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Add new NIC
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOEEFDNHAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOEEFDNHAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1046976545.3023.122.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

What kind of NIC is it, exactly? Many times the module for the NIC will
have a switch that indicates which card you wish for it to be.

If the NIC driver is built into the kernel, on the other hand, it may be
a simple matter as follows:

  ifconfig eth2 192.168.1.x netmask 255.255.255.0
  ifconfig eth2 up


-Cooper

From michael at ns1.robinson-west.com  Thu Mar  6 11:03:01 2003
From: michael at ns1.robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu Mar  6 11:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Add new NIC
In-Reply-To: <1046976545.3023.122.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOEEFDNHAA.mikel@quantecllc.com> <1046976545.3023.122.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
Message-ID: <20030306185851.21346.qmail@ns1.robinson-west.com>

On Thursday 06 March 2003 10:49 am, you wrote:
> What kind of NIC is it, exactly? Many times the module for the NIC will
> have a switch that indicates which card you wish for it to be.
>
> If the NIC driver is built into the kernel, on the other hand, it may be
> a simple matter as follows:
>
>   ifconfig eth2 192.168.1.x netmask 255.255.255.0
>   ifconfig eth2 up
>
>
> -Cooper
>
> On Thu, 2003-03-06 at 10:38, Michael Luevane wrote:
> > Hi, pluggers.
> >
> > I have a machine that I've added a NIC to, bringing the total to 3. I am
> > now scratching my head on how to tell Linux that there's another NIC to
> > configure/install. I already have one NIC card of that model installed
> > and working.
>

Well, if it's an ISA nic you need to add a lilo parameter for built in driver 
or try /etc/modules.conf for a modular driver.  If it's pci, most likely, you
should be able to do dmesg to find out if it detected.  On redhat there
are scripts under /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts where you should
find ifcfg-eth0.  You copy this file and modify it for your third net card.
I believe that ifconfig -a is another way to see if Linux knows about 
your third net card regardless of whether or not it is up.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Mike,

Send me the output of the following commands:

   dmesg
   lsmod

In the mean time, here's a hint from
/usr/src/linux/Documentation/modules.txt:

        alias eth0 3c509        # or whatever net adapter you have
        # you might need an "options" line for some net adapters:
        options 3c509 io=0x300 irq=10


-Cooper

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Mar  6 12:03:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Mar  6 12:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
In-Reply-To: <001601c2e415$2987d890$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
References: <001601c2e415$2987d890$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
Message-ID: <1046981157.3046.336.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Sean,

Here is a command that will (fairly) safely delete all files in your
/tmp directory that are older than 5 days old.

The operative here is "fairly." There is the potential for this command
to remove files in directories other than /tmp. There is every chance
this will happen if you type the command in incorrectly. PLEASE BE
CERTAIN YOU HAVE TYPED THIS COMMAND EXACTLY AS I HAVE TYPED IT:

  find /tmp -atime +5 -exec rm -rf {} \;

If you are squeemish and wish to manually "okay" each file before it is
removed from your system enter the following at the command prompt:

  find /tmp -atime +5 -exec ok {} \;

The above will ask you for verification to make sure you wish to delete
the files this command finds. Some distributions have an alias for 'rm'
to do this by default. In effect the first command may ask you for
verification if your distribution is set up this way.


-Cooper

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Mar  6 13:56:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Mar  6 13:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Oregon Open Source Bill Introduced
In-Reply-To: <20030306211544.GA579@glen.takilma.net>
References: <1046972519.3023.71.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com> 
	<20030306211544.GA579@glen.takilma.net>
Message-ID: <1046987926.3046.428.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

On Thu, 2003-03-06 at 13:15, collver1 at attbi.com wrote:
> 
> As much enthusiasm as I have for open source software, I wonder why it is a
> good thing to require the government to consider open source software.
> This bill seems a bit sleazy, but if there is there precedent, I could
> understand a "you must fight dirty to win" argument.

This legislation will require Open Source Software to be considered
right along with proprietary offerings for procuring IT client and
server software.

This legislation was introduced to help reduce costs associated with IT
spending. With the advent of Microsoft's subscription-based licencing
fees, this cost will reach millions for not only Windows but also of
Microsoft's Office products as well.

I sometimes find an apprehension to converting to Open Source software.
There is generally no argument that Open Source is more stable and
secure, and that support options are generally more than adequate.

I find two primary reasons for not wishing to migrate. The first is
simply the unwillingness to change. IT managers would rather keep their
jobs, thank you very much.

Even if it costs the taxpayers millions.

The second reason is a more insidious. I offer a brief rundown of what
often happens when IT managers who do consider the use of Open Source
Software in this simple, easy-to-follow, five step program:


  Step One: Large organization considers using Open Source for their IT
infrastructure

  Step Two: Large Organization receives mail or a "compliance visit"
from Microsoft.

  Step Three: Microsoft either threatens or actually performs an audit
through the BSA

  Step Four: The audit costs the company several hindered thousand
dollars

  Step Five: Linux/Unix administrators get their pink slips to cover the
cost of the audit and businesses write in the costs for next year's
budget as a loss.

Meanwhile, Senior citizens are taking their blood pressure on the steps
of the State Capitol building.

References are available upon request about the preceding process.

These steps for private enterprise, while underhanded, are fine--it's
business.

When we're talking about taxpayer money, though, it's different. We
Oregonians are facing a budget shortfall in the Billions--yes, that's
with a big 'B.'

I have heard the argument over and over again that Open Source does not
actually lower Total Cost of Ownership. This is simply not true. 

Ask Merrill Lynch, Reuters, Amazon.com, Sherman Williams, Winnebago, the
State of Florida, and on and on. Don't just take my word for it. Look at
their (except for Florida's) SEC filings.

One of the studies pointed out by the opponents of Open source is a
study performed last year by IDG. It was funded by Microsoft. It
basically said that over the past five years, Linux reduced TCO in some
areas but actually increased it in others.

Chief among the flaws in the study is that they did not amortize out the
_next_ five years including Microsoft's licencing 6. When you then take
into account the perpetual licencing costs of both the Operating System
and of the Suite (not to mention the cost of the OS when you buy the PC
or server in the first place), Linux starts to look real cheap. Real
fast.

Note also as one IDG director observed, "you have to remember that those
companies that sponsor these studies stack the deck in such a way that
you'd never see that kind of configuration in the real world."

I estimate that $10,000 p/1000 machines are spent on personnel keeping
track of software licences alone!

The bottom line is that our State government is shipping money by the
truckload to Washington State and Texas, and it is having a direct
effect on our ability to offer badly needed funds to citizens that could
really use it.

Finally, I think Oregon has a law prohibiting it's entities from doing
business with convicted felons...so what are we doing dealing with
Microsoft?


-Cooper

From michael at ns1.robinson-west.com  Thu Mar  6 15:39:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Network backups...
Message-ID: <20030306233459.22066.qmail@ns1.robinson-west.com>

Most backup references I find talk about dump, restore, 
tar, etc.  However, they seem to assume that your backup 
device is directly connected to the machine you want to 
back up.  For a multiple server/workstation environment 
this makes no sense whatsoever because of cost.  The 
option of moving a dump drive around in a bracket doesn't 
make much sense either as this movement wears out a 
hard drive and lowers the efficiency of backing up multiple 
machines.  As far as I can tell, a linux system cannot be 
completely backed up, everything, live.  There's runlevel 
one, however there is no network access in this mode. 
Without network access, there's no way to dump to a 
remote dump drive or directly to a remote tape :-o

To the end of being able to do a full backup of not only 
windows systems but also of Linux systems, I've managed 
to make a netbootable image of the most recent Tom's boot 
root disk.  Unfortunately, this Linux system doesn't have 
backup tools including rmt and is not capable of mounting a 
samba share to dump to.  The other problem with Tom's Root 
boot is root access without authentication to the machine it 
is booted on.  It doesn't seem to me that Tom's has that 
many network tools, don't know what what the maximum 
extent of Tom's capabilities are as far as network goes 
though.  If I can figure out how to make my own initrd 
system I'll make that netbootable :-)  Fortunately, the 
1.44 meg limitation on Tom's root boot doesn't exist for 
etherboot images which can expand to sixteen megs 
when they are loaded into ram.  Rumor has it that people 
have done 180 meg images, I'd use nfs myself before I'd 
load that much into ram unless I had a clever way to
detect that there's enough memory for an image of that
size.  I could use suggestions on what will help me 
learn how to build initrd linux systems that can be 
tagged for network booting.  I didn't modify Tom's, I 
just tagged it.  It would be nice to test initrd systems 
without having to reboot the developement machine
to try and netboot them.  

With etherboot is there a way for me to password 
Tom's Root boot or should I change the root 
password in the netbootable image itself?



Thoughts for an advanced network based backup system.
------------------------------------------

In an advanced setup you network boot into a boot/restore 
system, but you have to authenticate as yourself and the 
backup software available knows what backup, partitioning, 
and restore procedures are valid for you.   Whether or not 
a blank tape that you can claim or your own tape is loaded 
in the tape drive, whether the machine you are going into 
network backup from is open to your modifying it, and this 
net backup program limits the user's activity to the 
machine they boot it on.  

The Linux system is the obvious choice because it can mount 
just about any PC operating system's partitions, user 
seperation is available through standard accounts, the 
networking capability is there, and 
there are ample scripting options.  Ideally, an experience 
similar to menuconfig where you never get a normal 
console prompt makes the most sense.  I've had good luck
using dump and then tar and bzip2 to get the backups
onto my DI30 tapes.

The trick is figuring out which machine the network backup 
program is loading up on and applying that information to the 
authentication process.  While special methods of writing to 
tape are possible, this makes it more difficult to restore.  I 
think a non tamper resistant text file at the beginning of the 
tape that has the mac address of the machine backed up 
makes the most sense for a home environment.  To keep 
this simple, you would have one or more tapes per 
machine even if all your machines would fit on one tape.  
I guess I could write a text file to a new tape that indicates 
the user name of the person that can claim it and only allow 
the administrator to claim a tape that is truly blank.  The
mac address on the tape connects it to a machine where
authentication connects a machine to a person or standard
user.

For what I want in a backup system it keeps 
multiple peoples' backup jobs from exceeding the dump 
space, it implements first come first serve so that backup 
requests are served in the order they are recieved, and
backups are split over multiple tapes if they are too large
for one tape where backup size is calculated  before starting 
so that backup doesn't become unavailable for everyone 
while you rush to the store, or favorite web site, to order 
more media and find the administrator to check
it out to you.  I'm playing with the simplification of not 
allowing more than one backup job to be served at a time
because my dump space isn't two to three times my tape
space or better.

An advanced network backup environment is ready for
more efficient backup methods that use things such as
kickstart, etc.  I want ot get backed up what I have now
first before exploring the methods recommended
in many of the bare metal recovery howto's more 
closely.  Reinstalling can reduce backup size but
I'm worried about missing important changes, etc.

Netbooting involves dhcp giving host information based
on the mac address.  This is what I want to add to the
authentication information later when a person logs in
with some username and password and the system
has to decide if the person they logged in as is allowed
to modify the system they logged in from.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

It _is_ Oregon's problem, because we have to pay for it. We not only
with taxpayer money but also with _every_ good and service that we
consume as the costs to the manufacturer/service provider are passed to
the consumer.

> 
> You described two other problems: 1) IT managers wastefully focussing on
> job security, and 2) Microsoft bullying.  This bill obviously does not
> address problem 1, 

This bill is the first step toward promoting fair procurement processes.
In terms of problem one, history tells us that IT managers will often
choose what is easiest, even if they know a better solution exists. This
will force public sector IT employees to justify why they chose the
solution that they have. While it's true it does not directly address
problem number one, it does indirectly require them to think more about
the technology in terms of what is better and less expensive for their
employers/customers, and less about what is easiest for them.

but I see the relevance to problem 2.  If you force
> the Oregon state government to consider open source software at every IT
> decision, it makes it more difficult for Microsoft to single out individual
> organizations.  Is this the purpose of the bill?

I cannot speak to the intentions of the bill's author, but I can tell
you that it is definitely a potential benefit.

The state will now have the power to say, "hey, proprietary vendor,
that's the law!" By inference, if the proprietary vendor does not wish
to play ball nicely, then it is certainly justified for an IT manager to
write in his/her report, "we felt a very real threat from proprietary
vendor X that they intend to enforce strict licensing guidelines against
our software. Staying in compliance of these terms may be outside the
limits of our resources to track and pay for these licencing
requirements. We have no reason at this time to suspect that this
situation will change in the future."

> 
> AFAIK there is no bill requiring the Oregon government to consider
> proprietary software.  Granted this bill does not tell people how to
> perform their jobs, but it makes me uneasy to see Oregon law used to
> advertise open source software.  

I agree to a certain extent. What you may not know is that lobbyists
from Redmond are pouring _millions_ into the pockets of some
legislators' re-election funds across the country to help, "ensure that
software used by the public sector is of the highest technical and
functional standard." 

Do the math.

The boom times are over. Constituents in each district are taking a real
hard look at where the money is going. This is a good thing.

If Linux has such dramatic potential to
> reduce costs as you claim, it should "sell" based on its own merits.

History will tell you, young man, that it is simply not always the case.
The death of the Macintosh is an excellent example. On the business
side, I encourage you to look at the Anti-trust cases of Standard Oil
and Carnege Steel, Microsoft, and others.

This you may not know:

Bill Gates grew up in the upper-crust suburban Seattle in the 1960's.
His father, William Gates Jr., was one of Seattle's most prominent
lawyers and an active player in the political arena in Washington State.
Senators, congressmen, and governors came to dinner at the family's
house when Bill was a boy.

It was actually Bill's mother, Mary, who pointed a friendly IBM
executive to her son's fledgling software company, Microsoft.

Is William Gates III an intelligent and intense individual? Certainly.
Does he have a ferocious competitive appetite? Again, certainly.

Did he have a little help? I'd say that's a fair statement to say the
least.

I wish it really were a "may the best man win" business, but the truth
is that the technology sector is a rough, 'take-no-prisoners' arena
where you take every advantage that you can get. For some, even if said
advantage is illegal.

Michael,

Well, as you are probably aware of, many commercial backup solutions have
special add-ons for backing up live databases. If you don't go with one of
those then the best option is to script dumping the db to a file and then
that dump gets backed up to tape.

Look into AMANDA at www.amanda.org

It may fulfill many of your desires. It will back up linux boxes as well
as SMB shares. It also has the ability to separate the server software
from the tape drive. IOW, you can have the server run on box A, have the
tape drive (or changer) in box B, and back up C,D,..... Amanda has a very
active, helpful mailing list in which some of the developers pipe in now
and then.

Keith

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Mar  6 18:43:02 2003

	<86ptp46on6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Message-ID: <867kbbsxqt.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael Robinson <michael at ns1.robinson-west.com> writes:

Michael> [...] As far as I can tell, a linux system cannot be
Michael> completely backed up, everything, live.

Russell> I do all my backups live.

Michael> How?  

Essentially,

   mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
   mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf <n>
   tar -C <mount-point> -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
   mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf <n>
   tar -C <mount-point> -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0 

Salt to taste to pipe over ssh for remote backups.

Note: because files change between backup and compare, the compare is
going to generate some mismatch noise.  I generally glance at the
output for anything unexpected.

Michael> There are open files, fifos, and possibly changing files.

In some instance that might be important.  In my circumstances, it
hasn't proved to be.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Mar  6 19:10:03 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Mar  6 19:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emaill passwd and username recovery
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEMKCGAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303060954260.23664-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030306190730.00bb1fa0@192.168.0.2>

At 11:00 AM 3/7/2003 +0800, you wrote:
>how about recovering the username and passwd through the /etc/psswd file, is
>it possible....


The username, yes. The password, no. What's stored is a hash of the 
password. How it's compared is the user input to the password prompt is 
hashed, and the hashes are compared.

John the Ripper 
(http://freshmeat.net/projects/john/?topic_id=43%2C44%2C253%2C857%2C861) 
will crack many passwords, but it's going to take a long time on something 
thats completely random (i.e. a GOOD password).


Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Mar  6 21:44:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Mar  6 21:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303061156000.13898-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303061156000.13898-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047015810.4585.49.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2003-03-06 at 11:56, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 6 Mar 2003, Sean Dixon wrote:
> 
> > Can I rm all files in tmp without causing any problems?  There is all
> > sorts of crude in there.  One file called rhl-gsg-en-80.pfd is 4G alone
> 
>   NO! Some applications look for files there.
> 
>   But, you can delete all pdf, PDF, ~ and so on with impunity.

But you can safely empty it on reboot (as long as you yourself don't put
stuff there you expect to live past reboot).  I put this in my
/etc/fstab:

none                    /tmp                    tmpfs   defaults        0 0

Assuming you've got a reasonable amount of memory, this will make /tmp
work entirely out of memory, which (might) also speed (a few) things
up.  If you find big files getting stuff left there, you can find if
anything is actually using them with 'lsof' or 'fuser'.  (And if
something actually does have them open, the file blocks won't actually
be released until the file is closed.)

Wil

Subject: [PLUG] immediate shutdown problem
Message-ID: <20030307061221.GA20305@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Twice I've had my workstation poweroff un-commanded (the last two
times it was shutdown infact). Both times this has happened at the
same instant I've placed my visor in it's usb cradel. Has anyone
experienced this? AFAIK, I don't have any resident monitors on my
cradel, and I know I didn't inadvertently hit the hotsync button (nor
does this do anything yet, I haven't set that up, the cradel just acts
as a charging station.)

Cradeling the visor is something I do daily, and has never seemed to
cause a problem other than these two instances, about 2-3 weeks apart.

Both times the system was doing quite a lot, with a load average
arround 3 (I check this rather often), and high disk activity. This
leads me to think it may be powering off automatically due to heat
problems.. although it's a hell of a coincidence. Unfortunately I
don't have any thermal sensing software working.. 

Anyhow, the system specs are as follows (in detail to support the
overheating theory):

dual athlon mp 1600+'s
tyan tiger mpx mobo
512 ram
dvd, cdrw, cd (separate devices, all ide)
promise ata100 ide controller
3 dma 100 drives (and a slower one, that never sees activity)
G400 DH. video 
450 watt antex PS.
& 4 case fans.
 
Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.

-Rogan

tethereal is part of the ethereal source. You probably could do this with
tcpdump, but tethereal is my tool of choice. http://www.ethereal.com/

On the pop server run this for a few days / weeks ?

tethereal -l  dst port 110   | awk '/USER/ { print $0 ; getline ; print $0}' >
/tmp/pass_cap

Russell
