From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Mar  7 00:51:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri Mar  7 00:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emaill passwd and username recovery
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKENECGAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKENECGAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <200303070101.25600.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 07 March 2003 12:29 am, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> i would like to do this for username and passwd maintenance only.  users
> are complaining to me that i always give new paswwd whenever they ask for
> me for their forgotten passwd(which i think is not my fault).

Too bad for your users! No admin on any properly-managed modern system can 
recover a password, the only option is to reset it. Passwords should not be 
readable by human eyes. Though Russell pointed out how easy it is to capture 
and read network traffic. A little encryption goes a long way towards curing 
that. Some users are chronically whiny about passwords, the only things I 
know to do are to streamline the system so they don't need to track a bunch 
of passwords, and to be very stern on anything pertaining to security. No 
Post-its, no dictionary words, birthdays, or pet names; periodic password 
changes, no recycling the same three passwords, the usual basics.

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

That's an education issue. Explain to them that you do not keep a record of 
their password due to security and legal concerns. Also tell them that 
there is no way to "recover" a lost password, as that would make the 
security of their account questionable, at best. The only option is to 
issue a new password, if the old one is lost, and tell them that they are 
responsible for remembering their passwords.

Matt> That's what I was missing.  Thanks!

You also need

        somewhere.tld THIS_DOES_NOT_MATTER

in the map... from virtual(5):

       The virtual-alias.domain anything entry is required for  a
       virtual alias domain. Without this entry, mail is rejected
       with "relay access denied", or bounces  with  "mail  loops
       back to myself".

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Mar  7 09:50:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Mar  7 09:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Write Your Legislator
Message-ID: <1047059543.5120.111.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends,

What follows are instructions and a simple template for writing your
Representatives about the Open Source Consideration bill (HB 2892) that
is currently headed for committee in the House. You may find a link to
the bill here:

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/03reg/measures/hb2800.dir/hb2892.intro.html

It turns out that writing to your House or Senate Representative has
never been easier! Simply go the URL below, fill out your name and
address in the fields provided, and write what you wish to say in the
text box area of the page!

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/writelegsltr/writeset.htm

Your email will be automatically sent to the appropriate
representative(s) based on the address you provided! I have included a
template below. Really, though, write what you feel is important. For
goodness sakes, though, please write!


---------------------------Begin Letter---------------------------------

HB 2892

I am in support of HB 2892. This bill would require State agencies in
Oregon to consider Open Source Software when procuring Information
Technology goods and services. While I am not necessarily opposed to
proprietary software, Open Source software is truly a big win for Oregon
as it's legislators shop for alternatives.

This bill will help save the State of Oregon millions in IT licensing
costs and software expenditures. These funds could be used to improve
Oregon's IT infrastructure or diverted to other services that the
citizens of Oregon desperately need.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter. HB 2892 truly is an
important bill that would benefit the people of the State of Oregon.


Sincerely,



---------------------------End Letter----------------------------------


Guidelines for writing your representative:

  * Have the bill number prominantly displayed at the top of the letter
and in bold 

  * Have the words "I support" in bold in the first sentance of the
letter

  * Include your address with the letter so that your representative can
clearly see that you live in his/her district

  * Be honest. Say what you feel. Provide evidence in your own
experience how Open Source software has saved you or your company money,
increased reliability/security, whatever

Writing your representative shouldn't be a big deal, and it isn't.
Believe it or not they really do listen to what they're constituents are
thinking and feeling. 

Each House Representative has an individual file for each bill going
through the various stages as on it's way to law. Your letters go into
that file. 

Every morning, an assistant will look at the bills that are to be
brought before his or her canidate's committee or to the floor for a
vote. This person looks at your letters in that file and takes a tally
of the "yea's" and "nea's." This is why it is important to have the bill
number in bold at the top of the page and the words, "I support" in
bold. They then pass this information on to the representative so that
he/she can get a feel for how to vote on a particular issue.

So you see, your letters _really_ do count! Let's get this thing passed
into law!

Finally, for future reference I should note that if you wish to contact
nearly any Oregon official for any reason, you may conveniently do so
here:

  http://www.kxl.com/lars_feedback.asp

Lars Larson's site has a complete drop-down list of just about every
representative you can think of. It's easy to fire off an email to any
of these officials and tell them what you think.

If you have any questions or would like further information, please do
not hesitate to contact me directly.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Email: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www:   http://mwvlug.org

From matt-whiteley at attbi.com  Fri Mar  7 10:38:02 2003
From: matt-whiteley at attbi.com (Matt Whiteley)
Date: Fri Mar  7 10:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail --> Postfix
In-Reply-To: <20030306224642.94663.qmail@web21209.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030306224642.94663.qmail@web21209.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1047062411.6064.6.camel@galt.atlas.gotdns.org>

On Thu, 2003-03-06 at 14:46, Paul Lankow wrote:
> Since I can't figure out why Sendmail can't deliver local mail, it looks
> like it's time for me to drop Postfix in. Is there a document on the web
> designed to help migrate people over?
> 
> TIA,
> Paul
> 
> =====
> __________________________________
> Email: paul at lankow.net
> http://paul.lankow.net

Paul, this has been discussed on the psyche-list at redhat.com in detail. 
There are archives available from https://listman.redhat.com but I will
quote one message here that helped me fix the same problem.

Given a stock RH8 with the sendmail service turned on and the following 
> changes should allow local mail delivery as you describe.
> 
> If you are using tcpwrappers (/etc/hosts.{allow,deny}) hosts.allow must 
> contain a line like
> 
> ALL: 127.0.0.1
> 
> or
> 
> ALL: localhost.localdomain
> 
> in addition make sure /etc/mail/local-host-names contains
> 
> localhost
> localhost.domain
> myhost.mydomain.com
> ....
> 
> and finally make sure /etc/hosts contains
> 
> 127.0.0.1     localhost.localdomain  localhost
> 
> and not localhost.com
> 
> You can test using telnet to talk directly to the SMTP port 25 and 
> seeing where the "converstation"with sendmail breaks down.  The .... in 
> the following would, of course be replaced with a bunch of SMTP verbage 
> which should be reasonably helpful.
> 
> # telnet localhost 25
> 220 ....
> MAIL FROM: root at localhost
> .... OK
> RCPT TO: root at localhost
> .... OK
> DATA
> test
> 
> -- 
> Psyche-list mailing list
> Psyche-list at redhat.com
> https://listman.redhat.com/mailman/listinfo/psyche-list


-- 
Matt Whiteley <matt-whiteley at attbi.com>

From seanpdixon at yahoo.com  Fri Mar  7 10:41:09 2003
From: seanpdixon at yahoo.com (Sean Dixon)

Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
In-Reply-To: <1046981157.3046.336.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
Message-ID: <003701c2e4d8$f6897e70$7729e00c@w2c6z6>

The verification has been set by default.  How do I turn it off?

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Cooper Stevenson
Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 12:06 PM
To: PLUG Mailing List
Subject: RE: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx


Sean,

Here is a command that will (fairly) safely delete all files in your
/tmp directory that are older than 5 days old.

The operative here is "fairly." There is the potential for this command
to remove files in directories other than /tmp. There is every chance
this will happen if you type the command in incorrectly. PLEASE BE
CERTAIN YOU HAVE TYPED THIS COMMAND EXACTLY AS I HAVE TYPED IT:

  find /tmp -atime +5 -exec rm -rf {} \;

If you are squeemish and wish to manually "okay" each file before it is
removed from your system enter the following at the command prompt:

  find /tmp -atime +5 -exec ok {} \;

The above will ask you for verification to make sure you wish to delete
the files this command finds. Some distributions have an alias for 'rm'
to do this by default. In effect the first command may ask you for
verification if your distribution is set up this way.


-Cooper

Yep.  I'm running as root.  Bad Rob. Bad, bad, bad Rob.....

On Fri, 07 Mar 2003, Matt Whiteley wrote: 
> On Wed, 2003-03-05 at 08:10, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
[...]
> > find2perl . -name DS_Store -eval unlink -ls| perl
> > 
> > The -ls is just for a trace.  Leave it out to do it silent.
> > You can save the output of find2perl to reuse repeatedly.
> 
> Obviously my lack of perl knowledge is showing but I ran this command in
> a directory with files of the name 'DS_Store' and as far as I could tell
> nothing happened.  I took out the '-ls' and still could see no effect. 
> >From reading in the camel book it looked like it would work to me, is
> there something else I need to do?

Matt,

Note that the character after `ls' and before ` perl' is a pipe (vertical
bar), not the letter "l". `find2perl' generates a Perl script on stdout. You
can pipe it to perl, or redirect it to a file if you want to create the
script for future invocations. If you had the pipe correct, then the `find'
failed to find anything.

Sandy

From alan at clueserver.org  Fri Mar  7 12:27:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] rpm problem

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303070343470.28713-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

Look in /usr/lib/rpm for a bunch of temporary database files.  (They will 
end in .001 .002 and .003.)  Delete and/or rename them.  That should fix 
the problem.

It is a known bug, but never fixed in the mainline version of 8.0.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Mar  7 13:09:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri Mar  7 13:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail --> Postfix
In-Reply-To: <20030307205757.46707.qmail@web21209.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <1047062411.6064.6.camel@galt.atlas.gotdns.org>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030307130344.01c20000@localhost>

At 12:57 PM 3/7/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>It's very frustrating since Sendmail resolves
>localhost.lankow.net as my outside IP but a simple ping resolves it
>internally by virtue of my /etc/hosts entry.

As I recall, sendmail doesn't use the /etc/hosts file. It only resolves via 
DNS. I've run into this previously.

What I believe it's doing is looking up the MX record for lankow.net, since 
this would be the host it would be interested in. Since there is no MX 
record for localhost.lankow.net, it goes to lankow.net. If you want it to 
find your internal host, then you'll either need to define an internal 
network for it to find in DNS, or use localhost by itself, without the 
lankow.net after it.

I may be all wet here, but I believe that's the behavior I've encountered 
previously.


Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

Subject: testing
1, 2, 3

class=0, nrcpts=1, msgid=<200303072115.h27LFTcC024522 at prj.lankow.net>,
relay=root at localhost

When the email is submitted, the relay is root at localhost - this is
consistent with what log file fromthe earlier version of Sendamil would
show. When the email is delivered, the relay changes.

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Mar  7 14:23:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Mar  7 14:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
In-Reply-To: <003701c2e4d8$f6897e70$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
References: <003701c2e4d8$f6897e70$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
Message-ID: <1047075914.5121.299.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

As root, check out the following files:

  /etc/bashrc
  /root/.bashrc

Less likely you are using the Korne shell:

  /etc/kshrc
  /root/.kshrc

You should see something like:

  alias rm -rf='rm -rif'

Remove this alias and (possibly) re-login.

DISCLAIMER: Doing this may someday cause you grief. The Linux 'rm'
command, just like about everything else in Linux, will do _exactly_
what you tell it too. No "are you sure" dialog boxes, no "you are about
to do something silly" messages, just the absolute command.

'rm' will absolutely trash your system without even the common courtesy
of a ..err, you get the picture.

So if you're feeling manly--if you think you got what it takes, you just
remove those 'wimpy' lines from your *rc files, the sky's the limit!


-Cooper

> 
> Sean,
> 
> Here is a command that will (fairly) safely delete all files in your
> /tmp directory that are older than 5 days old.
> 
> The operative here is "fairly." There is the potential for this command
> to remove files in directories other than /tmp. There is every chance
> this will happen if you type the command in incorrectly. PLEASE BE
> CERTAIN YOU HAVE TYPED THIS COMMAND EXACTLY AS I HAVE TYPED IT:
> 
>   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec rm -rf {} \;
> 
> If you are squeemish and wish to manually "okay" each file before it is
> removed from your system enter the following at the command prompt:
> 
>   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec ok {} \;
> 
> The above will ask you for verification to make sure you wish to delete
> the files this command finds. Some distributions have an alias for 'rm'
> to do this by default. In effect the first command may ask you for
> verification if your distribution is set up this way.
> 
> 
> -Cooper

Oops, that should be:

$ cat > file2 <<EOF
1 1 1 57.6

Here's what I've come up with:

  $ awk '{ printf("$1 == %d && $2 == %d && $3 == %d { print $0 }\n",$1,$2,$3) }' file1 | awk -f - file2

Alice> grep -f file1 file2

Interesting, but not robust enough.  What happens if the key in file1
doesn't appear at the beginning of the line in file2?  E.g.:

7 1 2 3

in file2 would match the grep pattern "1 2 3" from file1, as would:

11 2 3 43

I could send file1 through some "armoring" filter, with a "^" and the
front and a delimiter at the end and pipe it like:

  $ <filter> file1 | grep -f - file2

And, here is what seems to be a suitable filter and command-line:

  $ sed 's/^\(.*\)[ ]*$/^\1($| )/' file1 | egrep -f - file2

I'll stipulate that I don't care about whitespace at the end of line
in file1, since it is mostly invisible and caring about it seems more
likely to cause confusion.  

In order to match lines that begin with my key and then either end or
have a delimiter followed by other data, I need (?) an optional, such
as ($| ) in egrep syntax.

Comments?

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Mar  7 16:46:01 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri Mar  7 16:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HTTP protocol Question
Message-ID: <2510.134.244.174.61.1047084255.squirrel@sautez.com>

Hello all,

I'm tracking down some info on how the HTTP protocol should work. Ok, it
is more then that but here is the jest of my question.  I'll try to
explain this so that you understand.

I have web server which on a link I have it process a request and then use
the Location: header to have the request sent to another server.  This
server then returns the process request to me.  Which in this case is a
file. A text file actually.

In this case both servers are running on the same host but different ports.

In the second server it tries to get the port number of the request so
that it may include that in the file I created.  I need that to process
the text file returned.  However, what I have found is that the server
running on the second port does not have access to the Port.  The first
server did not send it with the Location: header.  It appears to have not
included it in the protocol.  The Host header (when viewed in a tunnel is
just the host).

I have Apache as the first server and Tomcat as the second.  Tomcat uses
the HTTP request to get the port.  It can't find it on the request and
thus uses its port which is not the correct port I need.

Is this normal?  Is there a problem with Apache or Tomcat?  I think not as
I have a TCPMonitor java program that also appears to strip the port when
redirecting and HTTPClient libraries also do that.

Thanks for any help you can give.  I'm about to dive into the HTTP spec
but thought if there was a simple, Yes or No answer then I could spend my
evenings doing something other then falling asleep over the HTTP spec. ;-)

Josh



From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Fri Mar  7 17:44:01 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Fri Mar  7 17:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBDAB@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

Speaking of Holy Cows, you should be very careful with that large .pfd file.
Pfd (short for "pferd," the German word for "horse") files contain the
entire essence of a digitized horse (highly compressed, of course). Deleting
this file could cause your computer to lose some of its horse-power.

On the other hand, it could be a dead horse, in which case there's no great
profit to be made in killing or even beating it.

Just thought you might want to know....

-djp

On Fri, 2003-03-07 at 14:25, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> As root, check out the following files:
> 
>   /etc/bashrc
>   /root/.bashrc
> 
> Less likely you are using the Korne shell:
> 
>   /etc/kshrc
>   /root/.kshrc
> 
> You should see something like:
> 
>   alias rm -rf='rm -rif'
> 
> Remove this alias and (possibly) re-login.
> 
> DISCLAIMER: Doing this may someday cause you grief. The Linux 'rm'
> command, just like about everything else in Linux, will do _exactly_
> what you tell it too. No "are you sure" dialog boxes, no "you are about
> to do something silly" messages, just the absolute command.
> 
> 'rm' will absolutely trash your system without even the common courtesy
> of a ..err, you get the picture.
> 
> So if you're feeling manly--if you think you got what it takes, you just
> remove those 'wimpy' lines from your *rc files, the sky's the limit!
> 
> 
> -Cooper
> 
> 
> On Fri, 2003-03-07 at 10:40, Sean Dixon wrote:
> > This is great.
> > 
> > The verification has been set by default.  How do I turn it off?
> > 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Cooper Stevenson
> > Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 12:06 PM
> > To: PLUG Mailing List
> > Subject: RE: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
> > 
> > 
> > Sean,
> > 
> > Here is a command that will (fairly) safely delete all files in your
> > /tmp directory that are older than 5 days old.
> > 
> > The operative here is "fairly." There is the potential for this command
> > to remove files in directories other than /tmp. There is every chance
> > this will happen if you type the command in incorrectly. PLEASE BE
> > CERTAIN YOU HAVE TYPED THIS COMMAND EXACTLY AS I HAVE TYPED IT:
> > 
> >   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec rm -rf {} \;
> > 
> > If you are squeemish and wish to manually "okay" each file before it is
> > removed from your system enter the following at the command prompt:
> > 
> >   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec ok {} \;
> > 
> > The above will ask you for verification to make sure you wish to delete
> > the files this command finds. Some distributions have an alias for 'rm'
> > to do this by default. In effect the first command may ask you for
> > verification if your distribution is set up this way.
> > 
> > 
> > -Cooper

I have an answer for that Rich. Right now there is no mandate that the
State allow Open Source vendors consideration RFP and contract award
process. This bill mandates that Open Source be treated with the same
consideration as Microsoft and all of the other software vendors. This
is actually a very good thing since it seems to be difficult to convince
some State business units that moving to Linux is not as bad as they
think it might be.

Sean,

Use this command to figure out what is taking the most space in reverse
order by size:

  find / -exec du -h {} \; 2>/dev/null | sort -rn | less

This will take awhile. Substitute '/' with the directory that you wish
to search, '/var' for example.


-Cooper

I loaded my first P4 system.  The CPU was so new that the kernel did not

and it would fail with the above error.

> sure the monster just needs a cleaning, but I've no idea what to clean or
> what to use to clean it. The smudges are probably toner built up on
> something, but I'm no hardware repair person so I don't know where to start.
> 
> All suggestions greatly appreciated,
> 
> Rich

In most cases cyclic toner deposits on the page are caused by a failing
photoelectric drum (toner cartridge gone south). For the most part, not
always though, a dirty engine caused vertical streaking on the page.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Mar  7 22:34:03 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Mar  7 22:34:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emaill passwd and username recovery
In-Reply-To: <200303070101.25600.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKENECGAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph> 
	<200303070101.25600.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1047105208.2271.107.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-03-07 at 01:01, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Too bad for your users! No admin on any properly-managed modern system can 
> recover a password, the only option is to reset it. Passwords should not be 
> readable by human eyes. Though Russell pointed out how easy it is to capture 
> and read network traffic. A little encryption goes a long way towards curing 
> that. Some users are chronically whiny about passwords, the only things I 
> know to do are to streamline the system so they don't need to track a bunch 
> of passwords, and to be very stern on anything pertaining to security. No 
> Post-its, no dictionary words, birthdays, or pet names; periodic password 
> changes, no recycling the same three passwords, the usual basics.

Speaking from experience, I don't *fully* agree with this anymore Carla.
Although this theory works, the use of stronger passwords will, in the
case of most users, promote system unavailability which results in
post-it notes under the keyboard (which usually happens after calling me
3 times for password changes). About the time that more than 4 users in
a group of 20 have this happen the word gets around to the rest of that
department that the system is unreliable (it forgets my password every
few days and it'll forget yours too). Surprisingly enough, this is
likely to be a great excuse for not meeting deadlines in the eyes of a
junior/middle manager that slips a deadline or two as a result of an
obviously incompetent few. Considering that this is absurd and makes
folks like us roar with laughter is no consolation when your bosses
bosses boss wants a detailed report from an outside consultant as to why
the IT systems and administrators are so unreliable that the sales and
marketing groups are missing customer deadlines (remember, Executive
Managers are users too).

Moral of this rant:
Stronger system rules, like the three strikes and your locked out rule,
makes better sense than to force randomly generated and/or excessively
long and cryptic passwords down the throat of the user community. Good
monitoring practices and, as you mention here, abolition of in-the-clear
transmission is also a must. These methods are relatively transparent to
the user masses and will yield excellent results if properly
implemented. Also, it beats the hell out of a statement like:

"Carla the sysadmin's attitude about the user community is *too bad for
the users*"

showing up on that consultants report to the CEO!

Can you tell that I've been abused for something similar to this? It's
been a long time though and I swear that I'm not in the least bit bitter
about it.

Subject: [PLUG] PHP/IMAP Install Help
In-Reply-To: <000501c2e524$4f64e1b0$050a0a0a@xp1800>; from sigma_x@attbi.com on Fri, Mar 07, 2003 at 07:39:22PM -0800
References: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBDAB@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com> <1047090384.1237.8.camel@thorr> <1047093908.21545.8.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com> <000501c2e524$4f64e1b0$050a0a0a@xp1800>
Message-ID: <20030307232653.A17744@cogit8.org>

I just did this on my server with PHP 4.3.1, FreeBSD.  I followed the
direction on php.net also, putting the files where they said and pointed
to the directory with: --with-imap=/usr/local/imapxxxxx

I also had to make a switch about SSL since my imap compiled with SSL
support.

Here's my full config script if it helps...

'./configure' '--with-apache=../apache_1.3.27' '--with-mysql=/usr/local'
'--enable-memory-limit=yes' '--enable-debug=no'
'--with-imap=/usr/local/imap-2002b'
'--with-imap-ssl=/usr/include/openssl' 

-Rob

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Mar  8 08:23:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Mar  8 08:23:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emaill passwd and username recovery
In-Reply-To: <1047105208.2271.107.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303080807520.25185-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 7 Mar 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> Speaking from experience, I don't *fully* agree with this anymore
> Carla. Although this theory works, the use of stronger passwords
> will, in the case of most users, promote system unavailability....
>
> Moral of this rant:
> Stronger system rules, like the three strikes and your locked out
> rule, makes better sense than to force randomly generated and/or
> excessively long and cryptic passwords down the throat of the user
> community.

I really think password policies need to be appropriate to the 
situation.

* When I've worked in small private company, I typically ran John the 
  Ripper or l0phtcrack and *advised* employees that their passwords 
  are easily cracked using freely available tools.

  I worked under the assumption, however, that our network was
  relatively secure and insulated. I told employees that the biggest 
  danger to their account's security was probably other employees 
  running similar tools. I left it up to them to implement any 
  changes, but told them they'd be getting a similar notice every 
  couple months is their passwords were still easily cracked.

* Working in academia, where network users come and go at a dizzying 
  pace -- that's something different. The network is much less 
  insulated, much larger, and much more difficult to monitor.

  In our case, we run John the Ripper once a quarter and notify anyone 
  with an easily cracked password to make it more difficult *now*; 
  we check again in a few days and start disabling accounts (students) 
  or scheduling quick why-this-is-important meetings (faculty and 
  staff).

I just don't think there's a one-size-fits-all rule for password 
managment. Sometimes you can be loose, sometimes not.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Fri, 2003-03-07 at 01:01, Carla Schroder wrote:
> [...] No Post-its, no dictionary words, birthdays, or pet names;
> periodic password changes, no recycling the same three passwords, the
> usual basics.

In the (very large) company I work for, I have separate passwords for:
UNIX network systems (several different usernames)
UNIX root (several individual machines)
Windows network systems
Corporate intranet
Corporate VPN
SAP systems
Corporate external ftp
External web sites at affiliated companies

Many of these passwords force a change every 3 months, and you can't
repeat the last 5, etc.  Most people I know are forced to write down their
current passwords because they can't remember them all.  It's that or call
systems for a new password every three weeks.

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sat Mar  8 11:53:01 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sat Mar  8 11:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless pcmcia card & hub
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303080822540.9760-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303081213230.5188-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Sat, 8 Mar 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I'm buying a laptop and I want to put a wireless lan card in there and add
> a wireless hub to the network switch. I see that local stores are selling
> D-Link components (as well as LinkSys, NetGear and a product from that
> "other" place in Redmond). The laptop runs linux.
> 
>   This is all completely new to me so I'd appreciate suggestions.
> 


As 802.11b is very popular right now, unsurprisingly most pc cards have 
driver suppport with a few exceptions. Do your shopping an find the ones 
that strike your fancy for looks, features and whatever else.  Then do a 
google search for those particular cards.  There have been issues with 
Dlink (to name one) where the manufacturer changed the chipset but not the 
model designator rendering the card useless for linux compatibility.

>>>>>> "Josh" == Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> writes:
>
> Josh> I have web server which on a link I have it process a request
> Josh> and then use the Location: header to have the request sent to
> Josh> another server.  This server then returns the process request to
> Josh> me.  Which in this case is a file. A text file actually.
>
> So you have some process in the first server that is sending a full
> "Location:" header and 30x status code back to the browser, so the
> browser can fetch the URL from a new server?
>
> That's not clear from your description.  What happens if you fetch the
> URL directly with your browser?
>
> --
> Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777

Yes.  What I have found out is that if I put the URL in a browser it works
fine.  I have also found out that that Host: header that Apache writes
does not include the Port number with the first request.  If I ask for
authenication and not pass the cookie that I was Tomcat returns an
authenication prompt, I enter user/pw then Apache adds the Host: header
with the correct Port and Tomcat can retrieve the correct Port.

Headers look like:

with authenication first request

Host: tomcat.server.com


without auhenication but after manually entering auth.

Hot:  tomcat.server.com:8809

I have read up on the Host: header and it is suppose to add the port when
it is not 80.  This seems to be a consistant problem on many HTTP clients
which then makes we wonder.  It is only on the first request that they
fail to send the port number.  Like they want a response before actually
sending the correct information.

I hope that is clearer. Thanks for the help.

Josh

From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sat Mar  8 14:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Monitoring outgoing traffic
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303081133030.3634-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303081133030.3634-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1047162125.4058.7.camel@main>

On Sat, 2003-03-08 at 11:35, Phil Tomson wrote:
> 
> 
> The other day my internet connection (I'm still on dialup, I don't want to
> pay $50+/mo for cable) got very sloooowwww.  At first I thought it was the
> ISP's problem, but it persisted.  On a whim I rebooted my machine that
> does firewall/masquerading and after that things were back to normal.  Now
> a few days later it got slow again.  I'm beginning to suspect that perhaps
> something is sending lots of data out.  What's the best way to monitor for
> outgoing data?
> 
> Phil

Before you start to monitor with something like ethereal, which will
generate a large volume of data, you might want to use netstat -tus to
get a handle on the ratio of incoming to outgoing segments and
datagrams. With the info from netstat you can make a rational decision
as to what to focus on with a monitoring tool.

Steve

From jelque at feather.net  Sat Mar  8 16:22:01 2003
From: jelque at feather.net (Jeff Blain)
Date: Sat Mar  8 16:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] wheel mouse
In-Reply-To: <1047167639.1528.20.camel@thorr>
References: <1047167639.1528.20.camel@thorr>
Message-ID: <20030309002155.GA21652@blain.org>

On Sat, Mar 08, 2003 at 03:53:59PM -0800, Sean Dixon wrote:
> I am using a Logitech MouseMan Wheel mouse.  IMPS/2 does not work.  PS/2
> work fine, but I can't use that actual wheel in GUI.  Is there a way to
> activate the ability to use wheel scroll option?

Look in your /etc/X11/XF86Config-4 and make sure ZAxisMapping enabled.

Option          "ZAxisMapping"          "4 5"

Jeff

On Sat, 2003-03-08 at 22:58, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > No, it would mean the command isn't working correctly :)
> 
> It is counting the directories twice. I do not know why. This solves the
> problem:
> 
>   find / -type f -exec du -h {} \; 2>/dev/null | sort -rn | less
> 
> Does anyone know why this is happening? 

Because 'du -h /path' summarizes the subdirectories and the and
directories its called on. so for each subdirectory of /foo, you get
/foo counted.  If you want it to work right, use 'du -sh'.

Wil

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sun Mar  9 09:43:03 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Mar  9 09:43:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Admin Problem #2
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090747270.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090747270.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047231732.9974.126.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sun, 2003-03-09 at 07:53, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   According to the Slackware.txt file on the distribution cdrom (#1), there
> are supposed to be two directories: bootdisks/ and rootdisks/. However,
> they're not there.

If you ordered the official disk set, they may be on one of the other
CDs... they were taken off the first CD to make it small enough to fit
on a CD-R.  One-CD installs is what Pat was going for.

Grab them from your favorite mirror (leave ftp.slackware.com for the
mirrors to sync against).  I really like ftp.kpn.be, it is one fast
mirror and I know the admin.  :-)

>   If I read and understood the text file correctly, I need three floppy
> disks: a boot disk (bare.i), a root disk, and the pcmcia.img disk. Since the
> cdrom doesn't have the two directories it's supposed to, I'm wondering if I
> need to search the disk for the specific files then dd them to floppies.

Infortunately... the root disk is now something like six disks long in
Slackware 8.1.  The kernel can load one compressed initrd disk or
multiple non-compressed disks... so when Pat's root disk went over a
compressed 1.whatever megabyte disk size, he had to run it uncompressed.

He overcame the problem with 9.0 with the idea (I think) of putting just
the bare minimum on the initrd and then copying files from a second disk
after it loaded.  As boot/root disks are backwards-compatable (but *not*
forwards-compatable) you can use the boot/root/pcmcia from
slackware-current to install off the Slackware-8.1 CD.

A friend and I came up with the idea of a one-CD boot for those with
ATAPI CD-ROM drives but a BIOS unable to boot the new 8.1 CD (which
booted differently than 8.0 and earlier did - it didn't emulate a floppy
like they did)... we created a FreeDOS bootdisk with loadlin that loaded
an image off the CD-ROM drive.  It worked well, but I don't think would
work for your PCMCIA CD-ROM drive without a little hacking (to add
drivers for the PCMCIA controller).

>   I checked the Slackware Web site, but there's no general user mail list,
> only announce and security-announce. Other than one person in Ohio who I
> know runs Slackware, I don't know where to get educated. Some of you do run
> this distribution so I hope that you can help me over this first hurdle.

If you search groups.google.com for alt.os.linux.slackware, you should
find answers to most of your questions.  Otherwise, there are at least a
few Slackware users here on the PLUG list, and I think a few more over
on the PDXLUG list.  There are also a few general user lists out there,
I think.  There are also forums at www.userlocal.com (web-based) along
with links to a lot of other stuff.  Then there are a lot of packages
available at www.linuxpackages.net if you decide to go the precompiled
package route for things (which I don't suggest - just get the source).

Have fun, happy Slacking.  :-)

Rob




From plug at laynesoftware.com  Sun Mar  9 09:44:02 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Sun Mar  9 09:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Admin Problem #2
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090747270.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090747270.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030309174215.M20557@laynesoftware.com>

On Sun, 9 Mar 2003 07:53:21 -0800 (PST), Rich Shepard wrote
> 
>   If I read and understood the text file correctly, I need three floppy
> disks: a boot disk (bare.i), a root disk, and the pcmcia.img disk. 

You may have already figured this out from the sound of it, but as of 8.1 the
rootdisk is too big for a single floppy, so instead of color.gz you have to
make disks with install.1, ..., install.5.  So you'll need bare.i, pcmcia.dsk,
and the five install.* disks.  If you want you can use network.dsk and install
over the network if you have trouble with the pcmcia cdrom.

BTW, if you want to get bleeding edge and use slackware-current, there is a
handy perl script called slackupdate that updates currently installed packages
with packages in the current directory.  I'm keeping a private mirror of
slackware-current and have used that perl script as the basis for an "up2date"
script.  You can probably google for slackupdate, or let me know if you can't
find it and I'll email it to you.

--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR

From judah at opusnet.com  Sun Mar  9 11:39:02 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Sun Mar  9 11:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless pcmcia card & hub
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303080822540.9760-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303080822540.9760-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047238722.9900.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>

You really want to make sure that the card has Prism chipset in the
wireless card.

Check netgate for some really fantastic 200mW cards that will give you
the most range and sensitivity for the buck.
http://netgate.com/

The best linux support will be for the prism 2/2.5/3 chipsets and you
also have the ability to use them in AP mode to create a linux based AP.
Orinoco cards have great client support under Linux and are reliable
cards there is no AP mode support for these cards in Linux only AD-HOC
and Managed.

As far as off the shelf APs go the Linksys aren't that bad at all. 

Watch out for the new DLink and Linksys client cards as many
manufacturers have moved to a chipset from Broadcom and those don't have
support under Linux.

Check here for another list of Prism based cards:
http://www.personaltelco.net/index.cgi/Prism2Card

The Netgate cards are great.

A-

From drl at drloree.com  Sun Mar  9 12:14:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun Mar  9 12:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Admin Problem #1
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090744020.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303090744020.10539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047240824.8099.2270.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sun, 2003-03-09 at 07:47, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I have a portable running Libranet/debian and I need to change a user
> account so login goes to the console rathern than gdm. I've completely
> blanked on where the individual-user-run-level is set. It's not
> /etc/inittab.

/etc/init.d/ contains the startup scripts, /etc/rc?.d/ contain links to
the startup scripts.  Any link that starts with an "S" runs the script
with a "start" parameter, any link that starts with a K, runs the script
with a "stop" parameter.

Essentially, Debian uses only through run-level 2, the additional
run-levels are there, but they start off as just duplicates of rc2.d. 
These additional run levels can be modified, then utilized, but I'm not
sure that will do the job you in the way you want.

Do you want just one user to not get the GUI login?  Or, do you want all
users to not get the GUI login?

If the first is true, then you will probably be better off controlling
the .xsession and .bashrc of your users, have gdm off globally, but
starts up for those that you want.

If the latter is true, then just uninstall gdm, problem solved.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From raanders at acm.org  Sun Mar  9 16:47:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sun Mar  9 16:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making installation floppies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303091431440.11762-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303091642490.19486-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sun, 9 Mar 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've had the occasional floppy disk not want to work with linux, but today
> has set a record. I need 7 floppies to boot my notebook so I can install
> Slackware. Using "dd if=<filename> of=/dev/fd0", I successfully made 3 of
> the 7 floppies. The last 9 attempts _looked_ like they were working, but I
> cannot mount the floppy drive to look at the disks:
> 
> [rshepard at salmo /usr1/slackware-8.1]$ dd if=install.5 of=/dev/fd0
> 2880+0 records in
> 2880+0 records out
> [rshepard at salmo /usr1/slackware-8.1]$ mount /mnt/floppy
> mount: I could not determine the filesystem type, and none was specified

Sounds like there is no formatting on the floppies or they are some 
_really_ strange format.  As you may know floppies typically get a 
low-level format plus a system level.   Could be you have really raw 
bunch of floppies, ie. never used before.  Try 

	fdformat /dev/fd0H1440

first then use the dd command.


Rod

In-Reply-To: <1047075914.5121.299.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Cooper Stevenson
Sent: Friday, March 07, 2003 2:25 PM
To: PLUG Mailing List
Subject: RE: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx


As root, check out the following files:

  /etc/bashrc
  /root/.bashrc

Less likely you are using the Korne shell:

  /etc/kshrc
  /root/.kshrc

You should see something like:

  alias rm -rf='rm -rif'

Remove this alias and (possibly) re-login.

DISCLAIMER: Doing this may someday cause you grief. The Linux 'rm'
command, just like about everything else in Linux, will do _exactly_
what you tell it too. No "are you sure" dialog boxes, no "you are about
to do something silly" messages, just the absolute command.

'rm' will absolutely trash your system without even the common courtesy
of a ..err, you get the picture.

So if you're feeling manly--if you think you got what it takes, you just
remove those 'wimpy' lines from your *rc files, the sky's the limit!


-Cooper


On Fri, 2003-03-07 at 10:40, Sean Dixon wrote:
> This is great.
> 
> The verification has been set by default.  How do I turn it off?
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org 
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Cooper Stevenson
> Sent: Thursday, March 06, 2003 12:06 PM
> To: PLUG Mailing List
> Subject: RE: [PLUG] Failed boot and no startx
> 
> 
> Sean,
> 
> Here is a command that will (fairly) safely delete all files in your 
> /tmp directory that are older than 5 days old.
> 
> The operative here is "fairly." There is the potential for this 
> command to remove files in directories other than /tmp. There is every

> chance this will happen if you type the command in incorrectly. PLEASE

> BE CERTAIN YOU HAVE TYPED THIS COMMAND EXACTLY AS I HAVE TYPED IT:
> 
>   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec rm -rf {} \;
> 
> If you are squeemish and wish to manually "okay" each file before it 
> is removed from your system enter the following at the command prompt:
> 
>   find /tmp -atime +5 -exec ok {} \;
> 
> The above will ask you for verification to make sure you wish to 
> delete the files this command finds. Some distributions have an alias 
> for 'rm' to do this by default. In effect the first command may ask 
> you for verification if your distribution is set up this way.
> 
> 
> -Cooper

On Sun, 9 Mar 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   The md5 sums of install.? match the values in the file, CHECKSUMS.md5,
> from the slackware ftp server.

  Thanks to Rob and Ed I learned a lesson: the file copied to the disk with
'dd' is not mountable. However, when I calculate the md5sum on /dev/fd0, it
matches the checksum of the install.? file on the hard drive.

  In the six years now that I've been running Red Hat I never encountered
this situation so I had no experience in unmountable floppy disks.

  Public thanks to both of 'em!

Sean Dixon wrote:

>

> (HP Omnibook laptop) do not work either.  They did at installation, but
> I apparently changed something along the lines to disable them.
>

My ps/2 microsoft intellimouse is happy with
(/etc/X11/XF86Config-4)

Section "InputDevice"
         Identifier  "Mouse0"
         Driver      "mouse"
         Option      "Device" "/dev/mouse"
         Option      "Protocol" "imps/2"
         Option      "Emulate3Buttons" "off"
         Option      "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
EndSection

Don't know if case makes a difference.  Is yours a ps/2 or usb?  Have never 
configured a usb mouse.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

On Sun, 9 Mar 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> I'm currently the only user receiving mail on my home lan and I'd like to be 
> able send/receive (and access central addressbook) from two client machines 
> while maintaining one mailbox directory.

Kyle,

  I guess that I don't understand. Here, we have /home and /var/spool/mail
exported from the server and nfs mounted on the other workstation (or the
portables when desired). Regardless of which machine is in front of us, we
log in to our one /home directory and mail is there in the same place. I
wasn't aware this was a mail problem. It worked this way for several years
before we dropped dial up for ADSL. Ran fetchmail as a daemon (checking for
mail every 2 minutes via pop3) for almost two years until I set up postfix
here and had the primary MX point here.

From drl at drloree.com  Sun Mar  9 22:41:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun Mar  9 22:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Making installation floppies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303091924560.11804-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303091924560.11804-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047278455.8098.2338.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sun, 2003-03-09 at 19:32, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sun, 9 Mar 2003, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
> > Sounds like there is no formatting on the floppies or they are some 
> > _really_ strange format.  As you may know floppies typically get a 
> > low-level format plus a system level.   Could be you have really raw 
> > bunch of floppies, ie. never used before.  Try 
> > 
> > 	fdformat /dev/fd0H1440
> > 
> > first then use the dd command.
> 
> Rod,
> 
>   The disks are pre-formatted (vfat, of course). In any case, dd is a
> byte-by-byte copying tool so it doesn't matter whether or not the disk is
> formatted. 
This isn't true.  When I copy images of 1680k formatted disks, I have to
format the disk (with "superformat /dev/fd0 sect=21 cyl=80") to the
larger size before dd will successfully copy.  So the formatting of a
floppy does add information to the disk that dd doesn't (or can't) copy.

Just thought I'd set the record straight.

Derek Loree

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Mar 10 05:36:01 2003

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean Dixon <seanpdixon at yahoo.com> writes:

Sean> The alias referring to rm is in the root dir

Sean> I understand -i is a verify command.  I am going to live on the edge and
Sean> comment this one out.  Call me crazy  :^)

I think you're completely sane.  I think people who set up aliases
overloading system commands are nuts.

The problem is, if *you* do that on one box, and then you type on a
different box, that same flag isn't there.  Ooops!

Go ahead and alias:

        aliase del = 'rm -i'

and learn to type "del".  The worst that will happen is that you get
to another box, and the "del" alias isn't there!

  I have failed to communicate clearly. The 'dd' command ran to completion.

written to a floppy disk was done properly. Therefore, when the 'dd' command
returned, I tried to mount the floppy so I could list the contents. That's
why I was getting the messages about the filesystem type not being specified
or discernable to the system.

  However, using Rob's suggestion of comparing md5sums between the floppy
contents and the checksums provided on the Slackware site I was able to
verify both that the 'dd' command worked properly and just which file was on
the diskette.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 10 08:18:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Making installation floppies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303091431440.11762-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <1047260817.9969.141.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sun, 2003-03-09 at 14:35, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I've had the occasional floppy disk not want to work with linux, but today
> has set a record. I need 7 floppies to boot my notebook so I can install
> Slackware. Using "dd if=<filename> of=/dev/fd0", I successfully made 3 of
> the 7 floppies. The last 9 attempts _looked_ like they were working, but I
> cannot mount the floppy drive to look at the disks:

The rootdisks (five of them, IIRC) all together make up one filesystem. 
I'd test them with md5sum, not trying to mount them (if you don't want
to use the slackware-current rootdisks, instead, anyway)... or cat them
all together into one big file and try and mount that, loopback.

Since the disks together make up a single filesystem, you can't mount
them individually.

Rob




From stever at woo-hoo.com  Mon Mar 10 08:41:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
Message-ID: <34583.207.173.0.68.1047314414.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

My Postfix header_checks is blocking a friend trying to send me an email
because it is failing the helo filter.  It is failing because he is NATing
his home LAN, and his mail server presents itself with a FQDN which
doesn't resolve to a public IP address.
Is there an easy way to make a Postfix whitelist which says "accept mail
from so-and-so regardless of the other filters"?  I can simply turn off
the helo checks, but they seem to be useful in stopping at least some
spam.

Thanks!

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Mar 10 09:11:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Mar 10 09:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
In-Reply-To: <34583.207.173.0.68.1047314414.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <34583.207.173.0.68.1047314414.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1047316170.24520.845.camel@red>

On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 08:40, Steven Raymond wrote:
> Is there an easy way to make a Postfix whitelist which says "accept mail
> from so-and-so regardless of the other filters"?

Yes, of course. Just create a map file with the IP address(es)
of the remote mail server(s) you always want to receive mail
from and refer to it in your smtpd_recipient_restrictions
sections before the maps that block the mail.
For example:

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
      check_client_access = hash:/etc/postfix/goodip,
      ...,
      [your black lists]
      ...,
      permit mynetworks

In the goodip file:

1.2.3.4   OK


Don't forget to use the postmap program

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Mar 10 09:29:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon Mar 10 09:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IMAP for home use?
In-Reply-To: <3E6C3CA0.8030308@pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303092114440.12906-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030310092027.01789da0@localhost>

At 11:20 PM 3/9/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>I guess you've had better luck with nfs than me.  My experience is that if 
>a client disconnects ungracefully (dead laptop batt), the server becomes 
>unresponsive.

I can't say that I've had that problem, and I'm serving nfs to 150 *nix 
machines. However, I'm doing so via autofs, not static mounts. autofs 
allows the system to mount the directory when needed, and then it 
automatically unmounts if it's not used for a period of time.

There IS one problem with nfs in linux as opposed to other Unixes, that I'm 
aware of. And it does involve ungraceful umounting. However, it's when the 
server goes away while the client is connected. The client maintains the 
mount information, and when the server comes back, it doesn't know about 
it. The client will then report a "Stale mount", and the server ignores 
requests for that export, from that client. I know Solaris handles this 
gracefully, and will allow the client to reconnect. Forcing a umount on the 
client of the affected mount will usually resolve this issue.


Russ Johnson

From kaile at centerspan.com  Mon Mar 10 09:51:01 2003
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Mon Mar 10 09:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emaill passwd and username recovery
Message-ID: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC4855CEC@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>

Not necessarily. 

There is a little program called TealLock too. This program obfuscates
the on-screen passwords while you put them in by making them little
stars (*). You can also use a 'keypad combination'. That is a feature
that allows you to use the application buttons and scroll buttons on
your palm as a sortof combo lock. Also, TealLock has a feature that
allows you to set an arbitrary number of failed logins after which your
entire palm is erased. It also has encryption, and a lot of other things
that make life easier.

There is now a release of PGP 8.0 for PalmOS as well, giving PGPDisk
support (among other things) which is fairly secure.

I think the combination of these two things would make a palm fairly
well secured. Links provided below.

TealLock: http://www.tealpoint.com/softlock.htm
PGP 8.0:  http://www.pgp.com/products/mobile.html#palm


Kaile Riser
Systems Administrator
CenterSpan Communications Corp.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Mar 10 10:03:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Mar 10 10:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IMAP for home use?
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030310092027.01789da0@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303100958530.10080-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 10 Mar 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> There IS one problem with nfs in linux as opposed to other Unixes,
> that I'm aware of. And it does involve ungraceful umounting.
> However, it's when the server goes away while the client is
> connected. The client maintains the mount information, and when the
> server comes back, it doesn't know about it. The client will then
> report a "Stale mount", and the server ignores requests for that
> export, from that client.

In my experience, that's only partially true. If the server goes away
and then comes back while the client had no open files, then all is
well. The staleness gets reported only when open files are involved.

> I know Solaris handles this gracefully, and will allow the client to
> reconnect. Forcing a umount on the client of the affected mount will
> usually resolve this issue.

Mostly true, unless the NFS connection is using tcp instead of udp 
(which is far more common on Solaris systems than Linux hosts). tcp 
connctions, being stateful, require a forced umount/mount.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

##Equivalent of cut and paste

perl -0777 -ne

it into a second script that just does key lookups.  It should be
faster, especially since the precompilation can be done only when the
database changes.  It would save the iterating through hash keys.

On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 10:25, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Well, I knew it was too easy. :-) The installation on my Toshiba was
> plodding along just fine until I got to the networking setup. When the
> system asked me if I wanted it to probe for the NIC, I put in the pcmcia NIC
> and responded, "yes". The result was a kernel panic and an inability to fix
> anything 'cause I don't yet have a root password and I selected reiserfs for
> the filesystems when I ran fdisk.

I think all the probing for hardware does is it attempts to load a
module, then if that fails it moves on to the next, and so on.  Toss
PCMCIA into that mix and many times you run in to problems like kernel
oop's.

I'd just load the proper module for your network card manually and go
that route...

Rob

On Sun, 2003-03-09 at 21:38, Carla Schroder wrote:

> But but but the Slackware site says to do this:

Just so folks are aware... the slackware website is simply not kept up
to date.

A few years ago, Slackware lost its publisher (which also published a
BSD, and decided they didn't want Slackware and a BSD, as Slackware is
so BSD-like).... and when that happened, Pat took over and has pretty
much been running slackware by himself ever since.

He doesn't like documentation or website maintenance, as far as I can
tell... a group of regular posters from alt.os.linux.slackware have
started a 'Slackbook Renewal Project' to fix The Good Book so it is up
to date in regards to Slackware 8.0 and up.  The book was written for
7.1.  When that is done, the documentation on slackware.com will be more
up to date... but until then, look elsewhere for slackware specific
stuff (pretty  much just the install and special bootscripts) and look
at generic linux for the rest of it.

Rob

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Mar 10 14:24:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Mar 10 14:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] natural join on text files
In-Reply-To: <86k7fa92d1.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86heaealvu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<E18rQ4E-0005WX-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

	<20030307143805.A13755@zaphod.axian.com>
	<86ptp2947n.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86k7fa92d1.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86of4i275c.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> And, here is what seems to be a suitable filter and
Russell> command-line:

Russell>   $ sed 's/^\(.*\)[ ]*$/^\1($| )/' file1 | egrep -f - file2

Just a followup, my sed command is broken (doesn't strip trailing
white space).  This one seems to work better and is a little more
compact:

  $ sed -e 's/^/^/' -e 's/ *$/($| )/' file1 | egrep -f - file2

The first -e clause is a little confusing at first glance, appearing
to replace a caret with a caret.  However, the caret in the pattern
matches the start of line, while the caret in the replacement is a
literal.  

The second -e clause replaces trailing white space with the optional
pattern for egrep.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Mar 10 15:56:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon Mar 10 15:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] tcpdump data interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20030310124405.A2952@patch.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301290824380.11049-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303101200010.6993-100000@shell1.aracnet.com> <20030310124405.A2952@patch.com>
Message-ID: <20030310235540.GE5431@rauhaus.org>

* mikeraz at patch.com <mikeraz at patch.com> [030310 12:45]:
>
> Some process on your machine is talking to the irc daemon at 213.92.8.4 aka calvino.freenode.net.  So, yes, you are right about that.  The irc server is on the other machine and whether you know it or not, you had an active irc client going when you did the tcpdump.
> 
> netstat should show the connection.  Did you `netstat -nt` ?

Lots of rootkits & other bits of nasty software will open (without your
knowlege) a connection to an IRC server in order to receive their
instructions, such as which victim to start DOSing, where to email your
credit card/social security/bank account numbers, and so on.

So unless you knowingly had an IRC client running, assume that your
machine has been compromised.

--Stafford

>   I'm now wondering what else I have to add manually to get going. Haven't
> tried the network or starting X yet.

X will probably work without any messing with the config file, via the
VESA framebuffer.  But you want to configure it yourself to use your
video card/chip for the acceleration.  You can grab 3.3.6 packages if
you need to downgrade XFree.

If you didn't set up the network yet, run netconfig or just manually
edit /etc/rc.d/rc.inet1 (most of the variables are at the top, I think).

On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 09:09, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 08:40, Steven Raymond wrote:
> > Is there an easy way to make a Postfix whitelist which says "accept mail
> > from so-and-so regardless of the other filters"?
> 
> Yes, of course. Just create a map file with the IP address(es)
> of the remote mail server(s) you always want to receive mail
> from and refer to it in your smtpd_recipient_restrictions
> sections before the maps that block the mail.
> For example:
> 
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
>       check_client_access = hash:/etc/postfix/goodip,
>       ...,
>       [your black lists]
>       ...,
>       permit mynetworks
> 
> In the goodip file:
> 
> 1.2.3.4   OK
> 
> 
> Don't forget to use the postmap program
> 

Are you sure this will work?

http://www.postfix.com/uce.html

        At present, specifying a header pattern with OK serves no useful
        purpose. A rule ending in OK affects only the header being
        matched. The next header may still result in a REJECT match,
        causing the mail still to be rejected.

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Mon Mar 10 17:59:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Mon Mar 10 17:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] URL redirect with mod_rewrite?
In-Reply-To: <6829.12.47.207.4.1047346650.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <6829.12.47.207.4.1047346650.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <2064.134.244.174.61.1047347885.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>


> I would like to have Apache redirect URLs for me.  For example, when a
> user goes to http://server1.domain.tld, I want them redirected to
> http://server2.domain.tld.  Currently I'm accomplishing this with HTTP
> redirects in a bunch of HTML files, but I think it'd be cleaner and
> easier to manage if I could have one line per domain in my httpd.conf.
>
> Any suggestions?
> Thanks,
> ~M

Matt,

You may find the ProxyPass and ProxyPassReverse to be the easiest for
whole domain redirects.

Syntax is:

ProxyPass / http://server2.domain.tld/
ProxyPassReverse / http://server2.domain.tld/

This would redirect anything from the first domain to the other.  The
reverse will allow anything coming back from the 2nd to go back out from
apache.  I use this with much success.  You can even use this for things
like redirecting a particular sub directory to a completely differnet host
or port.

Another example would be:

ProxyPass /mydir http://server2.domain.tld:8888/otherdir
ProxyPassReverse /mydir http://server2.domain.tld:8888/otherdir


These would go in your virtual directives.  That is assuming you have
virtual directives. Or at the root otherwise.

Josh

mencoder can use the v4l driver to select a channel as an argument.

Here's the command I stole from freevo; salt to taste:

/usr/bin/mencoder -tv \
on:driver=v4l:input=0:norm=NTSC:channel=58:chanlist=us-cable:width=320:height=240:outfmt=yv12:adevice=/dev/audio:audiorate=32000:forceaudio:forcechan=1:buffersize=64
-ovc lavc -lavcopts vcodec=mpeg4:vbitrate=1200:keyint=30 -oac \
mp3lame -lameopts br=128:cbr:mode=3 -ffourcc divx -o foo.avi

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Mar 10 20:45:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
In-Reply-To: <1047347737.1199.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303102041560.17534-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 10 Mar 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:

> Are you sure this will work?
> 
>         At present, specifying a header pattern with OK serves no useful
>         purpose. A rule ending in OK affects only the header being
>         matched. The next header may still result in a REJECT match,
>         causing the mail still to be rejected.
 
Wil,

  I cannot address using IP addresses, but putting the domain name with an
"OK" works just fine here. I had a couple of folks who's mail bounced for no
reason we could discover. I put their domain names in /etc/postfix/badaddr
and /etc/postfix/header_checks, right at the top, and mail from them began
arriving again.
 
Rich

Kyle...

I don't see that it's that big of a deal. My entire family uses IMAP

reading our E-Mail from. Depending on what your options are. You could

has IMAP already implemented on their side and they just let you have
access to it. :)

> Bullets/Numbering and other such menu choices. Each of them gives me choices
> for how I want the results to appear (within their limits, of course), but I
> cannot see where to turn it completly off.
> 
> Anyone?

Numbering is usually tied to the paragraph style.  Select the
paragraphs that numbering automatically and then do:

Format -> Paragraph

Numbering Tab

In the pulldown, select None.

This will turn off numbering in existing paragraphs.

Hmmm....wait a minute, you mean automatic numbering, where
you're manually typing a list in and it decides to help
by automatically detecting and formatting.  Try this instead:

Tools -> AutoCorrect/AutoFormat

Options Tab

Deselect "Apply numbering - symbol: *"

I think this is a per document selection.  Does anyone know how to make
this Rich's (and my) default?

Colin

OK. My first hunch is that DNS isn't working correctly. On your Linux 
box, run

   dig hotmail.com mx +short

You should *very quickly* see an answer like this:

  5 mx3.hotmail.com.
  5 mx4.hotmail.com.
  5 mx1.hotmail.com.
  5 mx2.hotmail.com.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Mar 11 11:04:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Mar 11 11:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] delayed delivery of emails
In-Reply-To: <F74SpjYPEsJPWJs5Vdu000154f2@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303111053460.15515-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 11 Mar 2003, sag tom wrote:

> Thank you very much for your response. I ran that 'dig' command and
> it does show the results instantly as you mentioned.

OK, now we need to see if your Internet-facing IP address resolves 
correctly:

Let's assume that eth0 is your external interface. To find your IP 
address, run

host $(/sbin/ifconfig | \
  grep -A 4 eth0 | \
  awk '/inet/ {print $2}' | \
  sed -e s/addr://)

(Change eth0 to the actual interface you use to connect to the 
Internet.)

You should see something like

  56.232.187.66.in-addr.arpa domain name pointer www.redhat.com.

Or, you may see something like

  Host 200.33.95.129.in-addr.arpa not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)

If you see the second form, that's bad. It means that some mail 
servers won't like receiving mail from you.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Mar 11 13:40:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Mar 11 13:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mic -> MP3?
References: <200303111314.44487.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <3E6E579A.4000507@pacifier.com>

guy1656 wrote:
> Can anyone recommend a good, 'it just works,' GUI program which allows a 
> microphone plugged into the jack to record sounds into MP3?
> 
> -GLL


Audacity will do that, although I think it is a two step process.  Record 
your signal (it uses a unique format for it's temp files), then export to mp3.

You can find rpms of the older stable version, but enough new stuff has been 
added/fixed that's it worth the trouble of building the latest (1.1.1) from 
source.  IIRC you need to turn on mp3 cabability at build time, and you'll 
need the mp3 libs as well as a few other packages.  It'll do ogg, too.

$ ./configure --help

The docs are good and the app itself is pretty nice.  It is a waveform 
editor with just enough stuff without getting cluttered and overly-complex.

http://audacity.sourceforge.net/



--
Kyle Accardi

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Mar 11 20:40:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Mar 11 20:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems with proftp
In-Reply-To: <3E6EAD98.8010808@aracnet.com>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0303111028200.15515-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> 
	<3E6EAD98.8010808@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1047443949.1141.175.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-03-11 at 19:46, Kirk Goins wrote:
> My son was... shall we say tinkering and now I can't FTP to my Mandrake 8.2 box.
> I've un-installed proftp and re-installed but still can't access the system. 

Well, and I hate to overstate the obvious here, start with changing the
root password so this doesn't happen again. Sounds like supervised use
is prudent here.
 
> can ping the port but as soon as I try to start a ftp session I get:
> 'Connection closed by remote host' if I do it from windows. If I try to ftp from 
> the system to its self on either the private IP (192.x.x.x) or Public 
> (216.x.x.x) I get: 421 Service not available.
> 

Did you look into proftpd's conf file to make sure that you still have
an account setup? Might look at the owner of the filesystem that your
exposing with proftp too, make sure that the user that runs the ftp
daemon still has permissions. Also, if I remember correctly, proftpd
does write to /var/log/<something>. Take a look there to see if it is
starting and if there are errors that you can track. Take a look in
netstat -tl to see if port 21 is up too. If port 21 is not active you
might try manually starting it from a root prompt, normally done from
running the command `/etc/init.d/proftpd start` from a root user.

Best of luck to ya.

> >      (Source: LinuxWorld.com) Unix developer The SCO Group has

> > trade secrets, unfair competition and other illegal actions
> > related to IBM's Linux business. The suit seeks at least US$1
> > billion in damages. [IDG News Service]

> Interestingly enough, a lot of folks view this as a plea from SCO for
> IBM to purchase that failing company. SCO's reported net worth is about
> 25 million, that's less than IBM will spend on a legal defense here.
>
You forgot to add to that the usual amounts of money they'll throw at
Darl McBride & associates to go away. (Do you expect IBM to keep this
bunch of wankers as employees?) When I worked at GST, I heard that one
senior VP was given a million dollar severance package when she was
let go -- & a few months later GST declared bankrupcy. I'd figure that
it'll cost IBM about $10 million to properly dispose of the executive
staff who launched SCO on its final adventure.

On the other hand, does SCO have $25 million cash to make a proper effort
to litigate against IBM? SCO probably can afford a few million to pay
Boies & a small staff for a year or two; IBM probably can spare that many
salaried staff lawyers for an unlimited time to simply crank out enough
paperwork to bleed SCO dry. And SCO/Caldera hasn't had a profitable
quarter in quite a while.

It would be a great service to the FOSS community if IBM did call
SCO/Caldera's bluff, go to court, & when SCO/Caldera had to give up their
case because they ran out of money to pay their lawyers, IBM offered
to settle if SCO/Caldera surrendered all of their remaining assets.

Frankly, all of this is entertaining talk, but until we see the first
legal manueverings in this lawsuit, all any of this is just talk. I
wouldn't be surprised if SCO's case is dismissed with prejudice in the
first hearing. Then again, I've been wrong about this kind of stuff
before: they might go to court & actually win, or convince IBM to
buy them out.

Geoff

> Hi all folks
>
> I encountered problem in building a RPM package.  Steps carried out as
> follows;

Well, first of all, a tar file is not an rpm package.  Here are a few commands 
for dealing with tar files

tar tvf file.tar  (lists files in the tar archive)
tar xf file.tar   (extracts all files in the tar archive)

See the man page for tar for more information.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 06:55:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 12 06:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problem in building RPM package
In-Reply-To: <3E6F2FFF.2060308@icare.com.hk>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303120647391.1559-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 12 Mar 2003, Stephen Liu wrote:

> Hi all folks
> 
> I encountered problem in building a RPM package.  Steps carried out as 
> follows;
> 
> as 'USER'
> 
> $ rpmbuild -tb /home/user/AAA.tar
> error: File /home/user/AAA.tar: Permission denied
> sh: /home/user/AAA.tar: Permission denied
> error: Failed to rename /usr/src/redhat/SPECS/rpm-spec.iEoPOB to 
> /usr/src/redhat/SPECS/rpm-spec.iEoPOB: No such file or directory: No 
> such file or directory

1. USER will need write access to subdirectories in /usr/src/redhat.

2. Are you sure that AAA.tar has a .spec file inside it? Not all 
   tarballs ship that way...

3. Assuming that 1. and 2. are true, and it still doesn't work, you'll 
   need to do something like this to capture the error messages:

   rpm -tb -vv tarball.tar.gz | tee /tmp/rpm-errors.txt

   The resulting /tmp/rpm-errors.txt file will likely be very 
   instructive.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Mar 12 07:57:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Mar 12 07:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A look at SCO's odd lawsuit (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303111457100.20926-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303111457100.20926-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047484538.1894.1001.camel@red>

On Tue, 2003-03-11 at 14:58, Rich Shepard wrote:
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------

> SCO SUES IBM OVER LINUX, SEEKS $1 BILLION
A few things:

1. This is SOP for Caldera (now SCO). When Caldera was first
formed, three business units were formed. One marketed Linux,
another marketed embedded operating systems, and another was
established to sue Microsoft. This third business unit
acquired DR-DOS and then sued Microsoft for unfair trade
practices. Caldera prevailed and won an undisclosed
settlement that was never disclosed but many guess was in the
neighborhood of $400 million.

2. Before Caldera was formed, Project Corsair at Novell
resulted in Linux kernel code for Novell's IPX protocol. The
code was sent to Linus Torvalds and (via Alan Cox I imagine)
was included in the kernel source tree. When Caldera was formed,
that code was probably purchased from Novell. That code should
probably be removed from the source tree. Sorry, I'm an informed
but not authoritative source for this information.

3. I've decided to no longer mention UnitedLinux in my books
and articles. SCO needs to know that this action may cost
them their business. SCO's partners in United Linux need to
know this as well.

4. The Linux Professional Institute (LPI) has plans to release
a UnitedLinux certification. Perhaps they need to know that
this could put their normal Linux certification program in
jeopardy.

5. This affair has the Linux community rallying to IBM's
side. This is understandable given IBM's support for Linux
but let's not forget that IBM is an Intellectual Property
(IP) powerhouse as well. They could very well be a similar
threat in the future.

6. If you want to minimize IP risk, you should choose a
Linux distribution that's not directly tied to IP owners.
This makes Debian and Slackware all the more appealing.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

Nohup.out is only created if you do not redirect output of nohup yourself,
it's like a default redirection. So redirect it to /dev/null instead.

How about running the client in quiet mode. Then you wouldn't have a file to get rid of.

  From the distributedfolding client readme

     To run the client in quiet mode (i.e. no output whatsoever to the terminal),
     simply edit the foldit script (foldit.bat on Windows) and add "-qt" (without
     the quotes) to the end of the line containing "foldtrajlite -f protein -n
     native".

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Mar 12 11:30:03 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed Mar 12 11:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS Permission Q
Message-ID: <3E6F8AB0.40703@pacifier.com>

Okay, it's been awhile and I can't find the answer in the places I've looked 
(duh).

Problem is that a directory mounted via fstab (or manually by root) gets a 
uid/gid that doesn't otherwise exist on the client.  Therefore, no one has 
access.

Added no_root_squash to prove that my method is otherwise working.  And root 
can now `ls`, but this is to be for user home dirs.

I understand, that ideally, the user (let's call him `test`) should have the 
same uid/gid on both machines, but I don't want to do this.  I also don't 
want him squashed to anonymous.  Is this a job for NIS? or is there an 
easier way?  (Maybe NIS is easy...)

(From what I gather, automount wouldn't help this problem)


===========
server's /etc/exports
   /home/test	192.168.0.0/255.255.255.0(rw,no_root_squash)


client's /etc/fstab
   192.168.0.100:/home/test	/home/test	nfs	size=8192,wsize=8192


once mounted, /home/test looks like
   drwx------    2 502      502          4096 Mar 11 20:57 test


/etc/passwd says
   test:x:501:501::/home/test:/bin/bash


--
Kyle Accardi




From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 11:42:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 12 11:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS Permission Q
In-Reply-To: <3E6F8AB0.40703@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121133560.1559-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 12 Mar 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> Problem is that a directory mounted via fstab (or manually by root)
> gets a uid/gid that doesn't otherwise exist on the client.  
> Therefore, no one has access.
> 
> I understand, that ideally, the user (let's call him `test`) should
> have the same uid/gid on both machines, but I don't want to do this.

It's more than 'ideally'; more like 'mandatory' ...

Well, there's the hack of exporting each home directory with different 
anonuid and anongid settings (see the exports(5) man page), but I find 
very few good reasons to recommend that course of action.

Honestly, there's no substitute for a consistent uid/gid set across 
hosts. Until there's a common client/server mechanism for agreeing on 
authentication and authorization (NFS v4 maybe?), you'll have to 
suffer with sync-ed passwd files, NIS, or LDAP.

> I also don't want him squashed to anonymous.  Is this a job for NIS?
> or is there an easier way?  (Maybe NIS is easy...)

NIS isn't trivial by any means, but it's not that hard:

  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/NIS-HOWTO/index.html

On a small network, I'd just sync the passwd and shadow files, or 
parts thereof.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Mar 12 11:43:02 2003

>Okay, it's been awhile and I can't find the answer in the places I've
