>Problem is that a directory mounted via fstab (or manually by root) gets a 
>uid/gid that doesn't otherwise exist on the client.  Therefore, no one has 
>access.
>
>Added no_root_squash to prove that my method is otherwise working.  And 
>root can now `ls`, but this is to be for user home dirs.
>
>I understand, that ideally, the user (let's call him `test`) should have 
>the same uid/gid on both machines, but I don't want to do this.  I also 
>don't want him squashed to anonymous.  Is this a job for NIS? or is there 
>an easier way?  (Maybe NIS is easy...)
>
>(From what I gather, automount wouldn't help this problem)

Yes, the user must have the same UID/GID on both machines, or it won't 
work. That's why many (most?) automounting home directory setups use NIS or 
LDAP. With a central user repository, the user automatically gets the same 
UID/GID on any machine they log into.

Automount won't help, because automount would simply be automating the nfs 
mounts, when needed.

Can I ask why you don't want the user to have the same UID/GID on both 
machines? (I suppose I just did, huh?) That would be the easiest option.

Dimension 7/Stargate Online

Sounds like you need to run the network mounts through SAMBA.  It is
very easy to munge uid/gid for each "shared" resource.

I find that samba mounts between linux boxes is pretty stable, even if
the "server" goes down, the mount will usually just work when the
machine comes back up.

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Mar 12 12:39:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Mar 12 12:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To login or to not login?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121141270.23980-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121141270.23980-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1047501549.8098.2521.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 11:43, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I'd greatly appreciate someone passing me a pointer -- by reference will
> do, thank you -- to the differences between login shells and non-login
> shells. When does one want one and not the other?

It's just like it sounds, one type of shell will allow you to login and
interact with it, the other has no login capabilities.  Bash is an
example of a login shell, /dev/null is an extreme example of a non-login
shell.  Debian uses /bin/false as a non-login shell.  This allows the
system to have users that are not allowed to login.  The user that sshd
runs under would be a good candidate for a non-login shell.

When I create a user that will only have ftp access, I change the shell
to /dev/null for that user, ftp still allows login, but no shell will
ever be presented if that user tries to login through ssh (or telnet, if
it is running).

> 
>   The context for this question is that, apparently, Red Hat uses only login

> I'd like to fill.

Not having a RH box handy, I would have to doubt this.  This concept has

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 13:34:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 12 13:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To login or to not login?
In-Reply-To: <1047501549.8098.2521.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121329080.1559-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 12 Mar 2003, Derek Loree wrote:

> On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 11:43, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > I'd greatly appreciate someone passing me a pointer -- by
> > reference will do, thank you -- to the differences between login
> > shells and non-login shells. When does one want one and not the
> > other?
> 
> It's just like it sounds, one type of shell will allow you to login
> and interact with it, the other has no login capabilities.  Bash is
> an example of a login shell, /dev/null is an extreme example of a
> non-login shell.

No. This is not what Rich was asking.

The difference between bash as a login shell and bash as a non-login 
shell has mostly to do with what configuration files it sources at 
start time. The long answer is in the INVOCATION section of the 
bash(1) man page and the 'Startup and shutdown' section of tcsh(1).

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Mar 12 13:35:03 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Mar 12 13:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To login or to not login?
In-Reply-To: <1047501549.8098.2521.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121141270.23980-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1047501549.8098.2521.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1047504863.1894.1133.camel@red>

On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 12:39, Derek Loree wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 11:43, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >   I'd greatly appreciate someone passing me a pointer -- by reference will
> > do, thank you -- to the differences between login shells and non-login
> > shells. When does one want one and not the other?
> 
> It's just like it sounds, one type of shell will allow you to login and
> interact with it, the other has no login capabilities.  Bash is an
> example of a login shell, /dev/null is an extreme example of a non-login
> shell.  Debian uses /bin/false as a non-login shell.  This allows the
> system to have users that are not allowed to login.  The user that sshd
> runs under would be a good candidate for a non-login shell.
> 
> When I create a user that will only have ftp access, I change the shell
> to /dev/null for that user, ftp still allows login, but no shell will
> ever be presented if that user tries to login through ssh (or telnet, if
> it is running).

Now wait. I don't think that's what's meant by a login shell. When
you login to a system, the shell that gets run by the login program
is your login shell. If you later invoke a shell for some other
reason, it's not a login shell. Once you're logged in and at a shell
prompt, enter "bash" or "sh". You've spawned a shell but it's not a
login shell. Some of the scripts that get executed by a login shell
are not executed by a normal invocation of the shell.

Gee, if I'm wrong about this, many of my students will be ticked off.
But, I've been wrong before - there was that time in 68...
-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From danh at fork.com  Wed Mar 12 13:55:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <200303120750.03566.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Wed, 12 Mar 2003, Mark Martin wrote:

> On Wednesday 12 March 2003 07:19, Stephen Liu wrote:
> > Hi all folks,
> >
> > I am searching for a software to remove/uninstall a package which was
> > installed from a tarball.  'make uninstall' can't do the job.
> > [snip]
> >
> There is no one-size-fits-all answer to this question.  Often, you
> must remove all of the installed files manually.

Mark's right. To find out what files were installed and where you may be
able to do the following:

cd into the directory containing your source
make -n install > installation.log

Assuming that goes well, installation.log should contain a listing of
everything make did when it installed your program.

Dan

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Wed Mar 12 14:42:01 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed Mar 12 14:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS Permission Q
In-Reply-To: <1047499723.8153.2462.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <3E6F8AB0.40703@pacifier.com>
    <1047499723.8153.2462.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <E18tEvA-0004Mv-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

On 12 Mar 2003 12:08:43 -0800, Derek Loree said:

> On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 11:29, Kyle Accardi wrote:
>  > Okay, it's been awhile and I can't find the answer in the places I've looked 
>  > (duh).
>  > 
>  > Problem is that a directory mounted via fstab (or manually by root) gets a 
>  > uid/gid that doesn't otherwise exist on the client.  Therefore, no one has 
>  > access.
>  > 
>  > Added no_root_squash to prove that my method is otherwise working.  And root 
>  > can now `ls`, but this is to be for user home dirs.
>  > 
>  > I understand, that ideally, the user (let's call him `test`) should have the 
>  > same uid/gid on both machines, but I don't want to do this.  I also don't 
>  > want him squashed to anonymous.  Is this a job for NIS? or is there an 
>  > easier way?  (Maybe NIS is easy...)
>  > 
>  > (From what I gather, automount wouldn't help this problem)
>  
>  Sounds like you need to run the network mounts through SAMBA.  It is
>  very easy to munge uid/gid for each "shared" resource.

If we are going to propose different solutions, then here is an odd ball, might
be fun to build, might be useless, solution.

For a reason other than it being fun to try something different,  this a graph
of a comparision of the speeds vs NFS

 http://www.it.uc3m.es/ptb/nbd/img2.gif
"These are old figures now - taken under 2.0.36, as I recall, with a much older
version of NBD than the current one, but they're still useful. The testbed was
a pair of 64MB P200s on a 100BT switched circuit using 3c905 NICs. The best
speed I could get out of raw TCP between them was 58.3Mb/s, tested using
netperf. Of course, the current NFS implementations have improved too."


The hard part would be changing the users on the client if they are already in
use. 

1. Users on the clients need to have the uid start at 2000 instead of the usual
user id 500
Change the default in /etc/login.defs if you're setting up new users and then
create the users
To change already working users, log the user out and keep them out. Change the
user id in /etc/passwd and then chown the users directory, and all under it, to
be owned by the user.  

2. Setup a directory structure on the server for the export
Example;
/export/home/username1 
/export/home/username2
/export/home/username3
..

3. Using enbd;	http://www.it.uc3m.es/ptb/nbd/ on the server, set up the
exports using uid of the users as the ports for the export.
Example;

enbd-server 2000 /export/home/username1
enbd-server 2001 /export/home/username2
enbd-server 2002 /export/home/username3


4. On the client,  using enbd module, you would have a script that would mount
the export. 
Something with the minimum;
#!/bin/sh
MODPATH=/lib/modules/2.4.xx/drivers/block
insmod $MODPATH/enbd.o
PORT=`id -u`
enbd-client your.server:$PORT -n 4 /dev/nda 
mount /dev/nda $HOME

Thank you
Russell

From m at pdxlug.org  Wed Mar 12 15:44:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed Mar 12 15:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] making text pretty?
Message-ID: <40519.12.47.207.4.1047512637.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I wrote a shell script that reads a text file of names, addresses, etc.,
and then creates letters that are sent to a printer.  Everything works
perfectly...  except my manager doesn't like the plain text and wants to
use an Arial font and underline certain portions of text.

Is there some way I can pass the output of my script to something that
will make it an Arial font and do other formatting changes, and then
print it?  Is there someway within the plain text to specify what should
be underlined to the receiving program?
Thanks,
~M





From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Mar 12 15:55:03 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Mar 12 15:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] making text pretty?
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBDF7@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

If you know just what printer you're using, you can embed escape codes in
the output to direct it to print as you've asked. Unfortunately, this locks
you into using that brand and model of printer for evermore. Likewise,
there's the problem of having to manually calculate line breaks, since Arial
is a proportionally spaced font.

A little more complex would be to learn PostScript. That, however is a whole
lot of work for such a simple change.

The simplest text formatting engine I know of would be something in the
family of runoff, roff or nroff, where you would embed formatting dotcodes
into your output text and then pipe your format tagged file through the
above-mentioned engine. There are other routines to format dotcoded text
into PostScript.

> man nroff

or 

> apropos nroff

might give you a few valuable clues.

-djp
 
Daniel Petcher
Software QA Tester (contract)
503-264-9011
 
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 16:11:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 12 16:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] making text pretty?
In-Reply-To: <40519.12.47.207.4.1047512637.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303121606041.1559-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 12 Mar 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I wrote a shell script that reads a text file of names, addresses,
> etc., and then creates letters that are sent to a printer.  
> Everything works perfectly...  except my manager doesn't like the
> plain text and wants to use an Arial font and underline certain
> portions of text.

Getting it to print in an Arial-esque typeface isn't a problem; just
use enscript:

  enscript -f Helvetica12 --margins=72:72:72:72 filename.txt

To insert formatting codes, like boldface or underline, you'll likely 
end up using a word processor or spitting it into something like nroff 
or LaTeX.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 20:54:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 12 20:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problem in building RPM package
In-Reply-To: <3E70041C.7010106@icare.com.hk>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303122049080.1559-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 13 Mar 2003, Stephen Liu wrote:

> One further question off my head.  Could I do follows;
> 
> 1) Untar all files from a AAA.tar.gz with
> 
> tar zxvf AAA.tar.gz
> 
> AND
> 
> 2)
> rpmbuild -tb /(directory containting all source files)/*.*  AAA.rpm

No. You need to have a .spec file to build an rpm. It's an absolute 
necessity. If AAA.tar.gz has a working .spec, then

  rpmbuild -tb AAA.tar.gz

will work. Otherwise, you'll have to write your own AAA.spec, make 
sure AAA.tar.gz is in /usr/src/redhat/SOURCES, and do

  rpmbuild -bb AAA.spec

There are, as someone else suggested, some tools available that 
automate the spec-building process -- but the only one I've used at 
all is cpan2rpm, and it works only with Perl CPAN modules.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From felixcatk at attbi.com  Wed Mar 12 22:05:02 2003
From: felixcatk at attbi.com (The Kerstings)
Date: Wed Mar 12 22:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Old hardware and software
Message-ID: <001d01c2e926$4638ecc0$a5aee00c@motherdivine>

Friends,

Here are my two cents on the recent discussion of HB2800 requiring open source systems be considered; I heartily agree - the schools are another major candidate for migration to Linux as well.  I am super impressed with the good work being done thru Multnomah County ESD.  This is one of my inspirations to learn more about Linux and open source software.

But we need to think globally as well - Microsoft is - as seen in todays UN News;

UNESCO TO HOST MEETING ON RECYCLING OBSOLETE COMPUTER EQUIPMENT 

In the search for innovative ways to boost economies and drive development in poor countries, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is set to host an international conference to consider ways to recycle millions of obsolete computers collecting dust in the stock rooms of global corporations. 

Specialists from all over the world - including top executives from Microsoft and Digital Links International - will gather this Friday and Saturday at UNESCO Headquarters in Paris to discuss the recycling of millions of units of computer equipment that become obsolete every year, outstripped by rapid progress in information technology, but which could be extremely useful in developing countries. 

The goal of this first international meeting - "New Synergies for the Recycling of Information Technology Equipment" - is to learn about existing initiatives in the field and to draw up concrete proposals to include in a global strategy for more efficient use of recycled IT material. While computers, printers, scanners, software and servers come with three-year guarantees, many can become obsolete within a year of purchase, and some even within six months. 

Through a survey of 20 global corporations in Europe and the United States, UNESCO has learned that more than one million personal computers will be decommissioned in the next three years. The acquisition cost of these computers was probably more than $1.5 billion, but their residual value is likely to be less than $60 million. The top 100 global companies have an estimated IT stock in excess of 7 million PCs, and the top 1,000 may have more than 30 million. 

Although the immediate benefits of integrating computer equipment recycling processes in sustainable development programmes seem obvious, the prospect does raise a number of important questions. The participants are expected to consider whether this equipment can be used in a different social, economic and cultural context, how to finance the transportation of tons of recycled material, how to avoid conflict with local distributors, and how to guarantee that used technology will not add to pollution problems caused by electronic residue.

Message-ID: <E18tM0Y-0007yX-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I'm not following your question, so if I'm not answering what you asked, I
apologize.

This is what I usually do.
1. untar the tarball
2. run ./configure --help
3. If there isn't anything you need to specify or options you need to change,
run ./configure
4. do a make
5 run checkinstall

This will make a rpm out of the "make install" process and then install the
rpm. This means you can uninstall the rpm and all the files will be removed. 

Thank you
Russell

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Mar 12 23:07:02 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed Mar 12 23:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reading file backward in perl? (Slightly OT) 
In-Reply-To: Message from Alex Daniloff <alex@daniloff.com>

> Could somebody please advise me
> how to read file in perl but backward

>

> while ($line = <FH>) {
> 
>           print $line."\n";

Straight from the camel's mouth, so to speak.  (page 342 of the 2nd ed.)

open FH, "tac file.txt |" or die "Can't fork: $!";
while (<FH>) {
	print;
}
close FH or die "bad tac: $! $?";

galen

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Mar 13 07:46:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Thu Mar 13 07:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reading file backward in perl? (Slightly OT)
References: <mailman.1047536412.31112.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86n0jzxok9.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> writes:

Alex> Could somebody please advise me
Alex> how to read file in perl but backward
Alex> from the bottom to the top.

Alex> Conventional loop

Alex> open (FH "file.txt");
Alex> while ($line = <FH>) {

Alex>           print $line."\n";

Alex> }

Alex> doesn't work in this case.

You can't really "read backwards", because the O/S can't tell
you about line boundaries... your program has to discover that
for itself.

If the data is small enough to fit into memory, just slurp
it in:

    @ARGV = qw(your_filename_here);

    my @data = <>; # slurp it in

    for (reverse @data) { # reverse it
      print $_; # each line
    }

If it's too big to fit into memory, you'll have to read it forward,
note all the start-of-line boundaries, and then read it in chunks
in reverse.  Very easy to get slowly, harder to get fast.

Or, you can use DB_File to map a file to an array, which will sorta do
that for you somewhat automatically.

--

<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Mar 13 07:59:01 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Mar 13 07:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for uninstall solution
In-Reply-To: <3E700237.8080701@icare.com.hk>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0303121346000.9970-100000@cohiba.fork.com> <3E700237.8080701@icare.com.hk>
Message-ID: <200303130941.33270.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Your 3rd attempt seems to have succeeded.  Now you need to look in the file 
installation.log to see what commands the "make install" command executed.  
However, this probably won't help you much until you develop a better 
understanding of how software building and installation works.

By default, the make command uses a file called a make file, which has the 
name Makefile (or makefile), in the current working directory to determine 
what actions to take.  If there is no make file in the current working 
directory, then make will fail stating that there was no rule to make 
whatever target was specified, as it did below for the target "install" in 
your first two attempts.

Target names, such as "install" below, specify which set of commands within 
the file to execute.  Target names are arbitrary and are determined by the 
author of the software.  There are a few commonly used targets, such as 
"install", and automated build tools (such as autoconf and automake) have 
standardized certain targets further.  But make files are not in any way 
required to have specific targets.  This means that there are no universal 
answers to your questions.

Each software package can differ in what it requires for building and 
installation and it is important to read whatever build and installation 
documentation the author or authors have included.  This usually consists of 
files with names like README or INSTALL but can consist of arbitrary files or 
sometimes can be absent altogether.  Software is even ocassionally built 
without using make at all, possibly with scripts or alternatives to make such 
as Cons.  If a piece of software uses make but doesn't include any build 
documentation, you might even have to read the make file directly to 
determine what to do.

Since the build and installation procedures can differ so much for software, 
"uninstall", i.e. removal, procedures also differ widely.  There is no 
universal way to remove a software package and what is required depends on 
what the installation procedure did.

For more information on make, see the make man page or the GNU make manual at

http://www.gnu.org/manual/make/html_chapter/make_toc.html

or read the make man page.

Here are a few words regarding your confusion about tar files and rpm 
packages.  A tar file is an archive that can contain any arbitrary set of 
files (and directories).  Tar files are frequently used to bundle source code 
and documentation together but can be used to bundle together any arbitrary 
set of files.  They are not intended specifically for software distribution 
and were originally developed to facilitate storing files on magnetic tape 
(hence the name tar = tape archive).  Even tar files that contain software do 
not have to contain rpm packages.  In fact, rpm packages are almost never 
found in tar archives.

RPM (Redhat Package Manager) packages provide a different way of bundling 
files (and directories) together that is specifically intended for the 
purpose of building, installing, maintaining, and removing software.  An rpm 
package is a completely different type of archive.  In fact there are 2 types 
of rpm packages, "regular" rpm packages and source rpm packages.  A "regular" 
rpm package contains the binary and supporting files necessary for installing 
a piece of software on specific hardware with specific libraries.  A source 
rpm package contains the source code necessary for building the corresponding 
"regular" rpm package or packages.  Source rpm packages may always be 
**manually** constructed from tar files containing source code.  However, it 
is not always possible to **automatically** construct a source rpm package 
from a tar archive.  Whether or not it is possible to automatically create a 
source rpm file will depend on the specifics of the build process.  If the 
software has a nonstandard build procedure, then automatic creation of a 
source rpm package will not be possible.

On a related topic, rpm packages themselves are not universal either.  
Debian-based systems use deb packages rather than rpm packages.

I suggest that you get a good general Linux programming or systems 
administration (whichever is closer to your interest) book, such as the Linux 
Administration Handbook

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0130084662/qid=1047570347/sr=2-1/ref=sr_2_1/102-8748629-6636168

which has gotten very good reviews.  I'd give you more references but I'm in 
the middle of moving and do not have my books or any more time to spend.

Mark

Here is what works for me.

1) Laptop with <linux distribution> installed 
and a supported modem. 

2) dialup access with local dialup numbers in the place 
you will be needing it, otherwise use a cheap calling card 
and a long distance number.

3) wvdial to establish internet connection

4) ssh into home machine from laptop.

5) scp any files needed.

From pflnetws at yahoo.com  Thu Mar 13 08:54:02 2003
From: pflnetws at yahoo.com (Paul Lankow)
Date: Thu Mar 13 08:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail - local mail delivery problem solved
Message-ID: <20030313165400.92508.qmail@web21201.mail.yahoo.com>

With my new Red Hat 8 installation, I had no problems getting mail in and
out, but local mail would go undelivered. Instead of showing the relay as
"localhost" it would tack on the the domain "localhost.lankow.net" and
resolve that to an external IP. It would time out during the connection,
never deliver the mail.

As soon as I updated Sendmail from 8.12.5 to 8.12.8, the problem vanished.
The relay name returned to localhost, the messages are delivered in the
wink of an eye. I pass that on in case anyone else has the same issue.

Regards,
Paul

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Mar 13 09:00:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)

Before I installed linux at home, I could not get by without shell access at
my ISP. It's now extremely rare that I ssh to shell1 at aracnet. But since I
don't yet run my own mail server, there is still one thing that shell
account does for me. It permits me to get the envelope information and tag
the email with an X-header so that, in spite of fetchmail, I can see to whom
the email was actually sent...


## capture the address that caused delivery (possibly empty if to here)
ENVELOPE_TO="${1:-sandy}"
ENVELOPE_TO=$ENVELOPE_TO at herring.org
:0 fh
|formail -I "X-Envelope-To: $ENVELOPE_TO"
$DEFAULT


(modified recipe thanks to Randal, virtusertable hack thanks to Sean[1] :)

Once I start handling my own MX, my need for a shell account will vanish.
However, I know from reading the local newsgroups that there is a core of
userGeeks who would bail if there were no shell. It's one thing that helps
to set an ISP apart from the mindless morass of aol/earthlink/etc morons.

Sandy

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Mar 13 09:15:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Mar 13 09:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <3F09E1E6D02D804383502AFDC4DE4EC82D0A@cp01.office.wa-net.com>; from ebrock-ml@wa-net.com on Wed, Mar 12, 2003 at 11:06:02PM -0800
References: <3F09E1E6D02D804383502AFDC4DE4EC82D0A@cp01.office.wa-net.com>
Message-ID: <20030313091438.A4646@aracnet.com>

I wouldn't consider any of this critical, but here's what I have found
useful about shell accounts:

- Easy and fast access to my email from anywere on the net. Most ISPs now 
provide a web-based interface to email, but many of these are pretty lame, 
pretty slow, or not on a secure server. The situation is improving, but
for speed and security it's hard to beat ssh->bash->mutt.

- At one time I did my own spam filtering with procmail on my shell 
account, cutting down on what I had to drag through my modem. Now my ISP 
has instituted its own filters, so being able to implement my own filters
is not so critical.

- Lastly and least concrete, it's nice to have a place to call my $HOME
away from $HOME. 24x7 broadband is not available where I live and probably
won't be for many years if ever. So I don't have ssh/scp access to my 
box at home. My ISP shell account is a "place for my stuff" (ack to George 
Carlin) when I'm cut off from my real $HOME.

If I ever did get 24x7 ssh/scp access to my home PC from the Internet,
then I'd be hard pressed to find any remaining uses for my ISP shell
account.

Terry

From fixin at peak.org  Thu Mar 13 10:41:02 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Thu Mar 13 10:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <20030313141402.8274.89375.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>; from plug-request@lists.pdxlinux.org on Thu, Mar 13, 2003 at 06:14:02AM -0800
References: <20030313141402.8274.89375.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20030313104029.A920@tpol.peak.org>

> I'm a System Admin for an ISP here in the Portland Area, small but
> locally owned.  In my humble opinion that lends itself to have it's
> fair share of pros and cons.  Over that past nine years we've been
> in business we for a very brief amount of time offered shell access.
> While I wouldn't mind opening our system back up to our customers to
> provide shell access, my question is, is there really a desire for
> it anymore or am I just such a geek with the command line that I'm
> out of touch? :) As far as security goes, I know how to lock down my
> servers so there really shouldn't be an issue but is the ruling
> opinion that - mostly people that want to cause havoc are the ones
> who will use a shell or is there really still a demand for such a
> service?  I would love to know what people think and what
> specifically they think they'd use it for.

The way I read and filter mail and manage my web sites (plus stuff I
can't think of :-) require shell access.  I use procmail to forward
mail, reply automatically, run it through scripts to gather
statistics, etc.  Some of my static web pages are generated, or need
to be edited frequently, and while I could do that on another machine
and upload the results it's much easier to just 'cd public_html; make
site'.

Also, having an ISP I trust (and know isn't running Windoze :-)
professionally maintaining security around their site lets me keep
that account as an entrance to the servers I run at home (since I
travel a lot and am frequently sshing in from new locations).  If I
opened them up to the world at large I'd have to pay a lot more
attention to securing them than I have time for.

That said, without shell access at an ISP I'd simply configure a home
system to do what I now do there.  But I'm not excited about running
my own mail and web servers and all the rest.

--Eric House

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Mar 13 10:55:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Mar 13 10:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] stupid shell question
In-Reply-To: <000c01c2e98f$37bd1950$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
References: <20030311181935.W89427@grond.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030313104814.01ae64c8@localhost>

At 10:34 AM 3/13/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>I suppose PS1=xxxxxx isn't a command per se, but I was under the
>impression I could use it to change my prompt.

No it's not, but yes, you can. :)

The PS1 part is an environment variable, not a command. The command used to 
"install" environment variables is "set" or "export". Use "man set" or "man 
export" for more information on those two.

The "xxxxxx" part is the value you are placing in the PS1 environment 
variable.

I hope that helps.


Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Dear PLUGers,

We would have mentioned this last month, but didn't want to disrupt the
timing of the last PLUG meeting (PDXLUG had their first meeting the same
night...) and we wanted to test the process internally first.

We are working on a few group projects for the Portland Linux User Group 
(PDXLUG) community and would like to extend our efforts to all of you here
at PLUG. We have setup an online library using an opensource web app to
manage/track books that we are sharing with each other. At our monthly
meetings we are lending books to each other based on the requested books
that people have reserved throughout the month before. We currently have
over 115 book titles in our online library and many more are being added
on a regular basis as people find time to add their book titles to the
database.

If you're interested, stop by http://library.pdxlug.org/ and you can demo
it with user: guest pass: guest

If you want an account, please email me with the following:
desired username:

email address:

Thanks,

Robby Russell

>  
> > 3) wvdial to establish internet connection
> 
>   Connection established with whom? AFAIK, I need to dial into an
> established 'Net node. I cannot have the dialer call an IP address, can I?

That's correct, but there's a difference between dial-up internet
access and shell access. Most ISPs these days will not allow you to
dial-up and gain shell access. Once you log in a PPP link is immediately
established. I presume this is because the demand for a shell account
is so low it's not worth whatever extra effort it might take. At least,
that's my understanding. :-)


Paul

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Mar 13 13:43:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Mar 13 13:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86vfynq6z4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich> I guess that I've been missing something here. Unless I have a shell
Rich> account, to what am I connecting via ppp when I call the ISP's phone number?
Rich> Don't I want a system prompt so I can then ssh to my network?

You have a "shell prompt" on the system you are dialing from.  Once
you have an IP connection to your ISP, slogin (or whatever) to the
system on your office network.

                                      ------
   +--------+        +-------+      (        )    +---------+
   | remote +~~~~~~~~+  ISP  +-----( internet )---+ office  |
   +--------+        +-------+      (        )    +---------+
                                      ------

You dial-in from the remote system to your ISP over a modem.  ISP
gives you an IP number.  You run slogin on remote system, connecting
it to the IP number at your office.  Everything just works.

Or was there something complicated?

From barryb at proaxis.com  Thu Mar 13 13:44:01 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Thu Mar 13 13:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, Mar 13, 2003 at 01:20:12PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   I guess that I've been missing something here. Unless I have a shell
> account, to what am I connecting via ppp when I call the ISP's phone number?
> Don't I want a system prompt so I can then ssh to my network?
> 

You use the shell prompt on your laptop to do the ssh.

To further expand on my previous post,

It's fairly easy these days to get an ISP who will give you a list of numbers
nationwide where you can get local access. 

Large ISP's have their own numbers in many cities, but smaller ISP's and even
the bigger ones buy numbers from dialup wholesalers like
http://usbackbone.net/
or even qwest
http://www.qwest.com/wholesale/pcat/wholesaledial.html

For instance locally, Pacifier has national numbers
http://www.pacifier.com/dialup/index.php

and Coho says they offer nationwide dialup
http://www.coho.net/PnSChoice.htm

Then there are the large ISP's like Earthlink who
have their own numbers nationwide and they also
resell wholesale numbers.
http://support.earthlink.net/support/ACCESS/

I am sure there are others.

Just make sure that the places you normally go 
are covered and that the
numbers in those cities are not overbooked. i.e
you constantly get a busy signal. It can't hurt 
as a precaution before choosing a provider to 
just pick up the phone, dial one of the numbers
you are interested in and see if it is busy.

Bill Barry

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Mar 13 13:46:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Mar 13 13:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20030313211029.GA554@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030313134010.00b74848@localhost>

At 01:20 PM 3/13/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>I guess that I've been missing something here. Unless I have a shell
>account, to what am I connecting via ppp when I call the ISP's phone number?
>Don't I want a system prompt so I can then ssh to my network?

If you log in and get a system prompt on the other machine, then you don't 
have a PPP connection. PPP is "Point to Point Protocol" and is used to make 
a (usually) network connection between two computers. When you log in and 
get a system prompt, you aren't making a "network" connection. You are 
(again, usually) using a terminal program to gain access to the remote system.


Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Subject: [PLUG] Weird "PortScans"

Ok, I can't hold my peace any longer.
The webserver I administer is showing some strange behavior.
I installed SNORT on the firewall to help protect it's poor little IIS/Windows
2000 self, and one of the first things I noticed was that SNORT reported many
portscans -outbound- from "port 80" of our computer, all over the map for other
computers. 
So I firewalled off port 80 outbound (here's the iptables rule, to doublecheck
my work)

INTADDR=the internal (192.168...) IP address of the firewall (the default route
of the webserver)
WEBSERVER=the internal (192.168...) IP address of the webserver

/sbin/iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $INTADDR -p tcp -s $WEBSERVER --sport 80
-j DROP

Patches appear to be up to date on the Win2K server, but... evidence is to the
contrary.  I installed Symantec's AntiVirus package; it's running, checking- it
finds nothing, even after a reboot when I expect it to find something on the MBR
and in the registry.

The only open ports on our webserver now are 20,21,80,443 and the PcAnywhere
port; they're NAT'd thru the firewall, while the ssh port goes to the firewall.

Today, we logged in to do some other work, and we happened to open up
netwatcher- and there are many many connections between our port 80 and one
dialup computer, on many many sequential ports on the dialup computer.  IE it
looks like either our server is continuing to scan other computers or that
dialup computer is doing something weird from many many ports all to port 80
(not completely unreasonable) -- that snort is reporting as a portscan from our
server.

If that doesn't make sense, it's because it doesn't make sense to me. 
Can anyone shed some light on this?

From pem at nellump.net  Thu Mar 13 14:53:01 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Thu Mar 13 14:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20030313211029.GA554@nellump.net> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303131318500.27875-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030313225315.GA829@nellump.net>

On Thu, Mar 13, 2003 at 01:20:12PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   I guess that I've been missing something here. Unless I have a shell
> account, to what am I connecting via ppp when I call the ISP's phone number?
> Don't I want a system prompt so I can then ssh to my network?

This is my understanding: When you dial-up to your ISP, your dialer
program is met with a login/password prompt, and shortly after
authentication a PPP daemon is spawned that takes over the connection
and sets up an IP link to the ISP's host. After that, you effectively
have a direct connection to the ISP's network, which means you have
direct access to the Internet. It does not mean that you can login to
any of the ISP's servers and get a shell. You can, though, start up a
shell on your local machine and then use that to ssh into the remote
host of your choice (assuming you have an account on it).

When you dial-up to an ISP account that *does* provide shell access, you
never set up an IP connection between your local machine and the ISP's
host. The only connection you have is through your terminal app. You
could not, AFAIK, start up a local web browser and expect anything to
happen.

Anyhow... That's what I know. Corrections and clarifications welcomed.
:-)


Paul

The notion that when you dial up to an ISP that does provide shell
access you will never setup an IP connection is in my view false.  We
run 4 different access servers that handle the modem connections via IP.
When I originally posted my question I was talking about basically
handing the user control over their twenty megs of space so they could
from SSH edit PHP, or setup their mail, or do whatever they wanted
really.  I would be highly interested in what hardware an ISP would
still be using that gave a terminal right when the user dialed in.  That
seems like something that is pre '97 Internet if you know what I mean.
I remember dialing up before PPP got popular on the Internet and getting
right into the shell, but that was a LONG time ago, and it just so turns
out the ISP I was a customer of then I run now :)  Go figure...

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Paul Mullen
Sent: Thursday, March 13, 2003 2:53 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?

On Thu, Mar 13, 2003 at 01:20:12PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   I guess that I've been missing something here. Unless I have a shell
> account, to what am I connecting via ppp when I call the ISP's phone
number?
> Don't I want a system prompt so I can then ssh to my network?

This is my understanding: When you dial-up to your ISP, your dialer
program is met with a login/password prompt, and shortly after
authentication a PPP daemon is spawned that takes over the connection
and sets up an IP link to the ISP's host. After that, you effectively
have a direct connection to the ISP's network, which means you have
direct access to the Internet. It does not mean that you can login to
any of the ISP's servers and get a shell. You can, though, start up a
shell on your local machine and then use that to ssh into the remote
host of your choice (assuming you have an account on it).

When you dial-up to an ISP account that *does* provide shell access, you
never set up an IP connection between your local machine and the ISP's
host. The only connection you have is through your terminal app. You
could not, AFAIK, start up a local web browser and expect anything to
happen.

Anyhow... That's what I know. Corrections and clarifications welcomed.
:-)


Paul

I'm going to skip all of Rob's regurgitation of the "justification" for
war that you can read in any mainstream newspaper or see on CNN.  However,
I'll note that they're all about Saddam Hussein and the regime in Iraq
and, therefore, show total ignorance of the situation and why the U.S. is
involved.

> Many of them also seem to think they have a better understanding of the
> situation than those with actual power to act.

I have the same understanding as "those with actual power to act" (though
I would also claim to be a person with some power to act).  They told us
all about what they wanted and why they want it.

There's an organization founded largely by those in power today (Cheney,
Rumsfeld, Khalilzad, Jeb Bush, etc.) called the Project For The New
American Century (PNAC) that released a report in September 2000 (!!)
entitled "Rebuilding America's Defenses: Strategy, Forces and Resources
For a New Century".  The report is available as a PDF here:
<URL: http://www.newamericancentury.org/publicationsreports.htm >

It's fairly safe to say that this is the opinion and strategy of the
people in power today.

The report is shockingly frank and straightforward and describes a world
domination plan where U.S. military and economic control is unchallenged
and U.S. dependence is mandatory for a nation to survive.

One of the most shocking aspects of this report is that it's ostensibly
about U.S. defenses, but concerns itself primarily with reshaping foreign
nations to align themselves with the ideals of the authors.  The unstated
truth being that the state they evision cannot stand up to fair economic
competition.

Anyway, it's an interesting read and I recommend anyone interested in
seeing the world from the point of view of the hawks in office go ahead
and take the time to page through the report.

For the purposes of this discussion, there is the following section from
the report (Section III:  Repositioning Today's Force):

"Indeed, the United States has for decades sought to play a more permanent
role in Gulf regional security.  While the unresolved conflict with Iraq
provides the immediate justification, the need for a substantial American
force presence in teh Gulf transcends the issue of the regime of Saddam
Hussein."

In other words, this has nothing to do with the Iraqi people and
everything to do with building up U.S. forces in the Gulf region
permanently.

"Although Saudi domestic sensibilities demand that the forces based in the
Kingdom nominally remain rotational forces, it has become apparent that
this is now a semi-permanent mission.  From an American perspective, the
value of such bases would endure even should Saddam Hussein pass from the
scene.  Over the long term, Iran may well prove as large a threat to U.S.
interests in teh Gulf as Iraq has.  And even should U.S.-Iranian relations
improve, retaining forward-based forces in the region would still be an
essential element in U.S. security strategy given the longstanding
American interests in the region."

This is about "American interests in the region" and not at all about
democracy and freedom for the Iraqi people.  It's not about improving
their lives or their standard of living.  It's about setting up permant
bullying stations around the world to beat the living shit out of anyone
who threatens anything on the planet that the United States might possible
want to claim for itself.

> They know things that haven't been released to the public for security
> reasons... but we know better, for sure.

Do you think that Microsoft's claim that source code was not released for
"security reasons" is valid?  It's no more valid here, sir.

There is no secret information withheld for security reasons.  The UK
report that claimed to be suppressed for security reasons turned out to be
plagiarized from a graduate student thesis, misspellings and all.

As a user of Free and merely Open Source software, you should realize that
no security is gained from secrecy.  It's an excuse.

They need the veil of secret organizations so they can do whatever they
want and pretend to have secret information to justify it.

As any sysadmin will tell you, security through obscurity is no security
at all.

Open government for a Free world.

a few megs in $HOME.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Mar 14 01:25:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri Mar 14 01:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ISP shell access still in demand?
In-Reply-To: <3F09E1E6D02D804383502AFDC4DE4EC82D0A@cp01.office.wa-net.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303132041240.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Wed, 12 Mar 2003, Eric Brockman wrote:

> I'm a System Admin for an ISP here in the Portland Area, small but
> locally owned.  In my humble opinion that lends itself to have it's fair
> share of pros and cons.  Over that past nine years we've been in
> business we for a very brief amount of time offered shell access.  While
> I wouldn't mind opening our system back up to our customers to provide
> shell access, my question is, is there really a desire for it anymore or
> am I just such a geek with the command line that I'm out of touch? :)

(Returning to the original question.)

My opinion about your question is a qualified yes. Yes, in that there is
a small, but determined & usually clueful, group who want shell access.
At times, it is valuable to have an account on another host to troubleshoot
network problems, fiddle with procmail configurations, temporarily
store files, & lots of other occasional chores that make shell access
invaluable.

However, the vast majority of users could care less about this feature,
although a few might insist on having shell access vehemently, while
never using it & probably not know if their home account was set to
/dev/null & their shell to /bin/echo.

My advice is to offer it as an ``unadvertised special." There's a few
of us who will need it, & will ask for it -- & be grateful that you
offer it. The rest of your customers won't care.

Geoff

> Okay, so the user `test` can mount his home dir from a client machine.  The 
> goal was to have two concurrent X desktop sessions running that share common 
> data--bookmarks, mail, dotfiles, everything really.

You have to realize by now, that it is impossible for two different
users to use the _same_ X desktop independant of each other, that is a
contridiction in terms.  This would be almost like two operating systems
trying to share the same swap space.
> 
> I was afraid this would happen--mozilla doesn't want to play that game.  It 
> sees that it already has a lock and forces me to create a new profile which 
> seems unable to share bookmarks (not sure about mail yet) with the other 
> profile.

The only way two people can access the same locked files at the same
time is to "share" the X desktop.  The Linux Journal had an article
about this very topic, "Sometimes, You Have to Do It Yourself".  The KDE
Desktop Sharing package is supposed to be in KDE 3.1, or if you are
running KDE 3.0 go to http://www.tjansen.de/krfb  The only tricky part
looks like the path to KDE is not the same for each distribution,
configure with the --prefix=<path to KDE> before doing the make.

It sounds like this is the same type of thing that happens when a
vncserver is run from Windows, where the remote connection is just a
fully controllable mirror of the "real" X desktop, but there is only one
focus, which either person can control.


Good Luck

Derek Loree

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri Mar 14 15:07:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Mar 14 15:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Add a hard drive without rebooting?
Message-ID: <1047683158.1673.13.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

Hey everybody-

I just got a new hard drive for the server.  I'd like to, if at all
possible, install the drive without rebooting.

I understand Linux uses the BIOS only to get booted, then from there on
out, it pretty much ignores it and does its own thing as far as drives
are concerned.

Could I thereby just plug in a drive and somehow get Linux to find the
drive or am I going to need to reboot?

If I reboot the computer, I'm going to need to pull it out of the closet
and plug in a monitor, as the BIOS battery is shot.  That and I'd lose
my 159 day uptime.  :-)

It's an IDE drive, all IDE system, an FIC SD11 board, Via 686A
southbridge, AMD Irongate northbridge.  The second channel is not used,
the only IDE device in there is the current harddrive, and it's primary
master.

Anybody ever tried it before?  :-)

Rob

On 14 Mar 2003, AthlonRob wrote:

> I just got a new hard drive for the server.  I'd like to, if at all
> possible, install the drive without rebooting.

Rob,

  I'm not a hardware engineer but I've dealt with electronics and
electricity since about 1957. You risk blowing the entire box by taking off
a side and plugging in power cables while it's running. The slightest slip
and you've created a short -- at the very least.

  Uptime is nice -- for a stable system. It demonstrates that the server did
not need to be periodically rebooted just because. A deliberate shutdown for
hardware changes does not emasculate your manhood. Think of it as shutting
off your vehicle engine before refueling.

Rich

From dgc at easystreet.com  Fri Mar 14 15:58:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Fri Mar 14 15:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Add a hard drive without rebooting?
Message-ID: <20030314235729.118AEB3BF6@dsl-209-162-216-78.dsl.easystreet.com>

I have seen a command on my various travels around the web that tells the
linux ide driver to rescan busses, which is what you'd need to do a hotplug in
of a new drive.  There were MAJOR warning though on that web page that it
is extremely dangerous to use.  I don't remember the specific url but you
could probably google for it.

But I'd go along with the other comments that electrically it's very 
dangerous.  There are special connectors used in hardware that allows hot
plugins / changing / etc.  You do not see those connectors in a normal
"pc" motherboard.

dgc

> 
> The thought was to export my home directory which lives on the basement 
> workstation to my laptop.  Would work fine if X wasn't a requirement.

I think Synergy would be a better solution.  It is a "software" KVM,
from another article in the Linux Journal
(sourceforge.net/progects/synergy2).  With the server running on one
machine (your laptop), and a client running on another machine (your
basement box), you can configure it so that if you slide the mouse off
of the desktop of the server, in a particular direction, it switches to
the desktop of the client.  Of course, to get back to the laptop, you
have to have the server running on the basement box, so that when you
slide the mouse off the desktop, it goes back to the laptop's desktop.

HTH

Derek Loree

On Fri, 2003-03-14 at 15:05, AthlonRob wrote:

> I just got a new hard drive for the server.  I'd like to, if at all
> possible, install the drive without rebooting.

Thanks, everybody, for the tips, hacks, and warnings...

I booted the system three times and am now on the new hard drive has
totally replaced the old.

Powered down, put in new drive as hdc.  Powered up and moved everything
over.  Powered down.  Unplugged old drive, plugged new drive in as hda. 
Put in tomsrtbt floppy.  Powered up, chroot'd into new drive, and ran
lilo.  Removed floppy and rebooted.  Now I'm here, everything seems to
have made it over ok.  :-)

rob at linuxbox:~$ df -h
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/hda1             3.7G  1.2G  2.3G  34% /
/dev/hda2              18G  174M   17G   1% /home
/dev/hda4              14G  930M   12G   7% /usr/local

Life is good!  That's up from a 3.5GB Maxtor that had to have been close
to seven years old.  $65 after mail-in rebate.  7200 RPM drive.  Rob is
happy!  :-)

Rob

In-Reply-To: <1047679320.8703.23.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

I've been having this problem where my network gets slow (and ping drops a
lot of packets) after 3-4 days.
I found that if I rebooted the machine that does the IP masquerading that
the problem clears up.  Tonight I tried restarting the network script on
that machine as opposed to rebooting ( #init.d/network restart) and that
did the trick.  Prior to this I was looking for traffic with tcpdump, but
didn't find anything all that interesting (I was thinking that I'd find
that something was sending a lot of data around but I didn't notice
anything unusual).

Any ideas why I would need to restart the network script on this
machine every few days?

Phil




From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri Mar 14 23:28:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Mar 14 23:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network gets slow after a few days...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303142253100.3404-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303142253100.3404-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1047713216.4578.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Fri, 2003-03-14 at 23:03, Phil Tomson wrote:

> Any ideas why I would need to restart the network script on this
> machine every few days?

What kind of network card is it?  When you restart the network scripts,
I think you reinitialize the NIC... and some NICs (I hear the earlier
revisions of the 8139, for example) tend to poop out after a few gigs of
transfers.

A hack/workaround might be a cron job that restarts the network every
two days around 0300 or so, if that's a possibility, anyway.

Rob

From launi at zaramyth.net  Sat Mar 15 12:31:02 2003
From: launi at zaramyth.net (Launi)
Date: Sat Mar 15 12:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IDE RAID and Linux
Message-ID: <000b01c2eb31$a9219370$f800a8c0@launi.com>

*** 
I did a search on the archives (http://plug.skylab.org/cgi-bin/htsearch) and
found nothing for IDE RAID.
***

I'm going to build a replacement Linux server for one of my aging servers
and want to do RAID 5.  I have done hardware SCSI RAID on Window$ so I know
how it works in principle.  I have never done software IDE RAID before.  I
have a few questions before I get started that may save me aggravation later
on. I understand that the Linux 2.4.x kernel supports software RAID and I
also know that in order to get the best performance you need your IDE drives
on one channel.  I want RAID 5 with one hot spare using 5 identical 72 GB
drives.

I'm open to using any Linux distribution that will make this work.  I have
used RedHat, Mandrake and Debian in the past.

 1. Can I just have my 4 IDE drives connected to two separate two channel
PCI IDE controllers and Linux will recognize them during startup?
 2. If I do buy a 4 channel controller (Rocket Raid 404) which does not
support RAID 5 via hardware, will Linux support it using software?
 3. Should I only use the controllers listed here
(http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Hardware-HOWTO/ideraid.html)?
 4. If I'm not concerned about performance can I use one 2 channel PCI IDE
controller and connect the four drives (two on each channel)?


Basic RAID configuration questions
 
 1. If I use Linux software RAID without a hardware driver should I boot off
a single disk and then make RAID for just my data?
 2. If I have hardware RAID with Linux driver support can I install directly
on the RAID?

I'm on a budget and this is a home business system so that I can store my
clients graphic work.  If I can use one PCI card with 4 ATA controllers on
it at a cost of $100 then this would be ideal.  If I have to go with a
higher end SX6000 or Escalade 7500-4 ATA 133 RAID Controller Card then I
would have to spend about $300.  I'll spend the money if that's what it
takes to work, but I wanted to use Linux software RAID and did not want to
have to deal with third party hardware drivers.

Lonnie Wormley

From dcf at aracnet.com  Sat Mar 15 16:48:01 2003
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sat Mar 15 16:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] stupid shell question
In-Reply-To: <000c01c2e98f$37bd1950$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
References: <000c01c2e98f$37bd1950$7729e00c@w2c6z6>
Message-ID: <20030315163406.F264@grond.sourballs.org>

> I suppose PS1=xxxxxx isn't a command per se, but I was under the
> impression I could use it to change my prompt.  I am not sure where it
> is located as a file, but according to what I have read, typing the new
> prompt would return the changes, albeit temporarily for that session.

I think the problem here is shell confusion - mixing commands between tcsh
and bash.  To change the prompt in bash, try 'export PS1=my_new_prompt'.

> I added an alias to my .bashrc file where I found other aliases and it
> never worked.  It always returned a 'command not found' error.  I
> thought that I could also type this at the prompt to create an alias for
> the session.

Look in the bash man page, under the INVOCATION section.  A login shell
reads /etc/profile, ~/.bash_login, ~/.bash_profile, and ~/.profile, in
that order, if they exist - a non-login, but interactive shell will read
~/.bashrc.

--
David Fleck
dcf at aracnet.com

that my sources.list file still points to
sources.list.freegeek.  I thought that meant I would need
to take my computer to FreeGeek to use apt-get unless I
learned how to redirect sources.list to my
sources.list.public file, so I posted a question about that
at www.debian.org.  Then I started thinking that I should
backup as much of my filesystem as I could before making
any changes.  I don't have the FreeGeek software on CD, but
Hunger's book included a CD for 2.2, so I suppose I would
be able to install that and then upgrade and restore my
backed up files.

I don't have any media for a backup other than floppies and
a hard drive of about 500MB that was originally in my W95
computer, so I've been thinking of installing the hard
drive as a slave for partial backups.  

So far about all I've done is start to become more familiar
with my online documentation and the software that is
already on my machine.  I thought it would be a good idea
to use dmesg | less to look at the output of the startup
process and try to learn more about what it all means. 
Rather than write it all down I wanted to print it to my
LaserJet 4L, but I don't know how to do that yet.

So my first question to you folks is: how can I print a
hard copy of whatever is on the screen in a text terminal? 
I know that in Windows there is a way to print a snapshot
of whatever is on the screen.  Is there a way to do that
with Debian when I am using a GUI too?

To istall the slave and use it for partial backups what
steps should I take after it has been physically installed?
       Will I need to change my BIOS settings?  Will I need
to partition and format the drive?

When I first brought the computer home I had a Princeton
Graphics Ultra 17" monitor.  That monitor seemed to be
about to burn out so I traded up to a Gateway 2000 17"
monitor.  However, the Monitor section of my
/etc/Xll/XF86Config-4 file still lists the Princeton
monitor and it's refresh rates.  My monitor seems to work
okay, but I would like to have the correct information in
the XF86Config-4 file.  What would be the best way to do
that?  Would running XF86Setup allow me to just enter the
information that I want to change, or would I have to
re-enter the configuration information for the whole
system?

I will stop asking questions for now and look forward to
getting to know you better.  I hope this hasn't been to
lenghty or too many questions for a first post.
Alan

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Mar 15 18:16:01 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat Mar 15 18:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS exported home & mozilla/X
References: <3E721D9C.20805@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3E73DE1E.5000409@pacifier.com>

Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Okay, so the user `test` can mount his home dir from a client machine.  
> The goal was to have two concurrent X desktop sessions running that 
> share common data--bookmarks, mail, dotfiles, everything really.


Found a solution: close the unused mozilla & vncviewer.  Don't need nfs at all.

The March Linux Magazine has a cool article on how to make xdmcp listen to a 
local vnc server so that from any machine on the lan I can type `vncviewer 
my_host` and get a gdm (or kdm or xdm) login screen.  Avoids the extra steps 
normally required and you can make multiple resolutions available.  gdm/kdm 
allow you to select a more appropiate wm than sawfish (pokey even over 
100Mb) before logging in.

The article isn't available on their website for a few more months, but I'd 
be happy to summarize the steps if anyone's interested.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi





From steve at wirex.net  Sat Mar 15 19:19:01 2003
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Sat Mar 15 19:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IDE RAID and Linux (revisions)
In-Reply-To: <001a01c2eb41$d0a2d890$f800a8c0@launi.com>
References: <001a01c2eb41$d0a2d890$f800a8c0@launi.com>
Message-ID: <20030316031758.GA26057@wirex.net>

Hey Launi,

I'm going to preface my response by saying that I've only used software
raid (on ide) under linux, not hardware ide raid (though I've seen
others I work with beat their heads against the wall with hardware raid
driver issues).

On Sat, Mar 15, 2003 at 02:25:36PM -0800, Launi wrote:
> I'm going to build a replacement Linux server for one of my aging servers
> and want to do RAID 5.  I have done hardware SCSI RAID on Window$ so I know
> how it works in principle.  I have never done software IDE RAID before.  I
> have a few questions before I get started that may save me aggravation later
> on. I understand that the Linux 2.4.x kernel supports software RAID and I
> also know that in order to get the best performance you need your IDE drives
> on one channel each.  I want RAID 5 with one hot spare using 4 identical 72
> GB drives.

To be pedantic, the 2.2 linux kernels also support software RAID, which
is what I'm using. My understanding is that the software RAID format is
the same between 2.2 and 2.4, but don't know about 2.5 (I know there's
been drastic changes in the LVM stuff, not sure how it's affected
software RAID).

> I'm open to using any Linux distribution that will make this work.  I have
> used RedHat, Mandrake and Debian in the past.

AFAIK, they all will make it work. On the other hand, I have no idea
how well the installers handle it -- I set mine up manually long after
install time, as I was adding a mirror drive for a system without backing
up and reinstalling -- I had no backup device that could store the
amount of data reasonably.

>  1. Can I just have my 4 IDE drives connected to two separate two
> channel PCI IDE controllers and Linux will recognize them during
> startup?

I believe so, my raid 1 setup is two drives, one on each channel of the
ide controller. 

> 2. If I do buy a 4 channel controller (Rocket Raid 404) which does
> not support RAID 5 via hardware, will Linux support it using software?

Likely so (modulo my inexperience with hardware raid). Essentially you'd
be using it as a straight 4 channel ide controller, no raid as far as
the hardware device is concerned. 

> 3. Should I only use the controllers listed here
> (http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Hardware-HOWTO/ideraid.html)?

Dunno. You probably should also look at what the distribution you plan
on using supports for hardware raid, if that's the way you decide to go.

>  4. If I'm not concerned about performance can I use one 2 channel PCI IDE
> controller and connect the four drives (two on each channel)?

In software raid, I'm almost certain it will. All it looks at are the
block devices you give it, I don't think it has any meta knowledge about
them. You likely could be able to mirror across a mix of scsi, ide, cf
or other random devices, assuming they present themselves as block
devices (not having tried it, I don't this for sure, but it seems like
it). 

> Basic RAID configuration questions
>  
>  1. If I use Linux software RAID without a hardware driver should I boot off
> a single disk and then make RAID for just my data?  

You can, but you don't have to, you can have the root partition on raid
as well (I do this).  You will have to use an initrd (ram disk) with the
software raid modules (md) in it or have a kernel with software raid
compiled in so that the kernel has access to the software raid driver
before any of the file systems have been mounted.

> 2. If I have hardware
> RAID with Linux driver support can I install directly on the RAID?

Yes, I believe so.

> I'm on a budget and this is a home business system so that I can store my
> clients graphic work.  If I can use one PCI card with 4 ATA controllers on
> it at a cost of $100 then this would be ideal.  If I have to go with a
> higher end SX6000 or Escalade 7500-4 ATA 133 RAID Controller Card then I
> would have to spend about $300.  I'll spend the money if that's what it
> takes to work, but I wanted to use Linux software RAID and did not want to
> have to deal with third party hardware drivers.

I've been very happy with linux's software raid, though I've not had a
disk failure -- I did have to run in a failed configuration for a while
while I was moving my data from non-raid to raid. Personally, I'd lean
towards a raid 0+1 (or is it 1+0 that's the better of the two? I never
remember) if I had four disks and was willing to give up some space,
but that's just me.

Hope this helps.

-- 
Steve Beattie                               Don't trust programmers?
<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
http://www.personaltelco.net -- overthrowing QWest, one block at a time.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sat Mar 15 19:35:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sat Mar 15 19:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS exported home & mozilla/X
In-Reply-To: <1047785100.11895.5.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <3E721D9C.20805@pacifier.com> <3E73DE1E.5000409@pacifier.com> <1047785100.11895.5.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <20030316033416.GA28443@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> > Found a solution: close the unused mozilla & vncviewer.  Don't need nfs at all.
> 
> Same would apply to email, just close it before going downstairs, the
> hard part will be remembering to close it again when you go back
> upstairs.

Just put a "killall <program_name>" in a login script, or make aliases
that do this on a per-program basis:

ie: alias mozilla="killall mozilla-bin && mozilla"

This is basically what I do with mutt (I don't kill it, my alias just
displays the mutt processes I own if it's running, incase I just
forgot what desktop it's on).

This seems like a pretty rough hack though. Especially with something
like Mozilla, I routinely keep browser windows open for months at a
time while I wait for time to look at the page I left them on, so
killing moz. would axe all these.

I've heard rumors about gnome2.2 (metacity?) being able to move an app
from one desktop to another. Am I hallucinating or is this more than
rumor?

-Rogan

On Sunday 16 March 2003 11:22 am, Launi wrote:
> Your input helps, thanks. I'm going to going to buy one more SIIG IDE 2
> channel controller and start putting the hardware together.  I'll then
> start the install and try software Raid 5.

A word of warning about ATA RAID: some controllers do not handle disk 
failure gracefully.  So while your data will be fine, do not expect your 
machine to stay up if a drive fails.  Specifically, I've heard this about 
the Promise cards.  I've heard very good things about 3ware, BTW.  And 
most (all?) RAID controllers will allow you to turn off RAID and do it 
all in software.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Mar 15 22:28:01 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat Mar 15 22:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] vnc/xdmcp logins
Message-ID: <3E74195D.2000602@pacifier.com>

Reference: Linux Magazine March 2003, "Simplififying Remote VNC Logins"

Required: vnc installed on server and client/s

My instructions for gdm on RH 7.3


Edit /etc/X11/gdm/gdm.conf

[xdmcp]
enable=true

---------------

Edit /etc/services, add

#resolutions you want
vnc-800x600	5900/tcp
vnc-1024x768	5901/tcp

---------------

Create /etc/xinetd.d/vnc-800x600

service vnc-800x600
{
	disable		= no
	socket_type	= stream
	protocol	= tcp
	wait		= no
	user		= nobody
	server		= /usr/bin/Xvnc
	server_args	= :1 -inetd -query localhost -geometry 790x572 -depth 16 -once 
-fp unix/:7100
}


Do this for each service you've added.  I knocked down the geometry to allow 
room for the window border.  If you use more than one resolution, increment 
the display number in server_args for each.  Use :2, :3 etc

---------------

Log out of X and restart.  Also restart xinetd.  ie. `service xinetd restart`

To check from the server itself, in an Xterm `vncviewer localhost`
If that works, try from a client: `vncviewer <hostname>`

Still working on adding to the wm selection from gdm.  There's more covered 
in the article that I've skipped, mainly firewall rules and kdm/xdm.
The mag should be available at your favorite Fred Meyers.

--
Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

vnc-800x600x8   stream  tcp     nowait  nobody.tty      /usr/bin/X11/Xvnc Xvnc -inetd -query localhost -once -geometry 800x600 -depth 8
vnc-800x600x16  stream  tcp     nowait  nobody.tty      /usr/bin/X11/Xvnc Xvnc -inetd -query localhost -once -geometry 800x600 -depth 16
vnc-1024x768x16 stream  tcp     nowait  nobody.tty      /usr/bin/X11/Xvnc Xvnc -inetd -query localhost -once -geometry 1024x768 -depth 16

> generous at the time, but now I have less than 3GB of
> free space.
> 
> Could I move /home onto another partition? (Such an
> unused partition is available on my system.) I could
> mount the partition as something else, copy the files
> from my present /home onto it, then change fstab to
> reflect the desired new arrangement. Let's see...and
> then wipe the present /home directory.
> 
> Or perhaps the new partition could be /opt, leaving
> the present structure intact. (I have only one regular
> "user," so it is not really necessary to expand /home
> several fold.) Does anyone have suggestions on this subject?
> 
> =====
> Robert "Tim" Kopp
> http://analytic.tripod.com/
Yep,
mkdir a mounting point to temporarily mount point for the partition.  Or
if it is mounted already. Make a directory in it to copy your data.  Use
something like tar -cvf - . | ( cd to/the/directory; tar -xvf - ) to
copy what's in home to it.

Then while you are logged in as root, make sure all other users are
logged out.  Move the directory to the top of that partition if it isn't
already.  Then remove the present /home directory.  Then mkdir /home,
then umount the new partition.  Then mount the new partition to home.

That's all there is to it.  Simple, Hey.

Ken

From ebrock-ml at wa-net.com  Mon Mar 17 11:25:02 2003
From: ebrock-ml at wa-net.com (Eric Brockman)
Date: Mon Mar 17 11:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk management
In-Reply-To: <20030317041800.4893.qmail@web9608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3F09E1E6D02D804383502AFDC4DE4EC828D4@cp01.office.wa-net.com>

You can basically do anything you want with your Linux partitions and
mount points if you keep the permissions and ownerships intact with a
"tar cvzf <dir>" or something to that effect then mount the new drive at
the point where you want to place it.  Just take into consideration how
many users you have, if that is going to be growing and if their disk
usage will expand, if you're using quota or not and if you're going to
be installing new software.  If you've got your system to the point
where you got all your software installed that you're going to use, and
you just have users at that point to worry about, I'd just upgrade the
amount of space the /home was using.  On my servers I store all web
sites and users under /home/web and /home/users so that it's nice and
clean and when I have to I just pop in more space.  My drive layout is
big enough so that I haven't had to do that yet but it will be pretty
easy to when I have to.

Thanks,

Eric Brockman

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 17 13:50:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Mar 17 13:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] stopping outgoing virus mail
In-Reply-To: <200303171213.19189.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200303171213.19189.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1047937854.2448.5.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2003-03-17 at 12:13, Carla Schroder wrote:
> I'm trying to figure out a way to block outgoing email generated by a virus. 
> The idea is to stop it before it gets out into the world, and log the 
> activity for when the admin arrives to work refreshed and alert after an 
> unbroken night's sleep. 
> 
> I don't even know if it's possible, anyone have any brilliant ideas? The usual 
> virus-scanners check both incoming and outgoing mail, I'm looking for a way 
> to do it with iptables rules or procmail something similar. Don't even let it 
> past the firewall. Seems like there ought to be something to base a generic 
> ruleset on. 

You can't well block outgoing viruses with iptables unless you write
some code to capture and reconstruct smtp packets, then scan the
reconstructed mail for viruses... 

I thought procmail was for local mail delivery?

Use AMaViS.  I'm pretty sure you can specify you don't want it scanning
incoming email (but why not?).  If you're working for a nonprofit
organization, you can use it in conjunction with F-Prot for free. 
Otherwise, you might need to buy some AV software.

Whenever a virus-ridden email comes through my server, incoming or
outgoing, everybody involved is notified.  The sender is emailed saying
they sent a virus, the recipient is notified saying somebody tried to
send them a virus (and as a result, the email wasn't delivered), and the
postmaster is notified, saying somebody tried to send a virus through my
system.

Rob




From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 17 13:54:02 2003

On Mon, 2003-03-17 at 13:45, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Well, I think it would be rather nuts to not virus-scan incoming mail. ;-) 
> Heck, I'm still seeing damned Klez a lot. I was trying to figure out a way to 
> stop outgoing mail generated by an email virus, should it get past the virus 
> scanner. All kinds of nice egress rules can be written to foil IP spoofing, 
> spyware phoning home, and other nasties. So I'm hunting for something similar 
> for outgoing email sent by viruses. But I'm stuck on what to filter on. 

Are you talking about the nasties that talk smtp themselves rather than
relying on your lookOut Express installation?

If you're running AMaViS, could you just run a filter directing all
outgoing port 25 connections back to your own mail server?  That's what
AOL does (although without the AMaViS part).  

$IPTABLES -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $INTIF -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT \
--to-port 4080

is what I use for my transparent http proxy... but I don't know if you
can direct --dport 25 back to --to-port 25 or if that would give you a
loop.

Rob

I think the best upgrade path for 8.0 from Gnome 2.0 to 2.2 will be the
8.1 release. There are things like 
Garnome  (http://www.gnome.org/~jdub/garnome/)
that can build you a cutting edge 2.2 based setup but if you are looking
to stick with Redhat stable rpm's and their install base upgrading to
8.1 will probably be the easiest.

I've found the Upgrade process to perform very well especially if you
stay close to the current packages from RH.
