From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Mar 17 15:50:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Mar 17 15:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI Scanner question
In-Reply-To: <3E765B09.5080403@freegeek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303171545130.4393-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 17 Mar 2003, Richard Seymour wrote:

> I'm wondering if there's a way to disconnect one scanner, connect a
> different one, and have the second scanner get detected, without
> powering down the system? Or at least to detect the scanner without
> power cycling?

Yes -- but it works best if your system files (/, /tmp, /usr, and 
/var) aren't being served from a SCSI device.

The easy case is when your hard drive is IDE and only your scanner is 
SCSI. In that case, just rmmod the all the SCSI-ish kernel modules and 
then modprobe the module that handles your scanner. The bus will be 
rescanned, the device will be located, and you're in like Flynn.

If your hard drives are being served via the same scsi module, then 
you're in for a rougher go. I suggest power cycling in that case.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From kevinc at doink.com  Mon Mar 17 15:57:01 2003
From: kevinc at doink.com (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Mon Mar 17 15:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI Scanner question 
In-Reply-To: <3E765B09.5080403@freegeek.org> 
Message-ID: <20030317234459.274A956E3@joseph.doink.com>

On 17 March 2003 at 15:32, Richard Seymour <richard at freegeek.org> wrote:

> If I power on my SCSI scanner before I power on the computer, when linux 
> comes up, the scanner is detected. If I leave the scanner off until 
> after the SCSI card is detected, then the scanner isn't detected and not 
> available later on.


I tell my kernel that the scanner is connected using:

echo "scsi add-single-device 0 0 6 0" > /proc/scsi/scsi

My scanner is SCSI ID 6.

I tell my kernel that the scanner is disconnected using:

echo "scsi remove-single-device 0 0 6 0" > /proc/scsi/scsi



> I'm wondering if there's a way to disconnect one scanner, connect a 
> different one, and have the second scanner get detected, without 
> powering down the system? Or at least to detect the scanner without 
> power cycling?


I'm not sure that you can connect a different type of scanner.  I'm 
also not sure about hot-plugging SCSI.  YMMV....

Date: Mon Mar 17 16:02:16 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI Scanner question
In-Reply-To: <20030317234459.274A956E3@joseph.doink.com>

Message-ID: <1047945648.26521.11.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Mon, 2003-03-17 at 15:44, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> On 17 March 2003 at 15:32, Richard Seymour <richard at freegeek.org> wrote:
> 
> > If I power on my SCSI scanner before I power on the computer, when linux 
> > comes up, the scanner is detected. If I leave the scanner off until 
> > after the SCSI card is detected, then the scanner isn't detected and not 
> > available later on.
> 
> 
> I tell my kernel that the scanner is connected using:
> 
> echo "scsi add-single-device 0 0 6 0" > /proc/scsi/scsi
> 
> My scanner is SCSI ID 6.
> 
> I tell my kernel that the scanner is disconnected using:
> 
> echo "scsi remove-single-device 0 0 6 0" > /proc/scsi/scsi
> 
> 
> 
> > I'm wondering if there's a way to disconnect one scanner, connect a 
> > different one, and have the second scanner get detected, without 
> > powering down the system? Or at least to detect the scanner without 
> > power cycling?
> 
> 
> I'm not sure that you can connect a different type of scanner.  I'm 
> also not sure about hot-plugging SCSI.  YMMV....

For most SCSI devices hot-plugging is a big no-no, however, there are a
number of bus drivers that use the scsi subsystem for which hot plugging
is perfectly acceptable (IEEE1394 comes immediately to mind). 
Unfortunately, in 2.4.x, (I don't know about 2.5) the SCSI subsystem
doesn't really understand hot-plugging and as such, you need to use the
"add-single-device" and "remove-single-device" hacks to "hot plug" these
devices.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

information of the infected box could be lost in forwarding.

It looks VERY nice, but there are a couple of nasty gotchas.

It uses the new nptl threading library backported from 2.5.  This causes 
the nVIDIA OpenGL drivers no end of hurt.  The kernel driver does not 
compile.  If you patch it to where it will compile, the GL conflicts with 
register usage hangs your system.

Other than that...

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Tue Mar 18 08:37:01 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Tue Mar 18 08:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RH8.0 FTP up/down with AS400
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBE18@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

On the client side, have you messed-around with various settings of the FTP
program? Binary mode is your friend. There may be something with different
parity/word length or escape/EOF codes that's hanging you up.

Have you tried copying the file internally on the AS400 and then
transferring the copied file rather than the original? If the problem is all
on the AS400 side, doing this should either give more errors to tell you
that AS400 is having trouble with the file, or perhaps it will allow the
transfer to complete. (If you've got different volumes, try copying to a
different volume.)

Have you tried compressing the file and transferring the compressed version
instead? This may help if you only have a clean connection for a narrow time
window. The ability to compress the file on the server side will also
indicate a reasonably clean filesystem up there.

Of course, these suggestions are only really practical for one-shot
transfers. If you've got to transfer stuff routinely, you'll need to find a
root-cause of the problem and correct it.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

Subject: Nasty Samba security problem


Details below (from http://www.samba.org <http://www.samba.org> ) :

 

*	(14th Mar, 2003) Security Release - Samba 2.2.8 

A flaw has been detected in the Samba main smbd code which could allow an
external attacker to remotely and anonymously gain Super User (root)
privileges on a server running a Samba server. This flaw exists in previous
versions of Samba from 2.0.x to 2.2.7a inclusive. This is a serious problem
and all sites should either upgrade to Samba 2.2.8 immediately or prohibit
access to TCP ports 139 and 445. The Release Notes
<http://us1.samba.org/samba/whatsnew/samba-2.2.8.html>  are available
on-line.

In addition to addressing this security issue, Samba 2.2.8 includes many
unrelated improvements. These improvements result from our process of
continuous quality assurance and code review, and are part of the Samba
team's committment to excellence.

The source tarballs are available in both gzip
<http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/samba-2.2.8.tar.gz>  format and bzip2
<http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/samba-2.2.8.tar.bz2>  format. The
uncompressed  <http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/samba-2.2.8.tar.asc> tarball
signature should also be downloaded to verify the archive's integrity. Here
is the Samba Distribution  <http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/samba-pubkey.asc>
Key for verifying the tarball. Finally, here is the patchfile
<http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/patches/patch-2.2.7a-2.2.8.diffs.gz> against
2.2.7a ( signature
<http://us1.samba.org/samba/ftp/patches/patch-2.2.7a-2.2.8.diffs.asc> ).

On Tue, Mar 18, 2003 at 11:08:20AM -0800, Richard Steffens wrote:

Try running aumix to see how the levels are set. For recording your
"igain"  should be above 0 and the "line" level should have an R next to it
indicating that it is the place to record from.  Also if you have sox
installed, you can use the utility rec to record.
For listening, the default volume and pcm levels are often 0  on boot and 
must be increased to hear anything.

Bill Barry

On Tue, Mar 18, 2003 at 02:09:50PM -0800, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Bill Barry wrote:
> 
> > Try running aumix to see how the levels are set. For recording your
> > "igain"  should be above 0 and the "line" level should have an R next to it
> > indicating that it is the place to record from.
> 
> Progress, thanks. I was unaware of aumix. I've only seen the GUI mixer,
> and it looked to be set correctly. Apparently, it was not.
> 
> The level for Line was indeed 0, and when I raised it, sound passed from
> the stereo, to the sound card, and back to the stereo. It appears that
> both the Line and Digital2 controls need to be adjusted. If either of
> them moves, the level changes. There is an "R" next to Line, but not
> next to Digital 2.

If you want to record from someting plugged into audio in (not mic)
then the R should be next to line. As far as I know you can't set
more than one device for record.


> However, there still seem to be problems with gramofile. If I try to
> play a .wav file, it acts like it did it and it's done in a flash. If I
> try to record, it acts in a similar manner.

I don't know anything about gramofile

> I tried reading the man file for sox, but didn't make sense of it. I'm
> guessing, but is this partly correct?
> 
>   sox /dev/audio out.wav -t .wav -r 44100 -c 2
you have the options after the output file, and they should be before it
as in
sox   -t ossdsp -w -s -r 44100 -c 2 /dev/dsp out.wav

I wouldn't  use sox directly, but instead use rec which calls sox
 
rec -t wav -r 44100 -s w -c 2  out.wav 

for more information, man rec

> I couldn't figure out how to tell sox when to stop recording.

You can hit ctrl-c when you are done recording, or if you 
want to do timed recording you can use a little script 
like this

#!/bin/bash
#first use aumix to set the line levels where you want them
aumix  -v 0 -w 0 -m 0 -l R -l 0  -i 30
#then use at to kill the recorder at some later time
at now +5 minutes << EOT
killall sox
EOT
# then start rec
rec -t wav -r 44100 -s w -c 2  /tmp/out.wav  &


Bill Barry

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Mar 18 18:01:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Mar 18 18:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound recording w/ SB-Live! and gramofile
In-Reply-To: <3E77C109.2E5FEC2D@attbi.com>
References: <3E776EA4.77BD8E7E@attbi.com> <20030318202403.GA3192@edge.edge> <3E77992E.2862EDFD@attbi.com> <20030319003754.GA3365@edge.edge> <3E77C109.2E5FEC2D@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20030319020012.GA3485@edge.edge>

On Tue, Mar 18, 2003 at 04:59:53PM -0800, Richard Steffens wrote:

> options. Meanwhile, I can record the LP my wife wants burned to a cd.

I find it a bit tricky to set the gain when recording from LPs
If you set the gain too high you clip the sound, if you set it
too low you don't get the full dynamic range of the recording.
You can record an example clip from the cd and then use sox
to see if you have the gain correct.

sox out.wav -e stat

will give you some statistics on the recording

Note the minimum and maximum amplitude. If they are almost
equal 1 you have the gain too high. If they are too far from 
1 say 0.5 or less, you have the gain too low.

Bill Barry

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Tue Mar 18 21:05:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Tue Mar 18 21:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Webmin problem
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEIPCHAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCGEIPCHAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <2823.216.99.218.67.1048050212.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Anyone who have an idea on how to reset the Webmin password..
>
> TY.
>
> Billy


If you have a password for webmin that is different then your unix
password you can go to the conf directory.  On my system it is /etc/webmin

open up the webmin.users file and remove the second entry between the :
for that user and replace it with an 'x'.  This will make it use Unix
authenication.  If you do this for the root user you could then log in
with the root user then change the password schema back to anything you
like.

I just tried it and it worked for me.

You may need to restart your webmin server but that is also in the
/etc/webmin directory also.  Or it is for me.

Josh





From dcf at aracnet.com  Tue Mar 18 21:20:02 2003
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Tue Mar 18 21:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Should XFree86 work with Radeon 7500?
Message-ID: <20030318210002.G271@grond.sourballs.org>

I had a painful experience trying to upgrade my X server this past
weekend, and was wondering if anyone had any insights.

I was running XFree86 v4.2 on a system with an ATI Radeon 7500 without
problems, and decided to upgrade to 4.3 once I noticed the new ports
available. (As a side note here, I should mention that I'm using FreeBSD
(4.6), which has a package management system - the 'ports' system - that
allows the user to download and compile new software from source.  This is
the standard way to upgrade software on FreeBSD.)

The upgrade process ran without a hitch, machine continued to work ok,
then Sunday morning I restarted the X server ('startx', the way I always
do).  Server messages begin, then the machine becomes competely
unresponsive - can't Ctrl-C, can't switch consoles, can't even ping the
bloody thing.  Can't Ctrl-Alt-Delete -- have to push the start button to
reboot the machine.  After rebooting, the end of the X log looks like:

 (WW) RADEON(0): Video BIOS not detected, using default PLL parameters!
 (II) RADEON(0): PLL parameters: rf=2700 rd=67 min=12500 max=35000;
xclk=16615
 (==) RADEON(0): Using gamma correction (1.0, 1.0, 1.0)
 (II) RADEON(0): Validating modes on Primary head (DDCType: 0) ---------
 (II) RADEON(0): Total number of valid DDC mode(s) found: 0
 (WW) RADEON(0): Mode 1024x768 is out of range.
 (WW) RADEON(0): Valid modes must be between 320x200-0x0
 (II) RADEON(0): Total number of valid FP mode(s) found: 0
 (EE) RADEON(0): No valid mode found for this DFP/LCD
 (II) UnloadModule: "ati"
 (II) UnloadModule: "i2c"
 (II) Unloading /usr/X11R6/lib/modules/libi2c.a
 (II) UnloadModule: "ddc"
 (II) Unloading /usr/X11R6/lib/modules/libddc.a
 (II) UnloadModule: "int10"
 (II) Unloading /usr/X11R6/lib/modules/libint10.a
 (II) UnloadModule: "vgahw"
 (II) Unloading /usr/X11R6/lib/modules/libvgahw.a
 (II) UnloadModule: "radeon"
 (II) Unloading /usr/X11R6/lib/modules/drivers/radeon_drv.o
 (EE) Screen(s) found, but none have a usable configuration.
 Fatal server error:
 no screens found


In previous server logs (from 4.2), the Video BIOS *is* detected, and
many lines of monitor and screen info follow.

Tried reconfiguring with XFree86 -configure, and that hangs the machine
too. Searching the system logs shows that a kernel panic occurs about
here.

Reinstalling 4.2 fixed the problem.

So I'm wondering - since 4.2 *found* my card's video BIOS, and 4.3
*doesn't find* my card's video BIOS, is the problem likely to be a bug in
4.3?  It's possible FreeBSD's package mechanism is at fault here, but
that seems unlikely to me, as the software builds and installs OK. I've
Googled in vain on this topic.  Does this sound familiar to anyone?

David Fleck
dcf at aracnet.com

From ehem at m5p.com  Tue Mar 18 23:29:01 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue Mar 18 23:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Should XFree86 work with Radeon 7500?
In-Reply-To: <E18vWqJ-000420-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200303190728.h2J7STT6055182@m5p.com>

> From: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org (Russell Evans)
> I've the same symptoms with nvidia card when 3d is enabled. I can use the
> nvidia binary driver with 3d disabled but enabling 3d locks up the box. Linux,
> not FreeBSD.

> On Tue, 18 Mar 2003 21:19:43 -0800 (PST), David Fleck said:
> 
> > do).  Server messages begin, then the machine becomes completely
> > unresponsive - can't Ctrl-C, can't switch consoles, can't even ping the
> >  bloody thing.  Can't Ctrl-Alt-Delete -- have to push the start button to

Which AGP are you using? There is the kernel AGP, and the nVidia driver's
NvAGP. The nVidia driver does not like the kernel AGP, if you've built
your own kernel disable AGP support (this will only effect the kernel's
implementation, not the nVidia one), if you're using a prebuilt kernel
either remove the AGP module or tell the nVidia driver to disable AGP
altogether.

> > device).  This is on RedHat 8.  Everytime I upgrade the Kernel via

Unless a data structure used by the driver changes between kernel versions,
I think the driver should still be useable.  Perhaps the problem is that
depmod doesn't find the module after a kernel upgrade.  Where is
the module installed?  If it is installed under
/lib/modules/`kernelversion`/, try putting it under /lib/modules/
instead.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Mar 19 08:51:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Mar 19 08:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Slackware 9.0 and Java
Message-ID: <1048092748.7912.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

Slackware 9.0 was released yesterday, and some unofficial ISOs are
available on ftp.kpn.be (which, for the first time ever, is actually
maxing out bandwidth and FTP connections).

If you want to download Slackware, don't hit ftp.slackware.com - use a
mirror.  Leave that server for mirrors to sync with.

Now, Slackware 9.0 was compiled primarily with GCC 3.2.x.  This
introduces incompatabilities with binaries built with GCC 2.95. 
Including Sun's Java.  Redhat and others have dealt with this by just
compiling Mozilla with GCC <3.2.x.  Slackware didn't do that... the
advantages of compiling Moz with 3.2 are just too great... it really
does run faster.

According to Gentoo, Blackdown's latest Java builds were put together
with GCC 3.2.  So, while I haven't tested it, you should be able to just
drop Blackdown Java in there and it'll work with Mozilla.  The other
options, if you want Java in your browser, are to use Netscape or
Konqueror... or to compile it yourself (which is what I did in Gentoo).

Happy Slackin'  :-)

Rob

From m at pdxlug.org  Wed Mar 19 16:13:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed Mar 19 16:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Syslog question
Message-ID: <39126.12.47.207.251.1048119147.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I have a network device that supports sending logs to a syslog server. 
I'm successfully logging from this device, but I'd like these logs to go
to a separate file, instead of the messages file.  How can this be done? 
I don't see any obvious way using syslog.conf...
Thanks,
~M





From mikeraz at patch.com  Wed Mar 19 16:25:02 2003
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Wed Mar 19 16:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Syslog question
In-Reply-To: <39126.12.47.207.251.1048119147.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>; from m@pdxlug.org on Wed, Mar 19, 2003 at 05:12:27PM -0700
References: <39126.12.47.207.251.1048119147.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030319162445.A31470@patch.com>

Change the facility that the device logs to and write the logs for that
facility to a file.  Your syslog.conf will then have entries something like:

local0.*                                                -/var/log/local0.log
local1.*                                                -/var/log/devlog
local2.*                                                -/var/log/seartrs.log
local3.*                                                -/var/log/vpn.log
local4.*                                                -/var/log/pix.log
local4.=info                                            |/var/log/pix/info
local5.*                                                -/var/log/5399.log
local6.*                                                -/var/log/routers.log

How the "network device" is configured to support a different facility depends
on how the manufacturer designed it.

 

On Wed, Mar 19, 2003 at 05:12:27PM -0700, Matt Alexander typed:
> I have a network device that supports sending logs to a syslog server. 
> I'm successfully logging from this device, but I'd like these logs to go
> to a separate file, instead of the messages file.  How can this be done? 
> I don't see any obvious way using syslog.conf...
> Thanks,
> ~M

     (Source: Computerworld) For systems administrators, it means
they'll have another operating system to learn as their companies
capitalize on Linux savings by retraining staffers. Programmers
and developers may be called on to port Unix-based applications
to Linux systems or to write new ones. They won't need to learn
new languages.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742055

     (Source: PC World.com) A think tank advocating the use of
open source software in government is launching a source-code
escrow program that would let vendors make money on proprietary
software while eventually releasing their products to the open
source community. At least one software company says it may be
open to the idea.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742056

     (Source: CIO) Once a toy for geeks, open source is slowly
but surely filtering into the enterprise and transforming the way
software is designed, sold and supported. And any CIO without an
open-source strategy in 2003 will be paying too much for IT in
2004.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742057

LINUX MEANS MORE OPPORTUNITIES -- FOR RETRAINING
     (Source: Computerworld) For the IT professional, the ease of
learning Linux has drawbacks. Instead of creating jobs in a
still-slow employment climate, it appears that Linux is enabling
companies to fairly quickly retrain existing personnel in the
operating system.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=742058

     (Source: InfoWorld.com) Programmers need to innovate and

     (Source: ITworld.com) Hewlett-Packard announced Wednesday it

Hi all,

I'm having a problem with some people not being able to resolve a server
name in a zone that is being hosted by my DNS server.

I'm having a hard time understanding this, and would like the fine
members on this list to try something for me.  What it boils down to, is
that these same people that can't resolve www.infotects.com can resolve
mail.infotects.com.  These two server names are defined in the same zone
file, and both DNS servers have the same information in that zones.

Please try to go to www.infotects.com, if you can make, please let me
know, and the ISP you are using.  If you don't resolve it, will you do
me a HUGE favor and run dig on that name?  Then send the information and
the ISP you are using to me.  This information will be kept
confidential.

TIA,

Derek Loree

On Thu, 2003-03-20 at 18:53, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> I would like to block irc, yahoo, msn messenger in our RH linux
> server. How would I start with it. Anyone who could help me. These
> programs are causing virus to spread in our network.

Just add in iptables rules to block out the servers... maybe ports 6666
and 6667 for IRC.

Yahoo's server can be found if you fire up gaim and check its settings. 
I think MSN Messenger uses messenger.msn.com, but don't quote me on
that.  Figure out what it currently resolves to then block it... if you
have DNS running, block it there...

Rob

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Mar 21 09:38:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Mar 21 09:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking domains
In-Reply-To: <1048265824.1467.34.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303210934490.13849-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 21 Mar 2003, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Is it possible to block an email address such as *@such&such.net. In
> other words, not a specific email,but anything from a specific domain?

Dirk,

  It is if you're running your own MTA. With postfix I have two separate
files that are checked for each incoming message: one contains IP addresses
the other contains domain names. I duplicate some of the domain names in the
header_checks file when spammers direct their junk to my secondary MX so the
topmost header is from that server rather than the sending ISP.

Rich

IRC listens on various ports. Some common ones are 5000, 6000, 6660 - 6669, 
and 7000. There are others, based on what network you are connecting to, 
and the port they've adopted to use.

From shahms at shahms.com  Fri Mar 21 13:01:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Fri Mar 21 13:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: laptop screen cleaning
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303211253400.14619-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303211253400.14619-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1048280333.22599.20.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Fri, 2003-03-21 at 12:54, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   What are folks using to clean the lcd screens on portables? I generally
> use a microfiber cloth but one unit here needs something with more cleaning
> power.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich

That must be a dirty screen.  I've found simply using a clean cotton
cloth with a small amount of windex (or something similar) sprayed on
the cloth itself to work very well.  FWIW, spraying solvents directly on
the LCD is known to be somewhat dangerous, not so much for the screen
itself, but if the cleaner runs off the edge of the screen surface it
can damage Important Parts (tm).
-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

In-Reply-To: <864r6qgv7z.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:
Carla> Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term
Carla> data storage?  Seems like looking beyond five years gets
Carla> iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which still isn't that long,
Carla> compared to books and magazines.

Russell> I recently went back to 10-14 year-old floppies (720k
Russell> 3.5-inchers) and could read all but 3 out of about 200 (I am
Russell> not sure the failure rate was any better at the time!).  I
Russell> could read all of my 5.25-inch 360k floppies from the
Russell> mid-1980's, nearly 20 years old.

Just another update on this.  We are condensing heavily in preparation
for an office move.  One of the things on the chopping block is our
old 5.25-inch floppy drives, and so I am going through our archive of
old floppies.  I have yet to find a 15 year old 5.25 disk I can't
read.  I did have some trouble with the 3.5-inchers, but 98% of them
were fine and usually only lost 8 sectors off of those.  So, if you
want robust long-term data storage, go with 5.25 inch floppies! ;-)

On Fri, Mar 21, 2003 at 12:54:44PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   What are folks using to clean the lcd screens on portables? I generally
> use a microfiber cloth but one unit here needs something with more cleaning
> power.

I bought a packet of some name-brand (can't recall which) screen cloth
and a spray bottle of same-brand LCD cleaning fluid. Compared to
something simpler and more common, I probably spent too much, but
considering the total came to less than $6-7, it amounted to a
negligible percentage of my laptop's purchase price.

I find that a simple dry wipe-down gets rid of most dust and stuff. When
it gets really grimy, I break out the spray and moisten the cloth a bit.
Sometimes it takes a few applications, but it always does a good job.


Paul

For new users, it would be as easy as copying a generic .mozilla folder into /etc/skel. They would be able to change their copy, of course, but that would make your settings the default.

Regards,
Paul

http://paul.lankow.net

From trottierinoregon at attbi.com  Sat Mar 22 13:47:01 2003
From: trottierinoregon at attbi.com (John Trottier)
Date: Sat Mar 22 13:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Samba Setup
Message-ID: <002c01c2f0bc$76f76d80$9400a8c0@c970265a>

I have a home network with 4 computers connected to a router that is also a gateway and firewall. 3 of the machines are full time Windoze and one is a dual boot between XP and Linux. I want to configure Samba so that the Linux machine can act as a file and print server for the other 3. 

My problem - Samba wants to take over the DHCP duties from the router. In doing so it raises no end of havoc on the network with the other machines. 

Does anyone know how to make Samba "play nice" and leave the DCHP duties for the router?

Thanks in advance

JohnT

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Sat Mar 22 14:07:01 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat Mar 22 14:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Samba Setup
In-Reply-To: <002c01c2f0bc$76f76d80$9400a8c0@c970265a>
References: <002c01c2f0bc$76f76d80$9400a8c0@c970265a>
Message-ID: <E18wr8b-0006XP-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Samba does not take over DHCP. DHCP is a separate daemon. Try 
ps ax | grep dhcpd | grep -v "grep" 
at the command prompt and if dhcpd is running. 

Thank you
Russell.

On Sat, 22 Mar 2003 13:46:15 -0800, John Trottier said:


>  My problem - Samba wants to take over the DHCP duties from the router. In doing so it raises no end of havoc on the network with the other machines.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Mar 22 17:44:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Mar 22 17:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] &quot;secure&quot; mail clients
In-Reply-To: <4144.67.250.78.191.1048374875.squirrel@mail.moochercrew.org>
References: <8665qbrow8.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <4144.67.250.78.191.1048374875.squirrel@mail.moochercrew.org>
Message-ID: <1048383807.1249.4.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2003-03-22 at 15:14, deathfox at moochercrew.org wrote:
> I'm almost positive the POP has an SSL plugin, at least within courier,
> and I know that Eudora suports SSL.  The other option of course is SSL
> IMAP.
> 
> Those would be my two sugestions, the SSL mail stuff works very well.

Yes indeed.  Any POP/IMAP service can be wrapped with SSL using stunnel,
although some have their own built-in facilities for SSL, such as Cyrus
IMAP, and almost all MUAs support it.  (I think if you use a self-signed
cert with Outlook you need to import the cert with IE, though.)  
SSL-wrapping is the most maintainable way, if you don't otherwise have a
Kerberos infrastructure.  Using the SASL facilities which use
challenge-handshake require a separate password from the usual password
databases, which makes maintenance more difficult, and keeps it in a
clear-text equivalent, which makes it a liability.

Wil

> I have plenty of 12 year old 5.25-inch floppies that are mostly unreadable

And if you really want just to archive against electronic loss, you
might use a duplex, high-DPI laser printer and print them 8-up or
higher, which should be okay for scanning and OCR retrieval (although
you'd certainly want to test it).  This would keep your costs, storage
requirements, and paper consumption down.  Anyone know how long and in
what manner laser toner deteriorates?

Once again, lured by the promise of "Don't worry, it's easy!" I tried to set 
up a CUPS print server on my LAN. Before launching into a long tale of woe, 
and appending endless config files and log dumps, perhaps a brief description 
of the symptoms will serve:

I can use CUPS fine with local printers on /dev/lp0, no problem at all. I have 
the official CUPS books, CUPS: Common Unix Printing System, by Michael Sweet. 
It's better as a guide for someone who wants to write printer drivers, than 
for an ole country sysadmin who just wants to print things. I edited 
cupsd.conf according to the book. CUPS then added a phantom printer, in 
addition to the local printer, naming it HP6L:

"Remote Printer on unknown        
Description: No Information Available
Location: Location Unknown
Printer State: stopped, rejecting jobs."

Cannot delete it, cannot start it, the only thing that can be done is client 
machines connect to it with the greatest of ease, even Windows. That's right, 
without Samba even. But neither linux nor windows can print to this stupid 
thing, because it's really not there.

I have tried manually editing the configs, trying the various network 
protocols, and not a blessed one of em works. I have The Official Book and 
the online docs. No answers there.

Thanks in advance for brilliant advice. ;-)

On Sun, 23 Mar 2003, mike mcgranahan wrote:
> thanks for the info.  i do use xset for controlling
> dpms in X, but i am interested in something that will
> a) put the system into standby, not just the monitor,
> and b) work regardless of X running.
>
> any other suggestions or ideas?  i'm finally switching
> from windows to unix "full-time", so i am stuck
> choosing between freebsd and linux (gentoo).  i really
> like freebsd's integration, configuration,
> documentation and ports system, but auto-standby is
> important to me.  thie absence of this feature seems
> to me to be a significant, though not vital,
> omission--particularly useful in computer labs.  is
> anyone aware of a more general daemon or facility that
> can execute a command after a certain period of system
> idleness... perhaps some modified cron?

I'm not sure what is involved in putting the *system* into standby, as
compared to just the monitor - Linux distros usually provide a utility
called 'hdparm' to set spin-down and sleep times for IDE drives, don't
know if theres a SCSI equivalent.  I haven't found a similar utility in
FreeBSD - possibly one of the tunables mentioned in 'man ata' or 'man
tuning' would do it, I haven't looked very hard.

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sun Mar 23 11:36:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Mar 23 11:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] phantom printer on CUPS, cannot share printer
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303231104010.1274-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303231104010.1274-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200303231137.32866.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 23 March 2003 11:05 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sun, 23 Mar 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > It is easy, after you spend a week figuring it out. All fixed.
>
>   Well? Are you going to share with us?
>
> Rich
>

Well, since you ask.

Two changes to the default cupsd.conf should enable sharing of a printer, of 
course using appropriate values for your system:

<Location />
Order Deny,Allow
Deny From All
Allow From 127.0.0.1
Allow from 192.168.1.  <--- add this line
</Location>

BrowseAddress 192.168.1.255

The docs all say to do this:  

Allow from 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.255

Adding any netmask blocks client access, and creates the phantom printer. I do 
not know why, I just know what works. The netmask on my LAN is 255.255.255.0 
TCP/IP gurus are most welcome to chime in here.

Have a static IP on the machine connected to the printer. There's a few more 
steps, the cupsd.conf entries are the big showstopper.

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

>>>>> "Bill" == Bill Barry <barryb at proaxis.com> writes:

Russell> Anyway, my main point was just to note how well the 5-1/4"
Russell> media was holding up, which was something of a surprise.

Bill> [...] Amazing. The diskettes I said were bad, were from
Bill> 1993, but I still hold out hope even for them.

I was having fun last week recovering data from the 3.5-inch floppies
that were "bad", dd'ing images off.  When I got to a bad spot on the
disk, I'd just skip past it and dd the remainder to another file, dd a
replacement using /dev/zero and then cat the files together and mount
the resulting image using the "-o loop" option and read the files
off.  The result will be that some of the files will have chunks of
zeros that really shouldn't be there, but the upside is I got the rest
of the data off.  

In one case, the missing part was the first 8 sectors, which meant
that I lost the FATs and the root directory.  However, the data were
distictive enough that I could, under the assumption that the clusters
were written in order, figure out the starting and ending sectors and
dd them out of the image and then truncate the crap off the end.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Mar 24 08:37:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Mar 24 08:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Games under Linux
In-Reply-To: <3F09E1E6D02D804383502AFDC4DE4EC828D4@cp01.office.wa-net.com>
Message-ID: <20030324163615.83110.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

If you're a gamer, you might be interested to know
that the Linux client for Neverwinter Nights is
finally out. It actually won 2nd or 3rd place on the
"vaporware" awards, as it was originally supposed to
arrive when the Windows version shipped early last
Summer. I originally bought it with the expectation of
playing it on my Linux workstation.

Anyway, the client is only a beta, but I have to say
taht I was VERY impressed! I had originally got tired
of waiting and played it a little on my Win2k machine,
but was disappointed. It's an Athlon 2100+ with a
newer (though lower end) ATI video card. It ran
poorly, even at the lowest resolution and the bells
and whistles turned off. To top it off, after spending
20 minutes creating my character, the game
blue-screened about 60 seconds into the game, losing
my new character. I only played it a short time after
that, as it was jerky enough to give me a headache and
crashed a second time.

The Linux client, on the other hand, runs very
smoothly at a higher res with all the bells and
whistles, on a Celeron 1300 with an old GeForce2
running RedHat 8.0. I played it quite a bit this
weekend without a single flaw or crash.

I'm curious as to what other people have experienced
when playing a Linux port of a Windows game. Was it
faster/slower under Linux?

When I first started using Linux, I tried out Quake3,
and was getting at least 20% faster framerates on the
same hardware, and never had a crash. Unfortunately on
my latest install, Quake3 doesn't run. It loads, I
select the first map, the map loads, and locks up
about 1 second later. Any ideas?

Return to Castle Wolfenstein has run flawlessly for me
under Linux. When it first game out, I played it under
Win2k, but it had an aweful bug that would crash the
game every time I tried to load a game after dying,
which was a show-stopper. A lot of other people in
message boards had the same problem, but I have saw a
fix, even recently.

When installed under Linux (again on the same
hardware), it has run perfectly. I never did compare
frame rates, but it felt smoother under Linux.

Anyone else compared games under Linux vs. Windows?

-Scott

On Monday 24 March 2003 08:41 am, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> /dev/hda1             289M  266M  8.0M  98% /

Depending on how you have your system configured this could be the problem.  
The default is to leave 5% of you disk space free for root use when the 
filesystem gets too full.  Try moving some things to another partition


Such as

mkdir /var/opt
 
mv /opt /opthold

ln -s /var/opt /opt

cd /opthold
tar cf - . && ( cd /var/opt && tar xvf - )

Also you have a 4.8 /tmp directory.  This seems excessive.  I only make my 
500MB, and that's probably very excessive.


Sean

Disregard me previous comment about cached debian packages clogging your
hard drive. apt-get caches live under /var, and it looks like you got
more than enough space there. :-)

Root partition is getting a bit cramped, though. If I were you and had
time to kill, I'd consider swapping the root and tmp partitions. I can't
imagine you'll ever need 5 gig of tmp space.

I've heard it said that keeping the root partition towards the beginning
of the drive is best for performance (faster access of inner tracks,
supposedly). This always struck me as pointless hare-splitting.
Comments, anyone?


Paul




From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Mon Mar 24 10:42:01 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Mon Mar 24 10:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Samba Setup
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBE60@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

Want a sloppy, cheating solution that makes things work without addressing
the root cause of the problem?

 

Make sure your Samba box's DHCP scope and your router's DHCP scope are both
larger than the number of machines on your network and that they are both
within the same subnet. That way, it won't matter which DHCP server
responded first to a workstation's query. They'll both serve adequately. 

 

For example, Samba gives addresses ranging from 192.168.1.10 through
192.168.1.64 in a class C (255.255.255.0) subnet while the router gives
addresses ranging from 110 through 164 in the same subnet.

 

-djp

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Mon Mar 24 11:28:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Mon Mar 24 11:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Samba Setup
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBE63@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

I don't think so, but I'm willing to admit that I've been wrong more than
once or twice before.

My theory is that a newly booted workstation will transact its DHCP business
only with THE one particular DHCP server that responds first to its DHCP
request broadcast.

If that happens to be the same DHCP server 'A' it saw last time and the
server gives it an ACK to continue using the same address as before, the
workstation agrees to Server A's re-assignment and everything's fine,
despite the other server's jabbering. If the first DHCP server to respond is
the other one 'B' and NAKs the workstation's use of an address outside its
scope, it'll counter-offer an address the workstation agrees to the new
assignment and again, everything's fine. In either case, the server's
response is directed to the workstation's physical (MAC) address and it
contains the server's MAC and IP addresses for the workstation's responses.
Once the workstation hears its first response, it is only going to transact
with the DHCP server from which it heard its FIRST response.

If two DHCP servers always fought (NAK-ing each other's assignments) over
who can assign the workstation its address, there would be no way to set-up
redundancy in DHCP servers on a subnet without some complex communications
going-on between the redundant servers.

I think I mentioned that my solution was sub-optimal in that it doesn't
address the root-cause of the original poster's problem; namely, how to
shut-off the Samba server's DHCP service so that all workstations can get
canonical addresses from the router. I'll have to learn some more Linux
before I can give that answer with any authority.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Mar 24 14:31:02 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Mar 24 14:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat Network
In-Reply-To: <20030324220940.GA32300@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303240535530.27856-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 24 Mar 2003, Sandy Herring wrote:

> I have two demo RHN accounts and one paid subscription. I'm also quite
> pleased. For me, the main advantage is notification when an update that
> affects one of my systems is available, and up2date's ability to reconcile
> RPM dependencies. The downside is that RH does not good a good enough job of
> on their older releases (e.g. 7.3) of staying current with new packages
> (e.g. mutt 1.4i). I've sometimes resorted to building them from source, and
> then up2date urges me to load an older release. Guess I could build my own
> rpm so that the database shows the release I'm running :)

Redhat will backport security patches, but they resist moving to new 
versions of packages.

I understand why.  I don't totally agree with it, but I understand it.

If you were able to have current apps, then you would not move to the new 
bright and shiny thing that they want to sell you.  (That is, after all, 
how they keep in business.)

There is also the issue of creeping dependancies.  Think of a distribution 
as a tangles web of spidery dependancies.  When you grab onto an app and 
pull, you get all the things that it is hooked to.  When you upgrade, you 
get to deal with all of the updates that program may require and any new 
dependancies that may get added or dropped.  You also get to deal with all 
the other apps that may rely on the older versions.

For something like Mutt, this may not be a big deal.  For something like 
Evolution, it might me.  For packages that are moving from Gnome 1.x to 
2.x, it gets even messier.

And, no, apt-get is not the answer here.  I can name a couple of places 
where Debian has gotten it wrong as well.  (The move from /var/spool/mail 
to /var/mail is a primary example.)

It is a hard problem.  Redhat solves it by not upgrading except in large  
distribution-sized chunks.  Debian does similar things, but has a QA 
process designed to (hopefully) catch those problems before they become 
widely used.

As for the Redhat version number change.  I can understand that as well. 
They are making some serious changes to glibc.  When they change glibc, 
they tend to change major revision numbers.

Whether this is a good thing is difficult to say at the moment.  I have 
some concerns.  Depends on what the interaction is like between the nptl 
thread library and the nVIDIA X drivers are like.  (The last time I looked 
at it, it was not good.)

Message-ID: <20030325053400.GA4208@edge.edge>

On Mon, Mar 24, 2003 at 01:45:13PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   How can I specify a tab or hard return in the search and replace dialog
> box? I have about 50 pages of references where the first line is set in by
> two tab stops. I want to eliminate those in one, automatic S&R operation.
> Similarly, I want to replace the hard returns at the end of each line with
> the citation paragraph.

How about a small perl script.
Here is one to get rid of the two tabs at the beginning of a line

#-------------
#!/bin/perl
while(<>) 
{
   s/^\t\t//;
   print;
}
#----------

As for replacing the hard returns, what is a "citation paragraph"?

Bill

From mwlist at planetwills.com  Mon Mar 24 23:12:01 2003
From: mwlist at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Mon Mar 24 23:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Audio Dilemma
In-Reply-To: <20030324215331.R26214@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEHGDCAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>

Bruce,
The typical way to play CDs on a computer does not read the CD as data. The
computer just sends a signal to play the CD and the audio goes from the
Drive directly to the Sound Card. The sound card is only used as a
mixer/volume control. The quick way, if you don't have a sound card in the
computer is to plug your headphones or speakers directly into the jack in
the front of the CD. The CD playing software can still be used to start the
CD and change tracks, it just can't change the volume.

BTW the low-end Soundblaster PCI cards should work fine if you want to take
that path.

Mark

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Mar 24 23:29:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Mar 24 23:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Audio Dilemma
In-Reply-To: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEHGDCAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
References: <20030324215331.R26214@defiant.ncplus.net> <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEHGDCAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
Message-ID: <20030325072843.GA7578@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, Mar 24, 2003 at 11:12:09PM -0800, Mark Wills wrote:
> BTW the low-end Soundblaster PCI cards should work fine if you want to take


Perhaps I've been lucky, or perhaps I have a low end card, but I've
had no real problems with pci audio. Currently I'm using a SB Live 128
or something like that, and very happy with it. There is a lot of
online help for sound cards, through google or the ALSA page. one
reccomendation is to drop $30 on a SB. card and use the kernel
drivers. (I use the EMU10k1 driver, if that helps).

On the topic of ripping audio from CD:

* cdparanoia will make wav's from a music cd, (command line tool)
* lame will encode wav's to mp3 (and possibly ogg? not sure--command
       line)
* arson and grip are both excelent gui apps for putting cd's on your
computer. They are frontends for a bunch of other tools (such as lame
& cdparanoia), so be prepared for a little dependancy nightmare if
your package manager dosen't do it for you. It is well worth it
however.

Both arson and grip have hooks to cddb databases, and do the
ripping/encoding all for you, "in one step" (as far as the user is
concerned). With the cddb hooks, they can name the files as you want
them, you define the format and it does the rest.

Once you have mp3s/ogg files, xmms is a decent music player. The
random track selection isn't very random though.

-Rogan





From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Mar 24 23:42:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Mar 24 23:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: apt-get problem
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030324225151.00b24758@192.168.0.2>

	 <20030324174954.GA432@nellump.net>

Message-ID: <1048578101.24109.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-03-24 at 22:55, Russ Johnson wrote:
> At 06:43 PM 3/24/2003 -0800, you wrote:
> >Who measure the .0001% access time
> >difference.  When a HD manufacture comes out and tells me after extensive
> >testing this is the best solution, then I will act accordingly.
> 
> 
> I think many years ago, when access time was measured in seconds, not 
> msecs, it probably made more difference, and the idea stuck.
> 
> Even to this day, if you format a disk during a Solaris 9 install, it 
> claims to have faster performance if the swap space is at the beginning of 
> the drive. I don't know if QA actually tested that, or if it's a carry over 
> from many previous versions. The same claim is there at least as far back 
> as Solaris 2.6.

One of the features of the AIX LVM is the ability to specify in which of
five zones you want the PPs (Physical Partitions) for the volume.  For
lots of stuff, it probably doesn't matter, but if you've got a big
(expensive) system and want to get every last ounce of performance out
of it, it certainly can't hurt, especially if it's easy to do.

But you'd really want swap space or a very active filesystem like /var
or a filesystem containing database files to be in the fastest
portions.  / is scarcely touched after booting, except for /tmp, which
should probably be a memory-based filesystem (like tmpfs) instead.

I don't think I'd be terribly concerned about it in this case; I'd be
more concerned with the lack of space on / (although I'd probably only
give a few hundred MB to / and make the rest /usr/local or /opt or
both).

Wil

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Tue Mar 25 00:04:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue Mar 25 00:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Audio Dilemma
In-Reply-To: <20030324215331.R26214@defiant.ncplus.net>
References: <20030324215331.R26214@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <E18xjOi-0001BS-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I thought this was what rplay and rplayd were for.  Set some cd player to
output to /dev/dsp and rplayd picks it up. rplay on the client connects to the
rplayd server and outputs to the local sound card.  http://rplay.doit.org/

The other option is to use ogg files and a server, like gnump3d. A NFS export
of the ogg files to the other box is also possible.
http://freshmeat.net/search/?q=mp3&section=projects&filter=118 will get you a
few ogg cd rippers. There seem to be a few streaming servers also but I can't
find a freshmeat category for them to provide a quick link. A search on
freshmeat for ogg or mp3 should catch the servers as well as anything else. 

I can't speak to the best option as this isn't something I do. I did look into
rplayd for remote, ( all nodes on a private local NOC network ), network
monitor alarms at one time, but did not implement it. I'm not sure if the sound
quality holds up for music or the security implication if you want to use it on
a public network.. 


Thank you
Russell

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Mar 25 03:41:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Mar 25 03:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: apt-get problem
In-Reply-To: <200303241843.08979.sean@fork.com>
References: <1048524096.1396.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <20030324174954.GA432@nellump.net>  <200303241843.08979.sean@fork.com>
Message-ID: <1048592462.15966.191.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-03-24 at 18:43, Sean Whitney wrote:
> > I've heard it said that keeping the root partition towards the beginning
> > of the drive is best for performance (faster access of inner tracks,
> > supposedly). This always struck me as pointless hare-splitting.
> > Comments, anyone?
> 
> I heard this argument also, or that it should be at the outside of the disk.  
> The rotational velocity is faster at the edge so more sector's pass the head 
> every second.  Personally I think these are the rantings of no-nothing 
> "experts" with too much time their hands.  Who measure the .0001% access time 
> difference.  When a HD manufacture comes out and tells me after extensive 
> testing this is the best solution, then I will act accordingly.

My disk is rated at 7200 rpm, that stays the same as the heads move in
and out, reading sectors as they go.

The rotational velocity is constant, it's the linear velocity that
increases, more of the disk passes over the head each second as the head
moves away from the axis of rotation, but the angular velocity stays the
same.  So the theory is, less time is spent reading sectors at the outer
edges of the disks, if the sectors are all the same arc length
(presumably limited by the density of magnetic particles).

The real question is:  what do they mean by beginning and end?  I think
the drive makers start us off on the fastest part of the disk, radius
doesn't matter.

tomshardwareguide.com does a lot of testing, and for the most part they
all have mostly constant transfer rates, tapering off near the end if
they change at all.  Though I've seen some that drop to almost half the
starting rate.
 
The problem is, this is not a measure of me sitting here with 10 virtual
desktops, 3 other users logged in on other X-consoles (with what ever
games they left running), user-mode linux, apache, mysql, and various
other services running.  The disk is reading from and possibly writing
to 3 different partitions every time I open a program.

The fastest access would be to have all 3 partitions be very small, and
as physically close to each other as possible; all at the beginning of
the disk.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

a word processor.

Back to your issue, do you have complex formatting in your document? If it's
still fairly simple in its layout, you can export to a text file and then
use command line tools or perl to S&R. If it's formatted, you might try
exporting to either HTML or rich text format (depending on which format
preserves more of your desired formatting) and then resort again to command
line tools and/or perl.

bug-tracking forums might give a clue or three?

On Tue, 25 Mar 2003, Chaz wrote:

> There was a web site that had a table of linux hardware and info
> such as how many people had used it, etc. I tried recently to find
> it again without success. Does anyone know where it is or any other
> sources of HW info? Most of what I've found is very verbose and
> difficult to wade through.

The easiest way to answer hardware-compatibility questions is to 
start with the hardware and see if Linux supports it. Google makes 
that part easy.

If you're building a system from scratch and want to spec the 
individual components, I'd start at the LDP Hardware HOWTO:

  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Hardware-HOWTO/index.html

The Linux Journal and other journalistic sites also have articles 
about building Linux-friendly systems.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

I'm not sure I know exactly what Rich wants with his Newlines, but here's
something I've often wanted to do:

To clean-up
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda.\n
\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda\n
\n

and turn it into:
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda
yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda
yadda yadda yaddda.\n
Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda yadda yadda yaddda. Yada yadda
yadda yadda yaddda.\n

I do three replacements:
1) replace \n\n with some unique string like &&&&&
2) replace \n with just a space
3) replace my unique string with a single \n

-djp

Subject: [PLUG] Converting OO.o docs to pdf
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303251129250.13493-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Never mind -- I answered my own question. Using the postscript printer
definition and a .ps extension, OO.o wrote the file properly. It _is_ a
postscript file!

  I had not had a postscript printer defined before I added the postscript
module to the printer. Now I have CUPS configured so that laser5_ps does
duplex printing and laser5_non_ps does single-sided printing.

  Yea, it works! Kewl.

> I do three replacements:
> 1) replace \n\n with some unique string like &&&&&
> 2) replace \n with just a space
> 3) replace my unique string with a single \n

This is what Perl's $/ is for:

  #!/usr/bin/perl -w
  use strict;
  $/ = '';
  open( OLDFH, '< /some/file' ) or die $!;
  open( NEWFH, '> /some/file.new' ) or die $!;
  while ( <OLDFH> ) {
    chomp;
    print NEWFH $_, "\n";
  }
  close( OLDFH ) or die $!;
  close( NEWFH ) or die $!;
  exit;

Setting $/ to an empty string -- as opposed to undef-ing it or setting 
it to "\n\n" -- will tell Perl to "treat two or more consecutive blank 
lines as a single blank line" [Camel, 3d ed. p 666].

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Mar 25 12:20:02 2003

Date: Tue Mar 25 12:20:02 2003

On Tue, 2003-03-25 at 11:41, Chaz wrote:
> looked at the motherboard section.
> very small. wasn't impressed.
> I'll keep looking.

I've never had a working motherboard fail to boot linux.  In fact, linux
has better out of the box support for some chipsets (VIA and AMD come to
mind) than the dark OS.  Some of the on-board extras may not be
supported, but that is becoming less and less of a problem.  In short,
find the motherboard you want, then see if any of the on-board devices
are a problem under linux, instead of trying to find a list of all
compatible motherboards.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

On Tue, Mar 25, 2003 at 11:48:21AM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Tue, 25 Mar 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> 
> > I do three replacements:
> > 1) replace \n\n with some unique string like &&&&&
> > 2) replace \n with just a space
> > 3) replace my unique string with a single \n
> 
> This is what Perl's $/ is for:
> 
>   #!/usr/bin/perl -w
>   use strict;
>   $/ = '';
>   open( OLDFH, '< /some/file' ) or die $!;
>   open( NEWFH, '> /some/file.new' ) or die $!;
>   while ( <OLDFH> ) {
>     chomp;
>     print NEWFH $_, "\n";
>   }
>   close( OLDFH ) or die $!;
>   close( NEWFH ) or die $!;
>   exit;
> 
> Setting $/ to an empty string -- as opposed to undef-ing it or setting 
> it to "\n\n" -- will tell Perl to "treat two or more consecutive blank 
> lines as a single blank line" [Camel, 3d ed. p 666].

Too much typing.  Try this instead:

perl -000lpe 'tr/\n/ /;' input > output

or for in-place editing:

perl -i.bak -000lpe 'tr/\n/ /;' input 

or for dangerous in-place editing:

perl -000lpi -e 'tr/\n/ /;' input 

Might not be enough zeroes in the -000 part.

Colin

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Mar 25 15:28:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Mar 25 15:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] STunnel
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303251229270.32691-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303251512490.16474-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 25 Mar 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:

> 
> 
> Just curious, what are you using STunnel for?  It looks interesting.

This is convulsed - to say the least.  I have a system running vservers 
and am creating individual vservers for each application I'm runnning.  
Database (PostgreSQL), rt (Request Tracker), and a custom application for 
handing domains, hosts and IP assignments.  The idea being I can proto 
type (and run) the application(s) in the vserver and if they go south, get 
broken into, outgrow the capacity of the system, etc. I can move just 
the parts and pieces or kill and create a new vserver.
   Since the database is on one vserver and rt another I want secure
connections between them.  The most platform neutral method seems to be
secure tunnels.  Bandwidth will suck as the apps grown but the security
and ease is worth it.

So I have Stunnel running on the database system and using DBI from my 
custom app and rt I keep (or at least should keep) my data secure.


Rod

  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

in your printer list in swriter or other OO app. When asked for the target
directory to save the file in when setting up the pdf "printer", I used $HOME

multi-user machine.

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Wed Mar 26 08:06:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed Mar 26 08:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On The Radar
Message-ID: <1048694990.1481.367.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

All,

Microsoft issued a bulletin to their "Freedom to Monopolize" _ahem_
"Freedom to Innovate" web site yesterday. The bulletin is as follows:

"Open Source Software Procurement Preferences

A small number of state legislators have introduced legislation that
would require state governments to consider open source software when
acquiring new software, and provide justification for using proprietary
software products, including Microsoft's. Proposed legislation in Oregon
(House Bill 2892) and Texas (Senate Bill 1579) seeks to establish a
procurement bias for open source software, which would hurt competition
and innovation in the software industry. Similar legislation will likely
be introduced in other states as well. For more information on the
procurement debate, visit the Initiative for Software Choice."

You can view the posting here:

http://www.microsoft.com/freedomtoinnovate/newsletter/finnews_032503.asp
  
Here's Microsoft's chance to really shine. This is their opportunity to
truly justify their "innovation" as Government IT decision makers put
into writing justification for Microsoft's products in terms of value
for the people of Oregon. I would be absolutely astounded if Microsoft
or the so-called "Initiative For Software Choice" fought this bill.

I am somewhat concerned with their statement that this bill, "...seeks
to establish a procurement bias for open source [sic] software..."
perhaps they've simply misunderstood this bill.

The good news is is that this Open Source consideration legislation is
catching on. Like Ken Barber says, "...like a grass fire." I've just
received an email from a member of the Washentaw Linux User's Group
asking how he can get this kind of legislation to the Michigan's House
of Representatives.

I'll keep you posted.


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

From paul at lankow.net  Wed Mar 26 10:52:01 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul)
Date: Wed Mar 26 10:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sylpheed spell check
Message-ID: <20030326105105.2fe96783.paul@lankow.net>

It took me a while to figure this out so I thought I would pass it along. If you would like to add spell checking to the compose window of Sylpheed:

Configuration, actions
Menu name = Spell Check
Command = | cat - >/tmp/sc.tmp; xterm -e aspell -e -c /tmp/sc.tmp; cat /tmp/sc.tmp; /bin/rm /tmp/sc.tmp |

Enjoy ...

Paul

PS: I bound that to CTRL-T for quick access.

-- 
email: paul at lankow.net
http://paul.lankow.net

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Wed Mar 26 17:10:03 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed Mar 26 17:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892 Makes The Oregonian
In-Reply-To: <200303261540.06125.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303261324040.24390-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
    <1048716264.5048.718.camel@red> <200303261540.06125.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <E18yLtC-0001hB-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

There are a lot of people in the world that need "free beer". In the US,
because the business world uses "non-free beer" it makes little sense to
provide a "free beer" computer to someone who needs "free beer". A "free beer"
person without computer skills needs to learn "non-free beer" to increase their
chances of getting a job or better job.  This seems a catch-22. Think if "free
beer" were adopted by government and business; the saying "it takes money to
make money" might be a little less true and a few more people would be given
opportunity. I believe this is the reason we have public schools, I believe
this is why we have scholarships and grants for higher education, I believe the
government supplies small business loans for minorities for the same reason, to
create opportunity. Opportunity is the mother of liberty, because there is no
liberty in a single choice, no matter how many choose it.
http://www.fiu.edu/~fcf/castrocoronation11298.html

I think the idea of freeloader is wrong, "free beer" can mean liberty.

On Wed, 26 Mar 2003 15:40:06 -0800, Carla Schroder said:

>  Remember that 'free' means liberty, not free of cost, but that's mostly 
>  forgotten in favor of 'freeloader' er I mean 'free beer'.
>

On Mon, 24 Mar 2003, Percival, Ray wrote:

> ARe you trying to talk from a Win2k client to a Linux box?
> If so what are you running on the Linux box and why are you trying PPTP
> which is a protocol with so many problems that basically sending in the
> clear is just as good? Please more detail on what you are doing and why.
>

Ray,

    The Linux server is a firewall running Astaro Security Linux - which
is a very refined, cut down Debian variant.  (Well, there actually isn't
much Debian left.)  Astaro is a large firewall distribution, a bit
like Smoothwall, but much better and much more expensive.  It includes
packet filters, proxy servers, virus scans, IPSEC VPN, PPTP VPN, decent
reporting functions, etc.  Unneeded services have been removed to the
point that there are only about 100 commands left.  Most services run
in chroot jails.  It is pretty nice.

    My client wants to support a variety of Windows clients on the
VPN including Win 98, Win ME, Win 2000, and Win XP.  However, most of
the clients are Win 2000 or Win XP.  I have recommended getting IPSEC
client software for all the PCs or possibly using the IPSEC that
comes with Win 2000 and Win XP, but my client is reluctant to switch
from PPTP for a number of very good reasons.  At this point, it looks
like we will install PPTP and gradually migrate to IPSEC - which of
course is much better for several reasons - like it is relatively secure
and PPTP is not.

    In any case, what IPSEC client software do you normally recommend on:

                 Win 98
                 Win ME
                 Win 2000
                 Win XP

Do you recommend MicroSoft's IPSEC on Win 2000 and/or Win XP or do you
recommend something like SSH Sentinel or is there something more
OpenSource than this?

                                                     Dave Mandel

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Wed Mar 26 21:37:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Wed Mar 26 21:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 8.0 + 0.1 (?) = 9.0
In-Reply-To: <20030324120603.65d13b8b.paul@lankow.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0303262133150.11577-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Mon, 24 Mar 2003, Paul wrote:
> Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> wrote:
>
> > Looks like there won't be a Red Hat 8.1:
>
> Guess they figure they got it right the first time. :-) How long has it been out? Doesn't seem that long.

No, they figured that executables compiled on 9.0 will not run on 8.0 so
according to their version numbering convention, it cannot be called 8.1,
has to be 9.0. The rule for RH is very simple: as long as there is
backward compatibility, the major version number remains the same. When
they cannot guarantee backward compatibility, the major number increases
by one.
In this case, they went from the old Linux threads to NPTL. This change
alone is enough to break backward compatibility completely.

--

8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu Mar 27 01:27:01 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu Mar 27 01:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Used motherboard wanted
In-Reply-To: <1048728454.5052.810.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303262129450.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>

On 26 Mar 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> One of my servers is acting strange and I'd like to
> simply replace the motherboard. The current motherboard
> has a 1 GHz Celeron and PC-100 memory. Is anyone looking
> to get rid of an ancient motherboard?
>
Not really an answer to Ed, but I learned something very surprising
the other weekend about shopping for used computers.

I thought I'd have a look to see what was available at Goodwill,
figuring I could pick up an old 486 or Pentium I class computer
there for $20.-- or less. And so the wife & I went over to the
store on SE MLK, I found the electronics section, & I was shocked
at what they wanted for antique computers -- roughly twice what
I would price them at. (The least expensive unit was about $50.--,
& the hard drive was marked ``bad".)

I must not be too unreasonable in my price expectations, because
since then I found it trivially easy to locate similar makes of
used computers for less than Goodwill wanted -- shipping included!

Geoff

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Mar 27 10:55:03 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu Mar 27 10:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Voltage Monitoring Hardware/Software
In-Reply-To: <35169.63.105.27.245.1048790871.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
References: <35169.63.105.27.245.1048790871.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <20030327185331.GD3885@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Mar 27, 2003 at 10:47:51AM -0800, Keith Nasman wrote:
> I'm interested in starting a solar power project (Photovoltaic). To start
> small I'm going to get a small PV panel, charger, and battery(ies) to set
> up. I'd like to be able to interface the system with one of my Linux boxes
> so I can track the state of charge as well as what the panel is producing.
> 
> Anyone have any experience, recommendations, etc,  with PCI cards that
> would allow me to monitor voltages and such?

A lot of people have been using Dallas 1-wire parts for weather
stations and home automation (like HVAC zone-control) with Linux.  If
you work with batteries that charge to less than 6V, I'd visit our
website http://www.maxim-ic.com and check out the 1-wire parts list.
You probably want a DS2761, and I'm willing to bet you can get an eval
kit for cheap/free.

Colin

                             SuitWatch--March 27th

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                 This Week's Sponsor: Crucial Technologies

       Get the same top-quality memory the server manufacturers use.

                At low, factory-direct prices. It's Crucial.

   When you buy from Crucial, you're buying directly from the
   manufacturer, Micron--just like the manufacturers do. It only costs
   less because you aren't paying middleman mark-up fees. So you cut
   costs without sacrificing performance. Visit our Server Solutions
   Center at www.crucial.com:
   http://click.atdmt.com/CRL/go/spclzcru00500099crl/direct/01/ today,
   and discover why Crucial means business.
     _________________________________________________________________

                          "Welcome to GandhiCon 4"

   Thursday, March 27, 2003--Perhaps we'll remember March 18, 2003, as
   E-Day. That was the day when Evans Data Corp. delivered hard numbers
   to substantiate what most of us already sensed in our bones: Linux was
   now clearly on its way to becoming the majority target platform for
   enterprise software development.

   First came the company's release:
   http://www.evansdata.com/n2/pr/releases/3_18_2003.shtml to the press.
   "DEVELOPERS MIGRATING FROM WINDOWS TO LINUX", its headline said,
   adding "52% of Developers Now Targeting Linux Used to Develop for
   Windows". Linux, the survey said:
   http://www.evansdata.com/n2/surveys/linux/linux_03_1_xmp1.shtml, is
   pulling developers away from Windows more than it pulls from various
   forms of UNIX:

     Fifty-two percent of respondents who currently have Linux as their
     target for applications say they used to write applications
     primarily for one of the versions of Windows. Only 30% have
     switched from some form of UNIX to Linux as their primary target.

   Computerwire:
   http://www.computerwire.info/brnews/73C4FE58AF70456D80256CEC0054E3D5
   put the news in perspective, dismissing conventional Microsoft FUD:

     A new survey from Evans Data Corp. appears to contradict
     suggestions from Microsoft Corp. that the growth of the Linux
     operating system has been at the expense of UNIX, rather than its
     own Windows operating system.

   In other words, okay, we'll see your FUD and raise you a few FACTS. I
   immediately wrote and asked Evans Data to share a few more of those
   facts with us, which they kindly provided. Here are some of the target
   platform results:

     Unsurprisingly, Windows OSes are the most common, accounting for
     81% of developers' primary host environments...Linux, too, has
     become a contender in the most-used development OS comparison; 8%
     of respondents use Linux as their primary development OS, which is
     more than all the other flavors of UNIX combined (5.4%).

     For secondary target host environments today, 32% of respondents
     named UNIX, and about half of those (15.5% of the total) named
     Linux.

   For next year's plans, Evans Data said, "Linux use will increase, too;
   8% use it now, but 14% expect to use the open-source OS as primary
   host next year. (That 6% increase is suspiciously similar to the 6%
   decrease in Windows use.)"

   Among development platforms, however, Linux already kicks butt. Here's
   Evans Data:

     Linux is the primary choice of host platform at 40%. Windows 2000
     makes a strong showing at 29%, with Windows XP right behind at 12%.
     The landscape is about to change, however, as you will see below...

     Next year respondents plan to increase their use of Linux as the
     primary development platform by 15%, from 40% to 55%. They also
     plan to increase their use of Windows XP as a development platform
     by 8%, going from 12% this year to 20% next year. Both Linux and
     Windows XP are taking at least some of their share from Windows
     2000, since it drops 15% from 30% this year to 15% for the next.
     Other flavors of UNIX comprise an insignificant share of the host
     development platform this and next year, so Linux is obviously
     taking more share from Windows than any other OS.

   It gets better when we look at development platforms:

     The choice of OS for a development platform does not necessarily
     dictate the choice of OS on which to run the finished application.
     In this case, however, Linux tops the chart on both the development
     platform choice and target platform choice. Forty-percent of
     respondents said they most often target Linux for the OS on which
     their applications will run compared to 43% for all versions of
     Windows combined. Windows 2000 is the primary target for 23% of
     respondents. This distribution implies the bulk of applications are
     likely to be server-oriented, especially since the most often used
     client OS, Windows 95/98, is the primary target for only 8% of
     developers. Windows XP is the primary focus for 8%, as well.

   And what about next year? Get ready to rock:

     When it comes to the primary focus for the target platform for
     applications, the trend for next year follows the same trend for
     what respondents are going to use for their development platform.
     Linux gets the largest increase, going from 40% to 53%. The
     combination of all Windows versions drops from 43% to 33%. Windows
     2000 loses the most attention, going from 23% to 13%. Windows XP
     picks up more focus, going from 8% this year to 17% next year. The
     rest of the categories continue to get an insignificant amount of
     attention.

   Yesterday at PC Forum in Arizona, I talked with Avery Lyford,
   President and CEO of Linuxcare, which is one of the companies working
   to satisfy the demand outlined above. Avery is also an IBM veteran who
   knows the enterprise space extremely well, especially where Linux is
   involved. "It's done," he said. "Linux is a lock. The only remaining
   resistance is around open-source development, and that's only because
   a lot of IT people still don't understand it. But that will change
   soon, too. Count on it."

   Right before I talked to Avery, an IT guy at a Fortune 50 company
   pulled me aside to talk about the rapid movement toward widespread
   Linux deployment at his firm. All he needed to finish making it
   happen, he said, was a few hard numbers. "Do you know any?" he said. I
   told him to watch his e-mail. This morning I sent him the numbers I
   just shared with the rest of you.

   A few weeks back I asked Eric Raymond if he thought we had reached the
   final stage outlined by Mohandas Gandhi's famous quote: "First they
   ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, then you
   win."

   He replied, "Still GandhiCon 3:
   http://opensource.org/halloween/halloween8.php (they fight you), I
   think, though late in that stage."

   I believe these Evans Data results may have brought us to the verge of
   GhandiCon 4.

   --
   Doc Searls:
   mailto:doc at ssc.com is Senior Editor of Linux Journal.

Subject: [PLUG] A remote admin question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303271453560.30918-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I'd like to understand why remotely logging off a user on another
workstation could cause the monitor to become unresponsive without resetting
that machine.

  I'll ssh to the other workstation and, if my fiancee has not logged out
after a couple of days, I'll kill the open application processes, then xfwm
and her login. It used to work just fine.

  Now, however, if I do that then there's no login prompt that comes up when
we twiddle the trackball or press a key on the keyboard. It's dead and
unresponsive. However, after resetting, it comes back up normally (but with
my thanks for the journaling file system!). When logging out from that
terminal, the problem doesn't appear. That is, the monitor goes into
comatose mode after a while, but wakes up upon movement of the trackball or
press of a key. I'm careful to not kill a system process (such as init) so I
don't know why this lack of response occurs.

  Any insight or thoughts?

TIA,

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Mar 27 15:35:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Mar 27 15:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 1400x1050: odd, but workable, resolution
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303271528510.30607-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

At work, I have an older 21" Tektronix monitor on my desk. It's 
capable of running at 1600x1200, but just barely. It looks blurry to 
me at that resolution, so I've settled for running it at 1280x1024.

This morning, however, I configured it to run at 1400x1050, a 
resolution I'd never previously tried.

And, you know, it's not bad. If you've got a large but aging monitor,
you might think about giving it a try.

Actually, I do a similar thing on my 17" monitor at home: it runs at 
1152x864...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
