From tjg at craigelachie.org  Thu Mar 27 21:30:02 2003
From: tjg at craigelachie.org (Timothy Grant)
Date: Thu Mar 27 21:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] /etc/hosts
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303272117580.1959-100000@inetarena.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303272117580.1959-100000@inetarena.com>
Message-ID: <200303272129.34233.tjg@craigelachie.org>

On Thursday 27 March 2003 09:18 pm, Paul R. Johnston wrote:
> I have a single Linux box (RH7.3) and no home network...yet.  I am still
> doing dial-up Internet.
>
> What should I have in /etc/hosts?  I have checked several Linux books and
> Google, and am still scratching my head about what would be best here.

Pretty much anything that you're not going to get served via DNS.

127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain	localhost

# Your machine's primary IP address if it has one.
aaa.bbb.ccc.ddd hostname.domainname.xxx   hostname 

-- 
Stand Fast,
    tjg.

www.craigelachie.org

> What should I have in /etc/hosts?  I have checked several Linux books and
> Google, and am still scratching my head about what would be best here.

  To follow on what Tim suggested, here're the first two lines from
/etc/hosts on this machine:

127.0.0.1       localhost.localdomain   localhost
192.168.55.1    salmo.appl-ecosys.com   salmo, mail

  There's an additional line for each additional host on the network --
including the virtual win98 that runs in VMware on occasion.

> This is probably a dumb question, but what's the advantage of using a word

> or texmacs? Is openoffice better at handling pictures, for example?
 
Tyler,

  The "advantage" is communicating with the unwashed masses who still use
Microsoft products. They not only provide templates and other documents in a
winWord format, but many want products delivered to them in a winWord
format. Ergo, OO.o or AbiWord.

  FWIW, OO.o suffers terribly in comparison with WordPerfect. However,
Dollar Bill did his historical job of killing it off. First, he bought a big
financial stake in Corel to "save" the company. Then he killed WordPerfect
-- at least for linux if not all together, then he sold his stake and left
Corel to flounder on the wave-beaten coast. Another -- better quality --
competitor gone.

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Mar 28 08:02:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Mar 28 08:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892 News Update
Message-ID: <1048867562.10296.2862.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends,

Ken Barber and I spent yesterday at the Capitol building speaking with
legislators about HB 2892. I am encouraged to report to you that our
visit was a success.

First, the bill is scheduled for hearing before the General Government
Committee on Thursday, April 3rd. If there is general consensus, the
committee will hold a "workshop" to discuss the bill and if a majority
"okay's" the bill, they will send it on either to the House floor for a
vote or to another committee.

Secondly, the bill moves to the Ways and Means committee. Because this
bill has the potential for having a major financial impact on the State
(read: saving them a truckload of money), the Ways and Means committee
will look at the bill from a fiscal standpoint.

Finally, if the bill passes the Ways and Means committee, it is carried
to the House floor for a vote. If it makes it to the floor for a vote
you can bet that I will be _in_ the House chambers for that and will
keep you updated just as soon as the voting is closed.

Meanwhile, Joe Daunt with Rep. Barnhart's office has done a fantastic
job of organizing a diverse list of people to testify before the
Committee. I will update you when I know more.

Here are some of the highlights of our visit:

First, we now know that a representative from Microsoft has already been
to Rep. Krummel's office for a visit. Apparently, Microsoft told Krummel
that this is an "anti-Microsoft" bill. I am told that Krummel indicated
to the Microsoft representative to the effect that that was patently
false. I doubt that MS will get much traction with the legislature,
especially given the serious budget cuts they have recently endured.

By the way, Rep. Krummel is very knowledgeable about this issue. I
thought going into the meeting that I would be doing a lot of talking. I
learned very quickly in the meeting that I would be doing a lot of
listening. He already knew!! If you are a small business owner or care
about open source, this is one man you definitely want in your corner;
he is extremely knowledgeable about the challenges that face these two
groups.

Second, we have _huge_ support for this bill, including:

  Steven McGeady, former VP of Intel. 
  Larry Rosen, Council for the Open Source Initiative
  Joseph Scott Miller, Law professor at Lewis & Clark College
  Quentin Harman, Technology Coordinator for Fern Ridge School District
  Shane Warden, O'Reilly
  
There are many, many others. I have a three page list and we're still in
the early stages.

Red Hat contacted Rep. Barnhart's office while we were meeting with the
Committee legislators. I will follow up with them today. 

Over the weekend Rep. Barnhart's office will work to get a better
picture of where the committee members' support lies with this bill. I
am scheduled to call at 1:00 p.m. on Monday to find out where our
efforts are needed in support of HB 2892.

On a personal note, I was truly amazed to see the system in action. The
capitol building is just absolutely humming with activity. I was witness
to a House floor vote. Let me tell you, when it comes time for a vote
they bar the doors and post the guards. These guys are not kidding. 

The Representative's offices themselves each has a cubical area that is
open to the hallway as you pass by. The cubical is very accessible. One
feels invited to walk right up to their Representative's assistant and
schedule an appointment; it's just amazing! Overall I felt a sense that
the Representatives actually cared, that the work they do is important.

Again, thanks to all of you who have written, called, or visited in
support of this bill. I cannot stress enough that without your support
none of this would have happened.

If you haven't yet written or called your legislator in support of this
bill I urge you to do so. The toughest fight is yet to come and we need
all of the support we can get. If you need to find out who your
legislator is, you can find out here:

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/findlegsltr/findset.htm

Please know that your legislators very much welcome your input. I
encourage each of you to take the time to schedule an appointment to
meet with them.

I'll keep you posted.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Mar 28 10:15:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Mar 28 10:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Differences: Mozilla & Opera
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303281006510.1829-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I just learned something both interesting and bothersome: the PostScript
files produced by mozilla-1.2.0 and opera-6.0 when printing to disk are
different. This would not be an issue except that the flavor produced by
Opera cannot be translated into ASCII text by ghostview-6.52.

  I printed a Web page with opera to a disk file. A table did not properly
display because it's wider than the page. So I decided to translate it to
text and re-format it so I could print it out. No luck: gv error. However,
when I went back with mozilla, it worked like a charm.

  And I thought that postscript was postscript and that the 6.52 version of
ghostscript/-view could handle the different ps versions.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Mar 28 11:16:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Mar 28 11:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Differences: Mozilla & Opera
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303281006510.1829-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 28 Mar 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> And I thought that postscript was postscript...

PostScript is a programming language, albeit one optimized for 
handling bitmaps, graphics elements, and text.

Just like differnet compilers produce different assembly code, so 
different PostScript drivers produce different .ps files.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Fri Mar 28 14:31:01 2003

Date: Fri Mar 28 14:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Lycoris NFS?

On Fri, 2003-03-28 at 15:51, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> I read an article recently (
> http://www.linuxworld.com/site-stories/2002/1104.barr.html ) about using
> Knoppix as a GUI installer for Debian, but I haven't tried the technique
> yet. (Gotta' finish remodeling the bathroom first.)
> 
> Daniel Petcher
> http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

Hello,

I'm new here. Or rather, not there yet--I'm planning on moving to
Portland soon, and thought I'd start reading the local LUG. =)

I have used Knoppix as a GUI installer for Debian in a couple of ways,
and it's fabulously useful. It's been said by various people I've talked
to that you can determine if a machine (and its hardware) will be
supported by Linux by plopping in a Knoppix cd and booting. If it finds
the hardware in question, it's supported. If not, you're going to have a
bitch of a time figuring out how to get the thing working. =)

That said, there's a problem with the using-knoppix-as-a-gui method,
which is that Knoppix's install method installs EVERYTHING. So you end
up with 2 gigs of crap, which if you have the space is great cause you
rarely find you need anything, but if you're a minimalist like me, is
irritating. However, if you want to do that, here's how you do it:

Pop a Knoppix 3.1 cd into the cd drive, and boot to it. If you haven't a
bootable cd, grab their floppy. Once the GUI comes up, you can play with
it and decide if you like it, or you can just go and install it by
switching to the first virtual terminal (ctrl-alt-f1, as I'm sure
everyone knows) and typing knx-hdinstall . It's graphical, but very
barebones. You've got to have 2.2 or so gigs free, and such.

So I moved on to another method: boot knoppix, format the hard drive
that you want to install on, mount it, and run the command debootstrap
(it's usually debootstrap [woody|sid] /mount/point, but I always look it
up anyway in the man pages). This gives you the bare debian installation
with no frills, into which you copy Knoppix's configuration files (X,
network stuff, modules) and Knoppix's kernel, and you have a working
system (With a bit of tweaking). It definitely requires some work
though.

However, I have also installed Just Plain Debian, and I have to say that
it's not really so bad. You don't need to know truly arcane things,
until you get to X configuration. Then Debian requires you to know
Everything And More (EAM, or part of REAM, REALLY Everything And More
=). 

Debian, though, is FABULOUS if you have a) a truly simple graphics card,
like the Matrox MGA/Millennium (I, II), or b) no need for X. 

If you're looking for a user-friendly debian distribution, and knoppix
is too large, you might also consider Xandros. I've been hearing
fabulous things about the install--that it's as good as Knoppix, and
that the install is actually meant for installing).

Jeff

systems software at IDC."

and its successors, it is infeasible to rebuild the software for Windows NT 4.0
to eliminate the vulnerability," Microsoft said."

> lots if exacting and specific info about the hardware.

Not true, I am not a developer, and I can install debian.  All you
really have to know is how you want your hard drive partitioned, and the
name of the module that your network card uses.  The former is hardly
expert knowledge, and the latter can be found by trial and error (and
some educated guessing).  Everything else is laid out for you, all you
have to do is read and answer simple questions.

> 
> I don't want to be 1/2 way through this and suddenly find I have to take the 
> guts apart to find out 'How many cylinders are on /dev/hd1?' or some such 
> thing.
> 
> I've simply heard that Debian installs are a techno-intensive siege; I'm 
> looking for the slot-a-CD and start a video in the other room, listen for 
> 'BING,'  and your computer is now ready for a few quick NFS how-to-route 
> commands. 
> 
I'll admit it isn't that easy, you will have to come back every once in
a while to answer some more questions, but the flexibility is pretty
amazing; I've been able to install debian on a larger variety of
equipment than any other OS.

If you select the simple method for software packages, you can customize
the servers and services to run, including the choice of an X-server. 
The debian package management system is really easy to use, too.

> If there is a USER-friendly, RTFM-minimized, no-Web-research install of 
> Debian, let me know.

Tough it out through an install on an old Pentium system, it will then
be a very user-friendly install :)

Good Luck,

Derek Loree





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Mar 28 16:50:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Mar 28 16:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Another OO.o question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.53.0303281553270.16422@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303281641360.2752-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 28 Mar 2003, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> Cool, I've heard of that but didn't realize it was free.
 
Tyler,

  If you look at the pedigree it all makes sense. In the beginning Donald
Knuth created TeX. About a year later Leslie Lamport made a set of macros to
make writing in TeX easier, and that was named LaTeX. Many generations later
someone wore out the backslash and curly bracket keys by writing LaTeX and
remembering all the macros, so he and his friends but a GUI wrapper on LaTeX
and called it LyX.

  One can still put raw LaTeX in the document. For some reason, it's
referred to in the LyX community as ERT (for Evil Red Text because the
embedded LaTeX code is displayed in red). Shrug.

  There are still a number of masochists (one of whom I know) who still
write in raw TeX. Not LaTeX, TeX. That's like writing the linux kernel in
machine language. Shudder! But, as it is written, different strokes for
different folks.

  Have fun and be productive! Oh, don't forget to check out the styles for
theses, dissertations and various publications.

Rich

#!/usr/bin/perl

$a = "name";
$b = 5;

my $c = "name";
my $d = 5;

print ".D(${a}[$b])\n";
print ".D(${c}[$d])\n";

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Mar 28 18:11:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri Mar 28 18:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating glibc on RH
Message-ID: <3E85009B.10305@pacifier.com>

This has always bugged me: when updating the glibc libs there is a batch of 
stuff in the i386 tree, but then there are a few in i686, namely 
glibc-2.2.5-43.i686.rpm

Since all my machines are i686 class, I'd prefer to use this as opposed to 
the i386 version.  But you can't, because it needs the matching version of 
glibc-common from the i386 branch.  If you first update i386/glibc* then try 
to update i686/glibc* nothing happens becasue rpm doesn't see any difference 
between glibc-2.2.5-43.i686.rpm and glibc-2.2.5-43.i386.rpm

So it looks like I need to do this from the i386 tree

# rpm -Fvh glibc-devel-* glibc-common-* glibc-profile-* glibc-debug-static-* 
   glibc-utils-* ../i686/glibc-*

That's just seems ugly.  Not so bad if your repository is on localhost, but 
  you have to script this for ftp on a lan.  At least if they symlinked the 
stuff common to both archs life would be easier.

Having said that, I have used the i386 glibc on celerons & pentiums with no 
adverse effects.  Anyone know how to determine which arch of glibc you have 
installed?

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

I have a web server running at home using Apache.  I have not been able
to get the service to start automatically when I boot.  All the
documentation points to having httpd started using ntsysv.  The problem
is that I don't have an httpd service sitting on the computer.

I'm running red hat 7.3.  What do I need to do to get the apache server
to start on boot and/or how do I get the httpd service so that I can use
ntsysv to start up the service?

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Mar 29 09:22:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat Mar 29 09:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HTTPD Question
References: <1048915422.1750.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3E85D62C.7010104@pacifier.com>

Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I have a web server running at home using Apache.  I have not been able
> to get the service to start automatically when I boot.  All the
> documentation points to having httpd started using ntsysv.  The problem
> is that I don't have an httpd service sitting on the computer.
> 
> I'm running red hat 7.3.  What do I need to do to get the apache server
> to start on boot and/or how do I get the httpd service so that I can use
> ntsysv to start up the service?

My systems are RH 7.3, so this should all be relevant.  The apache rpm 
should have installed /etc/init.d/httpd

Assuming that it did
# service httpd start

should do it.  If you don't have this script, try erasing apache and 
reinstalling.

To make it happen on boot,
#chkconfig httpd on

(by default, this will start the daemon in runlevels 3,4,5)

--
Kyle Accardi

From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Mar 29 18:22:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sat Mar 29 18:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HTTPD Question
In-Reply-To: <1048982767.1643.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1048915422.1750.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <3E85D62C.7010104@pacifier.com>
	 <1048982767.1643.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1048990856.23128.58.camel@red>

On Sat, 2003-03-29 at 16:06, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I did not use the rpm to install it.  HTTPD is absent on the server. 
> How do I get the HTTPD deamon on there using the source, which is all I
> have been able to find.

Just compile Apache according to the directions in the INSTALL
file. Since it's not an RPM, you'll have to make decisions
about the directories that should be used. If you have no
idea about what directories you should use, choose /opt/web.
Then you'll be able to manually launch Apache with this command:

/opt/apachectl start

You can create a httpd file in the /etc/init.d directory 
by copying abother of the files in the directory and modifying
it. Use the above command in that file to start Apache and
this command to stop it:

/opt/apachectl/ stop

If you're not up for all this, you're better off finding
an Apache RPM, so all this will be done for you automagically.

If others respond with Red Hat-centric advice, ignore what
I say and follow their advice. I'm not a Red Hat enthusiast.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

Be careful that you don't do that as a function of MWVLUG if the LUG
is an official 501(c) charitable organization, because only a PAC can
lobby, not a charity.  Even if you're not a charitable organization
yet, if you ever decide to do that in the future, lobbying will kill
your app.

I've been on the board of three 501(c)3's.  The rules are pretty
carefully worded.  Charities cannot be politically active.  PACs don't
get tax-deductible contributions.  That's why they're distinct.

> press of a key. I'm careful to not kill a system process (such as init) so

> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

>                        Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)

> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

I can't tell you why the method you described causes trouble.  However, I 
thought I'd mention that just sending a SIGHUP to the X process, i.e.

kill -1 pid_of_X_process

or

kill -HUP pid_of_X_process

will log her off without having to kill all of those other processes 
individually.

Mark

I've never had a need to try it.

From cccs at teleport.com  Sun Mar 30 12:56:03 2003
From: cccs at teleport.com (Rick Konold)

On Sunday 30 March 2003 11:19, you hammered the keyboard to write:
> I was there the other day looking for a small/thin pc.  I was dismayed to
> learn that they don't sell their hardware to the public.  There is a bit of
> stuff in the "store" but there was many cool-looking boxes piled up next
> door in the window that are off-limits to non-non-profits (although I am
> unemployed, don't think that counts.)

This is true, but needs some clarification.  The www.freegeek.org website 
says it all, but this is the gist of it breifly.  The Primary Mission of Free 
Geek is to recycle computers in a responsible manner, and prevent their 
dumping into landfills.  

As part of that mission, we also provide a means for people who cannot afford 
to purchase a computer to get one in exchange for hours worked in our 
processing of donated equipment.  We also make equipment available to local 
non-profits as we are able.  

We try to provide other services to the community, including in various 
education classes, mostly Linux related.  (see website for listing).

It was never the intention of Free Geek to be a reseller of used computers 
and components.  However there are many items that are not needed to complete 
our main mission, and these are offered for sale to the public in our Thrift 
Store.  While not everything you might want is for sale, there are many cool 
things available.  For example large monitors, various expansion cards, 
inkjet and lazer printers.   We often have things like PDA's, Zip Drives,  
and speaker sets with sub-woofers, depending on the whim of the donating 
public.

In closing, I will make a plea to save some of our white elephants.  We have 
a lot of old Sun boxes and monitors, as well as a couple of SGI's, and an HP 
NetServer that we need to be rid of, before we have to recycle them by a more 
destructive means.

Thanks for your support of our mission.

Rick Konold ~~ Linux Advocate
Free Geek Sales Coordinator

From bspears at easystreet.com  Sun Mar 30 13:06:03 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Sun Mar 30 13:06:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CDROM filename problem
In-Reply-To: <1049052599.2687.288.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <1049048647.7030.2.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
	<1049052599.2687.288.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1049058481.7030.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>

Yup, its a problem with mkisofs. It needs an -R option to cause it to
write extra info that allows the files on the CD to appear to have stuff
like uid, gid, ownership and proper file names.

The book I used before, Red Hat Linux 7.3 Bible, forgot to mention this,
perhaps thinking that a Linux user might deep in his heart prefer DOS
file names.

Correct usage: mkisofs -R -o /tmp/whatever.cd  /home/weewillywinkle

> The OSU surplus sales sometimes have good deals:
> http://www.property.orst.edu
> I heard the last sale had ultraII's going for $20... I also heard some

I love going to the OSU auctions, they always have some great deals and
bidding for things in a live auction is always fun.  Beware though, the
more "exotic" computers (non-Intel boxes that is) they almost always
come by the pallet and there's typically 10-15 per pallet, however you
can often pick up a pallet full of interesting computers for $20.

You can often get good deals on office furniture too if you don't mind
it being a little old and sometimes slightly beat up (but still
functional).  All the used office furniture places in town have prices
at least an order of magnitude more expensive than what I've picked up
stuff in Corvallis for.

--Brent

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Sun Mar 30 17:14:01 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Sun Mar 30 17:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] shell drain bamage
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303301709050.26355-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>


You know it's time to put the keyboard down and walk away when....


I have a bash script that which needs to cd to arbitrary users' home
directories. I cannot assume the home directories are in /home and 
the account info is pulled from different sources (pam_ldap, pam_smb, etc)
so I can't just grep /etc/password.

With tilde expansion, this is a piece of cake:

	cd ~bob 

but if "bob" is in an environment variable, it breaks because the tilde
expansion occurs first:

	export FOO=bob
	cd ~$FOO
	bash: cd: ~bob: No such file or directory


Would someone be so kind as to hit me with a clue stick on this one? ;-)

-Eric

From griffint at pobox.com  Sun Mar 30 18:02:02 2003

	bash: cd: ~bob: No such file or directory

"cd ~$FOO"  is executed before eval is executed, which puts me back into
the same problem of "~" expanding before "$FOO" expands.

Terry's approach:

	export FOO=bob
	eval "cd ~$FOO"

works because $FOO is expanded by the shell and then

	eval "cd /home/bob"

is executed.


This would have been so much easier in perl ;-)

Thanks for the help!

-Eric

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Sun Mar 30 20:29:02 2003
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sun Mar 30 20:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of FreeGeek
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303301450380.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303301450380.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sunday March 30, 2003 15:01, Geoff Burling wrote:

> Slashdot had an item about this not too long ago. Wacky Willy's was all
> that was mentioned for the Portland area. I snarfed a link to Seattle
> area used hardware stores which I can share if anyone is interested.
> (One place that got frequent mention was the Boeing resale store: I
> wonder if Tektronix or Mentor Graphics ever had a similar junk store.)

Boeing surplus is fairly good, but the pickings can range from weird (bins 
full of 8" tires ), to full size plotters, Macs, the odd RS6000 CAD 
workstation etc.  I didn't think the prices were as low as I thought they 
should be, but they are still pretty cheap for most stuff.  You can also 
pick up some very interestingly shaped bits of aircraft-grade aluminum 
while you are there :-)

Seattle City Surplus is good if you can find it.  I've picked up several 
(10+) Pentium 133 machines for $5 each w/video, RAM, CDROM, HD, floppy 
etc.  I.e. all working.  When I bought 5 machines, they let me carry away 
as many PCI and ISA network cards as I could find.  They've also got a lot 
of laser printers. I picked up a fully functional HP 4MV (prints up to 
11"x17") for $30.  How much and what they have varies a lot.

They rarely have anything exotic, but for a firewall or spare parts, it's 
pretty good.  They often have office equipment too, like copiers.

Best,
Kyle




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Mar 30 20:30:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Mar 30 20:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] shell drain bamage
In-Reply-To: <1049083908.9983.2.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <mailman.1049078061.28750.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	 <867kagnrae.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
	 <1049083908.9983.2.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <1049084978.1745.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-03-30 at 20:11, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> Or:
> HOMEDIR=~
> FOO=bob
> cd $HOMEDIR/$BOB

Nope.  You've mis-interpreted the request: Not "~/bob" but "~bob" (i.e.,
not $HOME/bob, but bob's $HOME).  In your example, the "~" gets expanded
when you set the variable--try 'echo $HOMEDIR' and you'll get your home
directory.  Even if you quote the tilde it does not work.

Wil

From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Mon Mar 31 01:59:01 2003
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Mon Mar 31 01:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] xmms difficulties
In-Reply-To: <UTXW71ZTMK74DBSNZWOKUPLH31D9SQ06.3e87fc8a@miked>
Message-ID: <20030331095800.42115.qmail@web13808.mail.yahoo.com>

Maybe you need to kill a daemon or program that's
using up your sound device. see if "killall esd"
works. I never get problems with xmms, but other
programs seem to like it when I do this.

If that doesn't work, try playing a file from another
format, such as Ogg Vorbis. CD's don't count because
the CD drive often has a direct connection to the
Sound Card.

From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Mon Mar 31 02:31:02 2003
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Mon Mar 31 02:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CDROM filename problem
In-Reply-To: <1049058481.7030.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <20030331103001.36061.qmail@web13804.mail.yahoo.com>

I find that -r is often times better. It sets the
owner  and group of all the files on the CD to root,
and sets everything to chmod 444 or 555 as
appropriate. I've gotten headaches about mismatching
UID's if I try to access an old '-R' cd's after I've
wiped my drive clean and installed a new distro, thus
having to login as root to just copy the file. (It
seems that I had a few chmod 600 files).

Also if you plan on using these CD's with Windows, It
would be a good idea to use the -J flag too for long
filenames in Windows 95+. I, personally, don't have
any intention of using Windows, but I set this flag
just in case.

Peace,
Vincent Damewood

From ziggy at anodizing.com  Mon Mar 31 08:49:01 2003
From: ziggy at anodizing.com (Abraham Zwygart)
Date: Mon Mar 31 08:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] fyi, Installing Mandrake 9.1 Notes
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0303281358580.2173-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3E88714E.7080508@anodizing.com>

Hi all,
I was having trouble last week installing Mandrake 9.1.  Found the problem.
My down load of the 3rd disc was bad.

Got a interesting point.  When you are install 9.1 and when you come to
a screen asking you if you wish to check for updates, the default is no, 
change this
to 'yes'.  If you don't the install will freeze later on and it does not 
install correctly.
I tried installing 5 different ways and it kept locking up at the end. 
 It wasn't until
I checked yes on the check for updates screen that the install worked.

Have a good day
Abraham Zwygart

From richard at freegeek.org  Mon Mar 31 09:13:01 2003
From: richard at freegeek.org (Richard Seymour)
Date: Mon Mar 31 09:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of FreeGeek
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303301450380.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>
References: <3E874350.60605@pacifier.com>
        <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303301450380.15491-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <1055.207.202.132.70.1049130840.squirrel@anarchysoftware.com>

Geoff Burling wrote:
> On Sun, 30 Mar 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:
>>I was there the other day looking for a small/thin pc.  I was dismayed to
>>learn that they don't sell their hardware to the public.  There is a bit of
>>stuff in the "store" but there was many cool-looking boxes piled up next
>>door in the window that are off-limits to non-non-profits (although I am
>>unemployed, don't think that counts.)


As Rick pointed out, our main mission is to recycle computers and give
them away for free. (Both those things, plus teaching people about the
technology and issues are part of the mission, which gets complicated to
expalin to folks, but hey -- life is complicated!) The store is a way to
support the main mission, so some things (that would detract from the free
products we create) will never be in the store. Though what those things
are will change over time.

> Try to find Rick Konold & ask him for help.



Rick's job is Sales Coordinator, so he's a logical person to look for. But
also, any volunteer working in the store should be able to help out.

The reason the other staff members and volunteers may seem to have an
"attitude" about what gets sold is pretty simple. All the staff at FREE
GEEK have a zillion responsibilities to manage at any given time. Quite a
number of people walk into FG expecting that it is primarily a store, and
therefor expect us to drop what we're doing to service them. We try to
politely point them to Rick and the store, so that we can get back to:

- teaching people who don't even know how to click a mouse about computers,


- getting the zillions of donations into the database (again showing
volunteers that range from complete newbies on up how to do the job
without making too many mistakes)
- getting tested stuff built into computers,


- bringing people who want to learn how to build computers up to the point
where they can learn that (teaching how to identify all the components,
understand BIOS and resource conflict issues, etc.),

- teaching coding skills and developing software for testing hardware,
running the database, getting linux onto the FreekBoxen,

- dealing with industrial recylcers,


- working with end users to make the distro choices as simple to use as
possible.

Anyway, there's a lot going on. Many people to needed to help. Drop by and
ask about volunteering if you're so inclined (and haven't already
started).
--
These things must be done -- delicately!
Richard Seymour
The Man Behind the Curtain
FREE GEEK

--- Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com> wrote:
> But if I'm backing up a home directory -R would be

I wouldn't. The thing is, RockRidge stores UID's, not
usernames. So when I went back to get some
files--despite the fact that both when writting and
reading the cd my username was 'vince'--the UID's
didn't match and I still got those problems. I guess
it would work if you add users by editing /etc/passwd
directly and give the same user the same UID each
time.

If I need to keep file permissions intact I just use
tar, other wise -r works for me.

* mike <mike at linuxlink.com> [2003-03-31 11:15]:
> What next?
> 
> Here is one example of the far-reaching harmful effects of these bills.
> Both bills would flatly ban the possession, sale, or use of technologies
> that "conceal from a communication service provider ... the existence or
> place of origin or destination of any communication". Your ISP is a
> communication service provider, so anything that concealed the origin or
> destination of any communication from your ISP would be illegal -- with
> no exceptions.

I think a valid arguement could be made that you aren't hiding anything, since the packets have valid headers on them, otherwise, they wouldn't work. 

No, they aren't in plain text, but they must be vaild packets with both origin and destination in the headers. 

The same could be said for NAT. Even though your NAT system readdresses the packet, you're not hiding the origin (you still send it through the gateway, didn't you?) and obviously, if the packet reaches it's destination, it must be listed too.

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Mon Mar 31 13:41:01 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Mon Mar 31 13:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network popup message on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <18930.12.47.207.251.1049143144.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <18930.12.47.207.251.1049143144.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1049128787.1369.26.camel@zadie>

On Mon, 2003-03-31 at 15:39, Matt Alexander wrote:
> In Windows you can send a popup message to everyone in a domain/workgroup.
>  For example, a window would popup and say, "Please logout of the file
> server."
> 
> Does anyone have a suggestion on how this could be done for Linux clients?
>  In addition, if this could also be initiated from a Windows client, that
> would be useful.  We have a mixed Windows/Linux environment so ideally I'd
> like to be able to send messages both ways.
> Thanks,
> ~Matt

We do this sometimes to let us know when programs are finished on the
servers (unix). It's not too hard from unix-to-unix or from
windows-to-unix, but unix-to-windows or windows-to-windows might be
problematic.

>From Windows to Linux is easy:

set up the Linux x servers to accept tcp connections (get rid of the
default on most linux installs of -nolisten tcp), and set up your xhost
properties to allow connections from the localhost with a specific user
(you'll probably want to create a special user on the linux boxes so
that it is a bit harder to abuse and so you can add an environment
variable "DISPLAY=:0.0" in the login scripts), and then when you want to
send a message to a box, you can use any command line ssh program (there
are several for windows) to do this:

ssh messageuser at linuxclient xmessage <message>

You can use the xmessage options or run another program if you want
(hey, you could have xeyes pop up when you did something wrong! =) to
customize what it looks like. This works from linux-to-linux and from
windows-to-linux, but for linux-to-windows you'll need to figure out a
way to run a) an ssh server, b) a program from the command line that
pops up a message, etc.

Also, if you generate sshkeys you can script this so that you can have
it autogenerate messages.

Jeff

My goal was to collect as much information as I could about the bug
before posting it.  When I was on p5p it was sad to see just how much
time was spent saying, upgrade, read the release notes, RTFM, and so
on.  As it turns out, someone on p5p had already encountered and
submitted a patch for it, so my posting to perlbug didn't help much
anyway.

> Colin> p.s. If you're wondering why I didn't send this to the local Perl
> Colin> Monger group, then check out their early archives when the group was
> Colin> set up.  At the time, they were disinclined to do "helpdesk" kind of
> Colin> stuff, and there's been no email since to indicate that things have
> Colin> changed.  Of course, many of them do that kind of stuff anyway on
> Colin> comp.lang.perl.misc and perlmonks anyway so it's no big thing.
> 
> Dude, you give pdx.pm a disrespectful nod that is just FUD.  You
> should have just asked, and taken the heat if it was offtopic.  Lots
> more Perl people there than here.

I've been on the pdx.pm mailing list for years (~3), and since the
emails about not wanting to do user support/RTFM/newbie q's there
hasn't been more than a handful of emails asking for help with simple
code or bugs.

Don't you think I didn't consider writing to pdx.pm about this?  Why
not ask the likes of chromatic and schwern, who do presentations about
Perl testing?  Or yourself and Tom Phoenix, or Ovid, or Ingy?  (None of
the other posters are slackers, either)  I've been part of p5p,
comp.lang.perl and comp.lang.perl.*, and just joined perlmonks.  pdx.pm
is the only online user community I've found who, at its inception,
decided not to do general user support.

At the time there were maybe 5 or 6 of us, I don't even think you'd
joined yet, and it was the height of the comp.lang.perl.misc flames
about how to deal with newbies.  (RTFM, flamage, helpfulness, or
whatever)  People were concerned about being buried with newbie
questions and lowering the signal to noise ratio to the point where the
mailing list wasn't useful.

It was a decision that I didn't (and don't) like, but respect.  And I'd
grant you that pdx.pm has changed a lot since it was created.  I went
back through the email archives, and have found a few questions (1 or 2
per month), but most of the traffic is notices about OSCON, the
programming reading group, meetings, social meetings, visits, buying
and writing books, and so on, but not many, if any, asking for help
about core programming issues instead of application level stuff.

If you want to read some real FUD, please go check out the recent
Computer Bits article about PHP and Perl.

Colin

p.s. I'd love to show you the emails, but it was way back when
majordomo was used and I don't have the emails in my own archive.  I
realize that that's too convenient an excuse, so if you can find the
emails and show me that I'm wrong, I'll apologize.

From wally at walstr.org  Mon Mar 31 21:04:02 2003
From: wally at walstr.org (Wally Wharton)
Date: Mon Mar 31 21:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network popup message on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <18930.12.47.207.251.1049143144.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303312051510.10965-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>

On Mon, 31 Mar 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:

: In Windows you can send a popup message to everyone in a domain/workgroup.
:  For example, a window would popup and say, "Please logout of the file
: server."
:
: Does anyone have a suggestion on how this could be done for Linux clients?
:  In addition, if this could also be initiated from a Windows client, that
: would be useful.  We have a mixed Windows/Linux environment so ideally I'd
: like to be able to send messages both ways.
:

man smbclient

WinPopup messages are part of the smb protocol, and are limited to
1600 bytes in length.  From Linux to Windows, you can use the -M
switch to `smbclient'.  See the message command parameter in the
smb.conf(5) for a description of how to handle incoming WinPopup
messages in Samba.

Wally
